loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
The following description was written by Moses O., a volunteer with Village Enterprise Fund and partner representative for Kiva in Uganda:

Justine O. is among the most successful small-scale business leaders.

He got a grant of 100 US dollars from VEF. He started by buying and selling of goats right away. Most butchers have known his business, so a number of them come to him to buy goats.

He can now buy and sell between 15 and 20 goats in a month -- a great amount.

The market is very open since most of Ugandans rear goats and cows for raising money whenever needs arise like school fees, sickness, death, journey etc.

O. has attended business training and he is capable of handling the loan and paying it back.

Given a loan of 500 US dollars, he is targeting to introduce bulls for slaughter and opening up a butcher shop himself.

loans.use: Buy bulls, open a butcher shop

payments.comment: This group made the first effort to make the payment of the loan money by giving 51,000 Ugandan Shillings that is equivalent to $30. More updates will come in the next news. Pasor Moses Onyango.

They have registered the second installment payment of the loan in Ugandan shillings 82.0000 worth $50. In the next few weeks, they are promising to make another payment. Good profit is being realized in this bussiness. God bless you all who are the funders of this loan. Yours Pastor Moses Onyango.

This bussiness has payed 82,500 ugandan shillings that is equivalent to $50. This is one of the great move this bussiness has done to show that its able to recover all the loan money without any difficulty. Also, this is one of the signs of a progressing business. keep this bussiness in your prayers always. If the active poor can do this in order to deliver them selves out from povety,its amazing. Thanks once again for supporting this bussiness. Yours Pastor Moses Onyango.

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
The following description was written by Moses Onyango, a volunteer with Village Enterprise Fund and partner representative for Kiva in Uganda:

Geoffrey O. J. is one of the most hard-working beneficiaries in Tororo District.

He got a grant of 100 US dollars form Village Enterprise Fund as a kick start.

He started with baking local bread called Mandazi, Kabalagala (pan cakes) and also Samosa.

After attending training on business skills twice, he got wide knowledge on how to choose and run his businesses effectively.

He then shifted to running a produce business, including the buying and selling of millet, sorghum, rice, groundnuts, peas, beans, green grams and sunflowers.

His business picked up very much and he got enough profit to hire a store for stocking the produce before selling it.

He now moves around the district buying all the produce from the beneficiaries of Village Enterprise Fund.

I expect him to do greater business to bring development in the lives of our people who are the poor of the poorest.

Given a loan of 500 US dollars, he will excel very much.

He is capable to handle repay the loan effectively.

loans.use: Buying more produce each time for greater profit

loans.name: Apollo

texts.en:
The following description was written by Moses Onyango, a volunteer with Village Enterprise Fund and partner representative for Kiva in Uganda:

Apollo is a very hard-working man in his business.

He got a grant of 100 US dollars from VEF. He stated by buying and rearing of goats before selling. After selling over 10 goats, his business improved such that he was able to buy 10 Ã± 15 goats from the villages around and then eventually to the central market for better profit.

He has done this business for 3 years.

Given a loan of 500 US dollars, he is planing to continue with goats business and with time he will introduce bulls for slaughter.

Apollo is capable of handling and paying back the loan promptly.

loans.use: Increase number of goats bought and sold each time for greater profits

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice received 100 dollar grant from Village Enterprise Fund.

She started a small scale business of selling essential commodities.

When she realized a good profit, she decided to start a new business of buying and selling used clothes. This is a very paying business because of the open market.

Most of our people in the community are very poor such that they can not afford to buy brand new clothes. Therefore all are ready to go in for used clothes.

Eunice is making some good money out of her little capital.

Given a loan of 300 US Dollars, she will improve on her business by buying better quality Mitumbas that can raise good profit for her.

She is capable of handling the loan and also to refund it.

loans.use: Buy used clothing (mutumbe) of higher quality so it can be sold at a higher price for higher profits

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
The following description was written by Moses Onyango, a volunteer with Village Enterprise Fund and partner representative for Kiva in Uganda:

Rose got a grant of 100 US dollars from VEF. She started straight away with her business of buying and selling produce.

She buys and sells the following items: millet, sorghum, rice, beans, dry cassava, peas, etc.

Most of the people in Uganda live by agriculture. So the only way for the community to raise money for supporting themselves is by selling off their food crops to the available market.

Uganda lies on equatorial region so this makes it to receive rain throughout the year. Thus people are able to plant and harvest their crops thrice a year. This gives RoseÃ­s business of produce to run all throughout the year.

She is able to raise some money out of her small capital to support her family.

Given the 500 US dollars, she will excel in her business very well.

She is capable of handling the loan and also to refund it back.

loans.use: Buying and reselling of produce

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
The following description was written by Moses Onyango, a volunteer with Village Enterprise Fund and partner representative for Kiva in Uganda:

Christine was given a grant of 100 US Dollars by Village Enterprise Fund.

Immediately she opened up an eating house for the people within the community, travellers and school children. Her Kiosk is strategically placed such that she is able to receive over 50 customers per day.

She started by cooking simple food like beans and also posho, millet bread, some rice and also selling drinks like tea and juice.

After attending the business training that was organized by Village Enterprise Fund, she improved on her menu by introducing meat, chicken, fish, milk tea, sodas etc.

This has earned her a good profit such that she is able to meet her home needs, buy scholastic materials for her school-going children and also medical attention.

Given a loan of 300 US dollars, she is planning to expand her business by buying Nice Utensils, plates, cutleries, enlarge the shelter, buy varieties of foodstuffs, improve hygiene of the place, contact more institutions to be fed in her food Kiosk.

She is capable of handling the loan and refunding it back.

loans.use: Buy better utensils, plates, and cutleries, and buying building supplies to enlarge restaurant

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
The following description was written by Moses Onyango, a volunteer with Village Enterprise Fund and partner representative for Kiva in Uganda:

Elizabeth O. is a widow with seven children in her family.

Village Enterprise Fund (VEF) donated 100 Dollar grant to her in the year 2000.

She started with a small business of selling greens, tomatoes, onions and cooking oil. He business continued well for a period of eight months as she realized some profits.

In 2001, VEF organized for business training course for all the beneficiaries in Tororo District. She happened to be among the participants who attended the training.

She learnt how to choose a profitable business, marketing, book keeping and business strategies.

She then decided to change her business to Fish Mongering.

Here she got a better market whereby the profit in her business has enabled her to buy goats, cow, pigs, chicken and also taking her children to school.

Given a loan of US $500, she will be capable of doing better business, by expanding her stock and also shift to Tororo town in order to meet the middle man for the progress of her business.

She is capable to handle the loan and to pay it back promptly.

Being a widow, I know that she will be helped a lot in development of her family.

loans.use: Increase stock, open new location in Tororo town (as opposed to village area)

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is married with four children, and also cares for three orphans added to their family. She started her business with a goal of succeeding in it.

She was given a donation of 100 US Dollars by Village Enterprise in 2000 and has attended five trainings that were conducted by VEF.

Betty is capable of handling the loan money very well. She plans to buy the following with the loan money: - maize, millet, sorghum, peas, groundnuts, simsim etc. Betty is planing to buy the items in bulk depending on the most needed item in the market.

She wants to make sure that in each purchase, she gains a good profit to continue boosting the bussiness and paying the loan. She has good relationship with her customers. The loan period will be 6 months.

loans.use: Buying maize, millet, sorghum, peas, groundnuts, and sesame in bulk.

payments.comment:
This business has taken off in their operations by begining to raise profit from every day sells.
They have payed $50 for the loan refund.
Thanks alot for funding this business.
Yours Moses.

The people of Uganda are very active in business thus buying and selling during Chrismas season.
This was a very great opportunity for this business to gain more profit to increase the stock and refund the loan money.
They have refunded $100.

There was a general complaint from all the businesses that the campaigns of the resent presidential election affected the businesses very much.
People lived in fear to do their normal activities as the government soldiers were deployed all over the villages all round Uganda.
The businesses are just picking up since the country has remain peaceful.
For this reason, this business has managed to make a payment of $30 for the loan refund.
The business opportunity is now high since all the people have gone back to their usual business.
Thanks alot for funding this business.
Moses.

loans.name: Benna

texts.en:
Benna O. is a widow but not out of HIV/Aids. Her husband died of motor accident in 1988.

Benna cares for eight children. She has another relatives that she is taking care of. The total number of her family together with other dependants = 12 People. She started a small business to help her feed her children and take the to school. Village Enterprise gave her a grant money worth 100 dollars in the year 2003. She used the money well through the skills she got from the several trainings that she has received from Village Enterprise Fund.

She is capable of handling the loan money. Given a loan of 500 dollars, she will expand here business by buying the following items in large quantity: - millet, sorghum, rice, simsim, dry cassava, groundnuts.

She is very active bussiness lady with good customer relations. With her integrity, she will do her bussiness with the loan money successfully.

loans.use: Buying millet, sorghum, rice, and other cereals in bulk

payments.comment:
This business has registerd a wonderful begining in their operation. They are now realizing already some profit from their sells.
They have payed $50 to reduce the loan money.

Yours Moses.

They have paid loan money worth $100.

People lived in fear to do their normal activities as the government soldiers were deployed all over the villages all round Uganda.
The businesses are just picking up since the country has remain peaceful.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry is married with five children. This bussiness supports 9 members of the family as there are others too.

This photograph is not of Henry but Mrs O.. She is the one who seats in their retail shop, while Henry moves around doing the purshase of the goods. When you come visiting, you will find her in the bussiness and this is the reason why I have decided to send her pthoto instead of Henry's.

Henry started at the beginning with baking bricks (Building Material). After raising some money he started a small shop in his village. Village Enterprise gave him a seed grant of 100 dollars to boost his business in 2001. He has maintained the same business to this date. He has received a wonderful training as a resource person in the community. These are respected people in the community with good bussiness relations due to the several trainings that they have acquired.

Henry is capable of handling this loan money and even making the refund. He plans to use the loan money for increasing the quantity of the essential commodities in his shop e.g. Sugar, bar soap, salt, tea leaves, cooking oil, soap in powder form for washing (OMO) and for bathing, posho, beans etc. With the loan money, this bussiness will increase the quantity of the goods that they will stock in the shop.

This is a very special bussiness to the people of the community. Instead of people in the community riding their bicycles for 15 Kilometres going out to Tororo town to buy some of essential commodities for their famillies for home use,this bussiness now does the job for them. This bussiness is now providing the sevice to the people within the community by providing all their basic needs in the village.

loans.use: Increasing retail shop inventory

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is married and has 4 children. In addition to their own children, they have more 4 other people to be cared for in their family.

He started by growing 1/2 an acre of sorghum. He sold it and realized some profit which he committed to business of buying and selling dry cassava and other produce.

Given a loan of $500 to this bussiness, they plan to increase the stock of the produce to be taken to Soroti or Mbale town for better profit. They will target the most needed items by their middleman's market.

Right now the capital amount of money that they have is 520,000 Uganda shillings that is equivalent to $300. This capital is very little for this bussiness to excel.

These people are respected in the community as people of integrity. He attained business skills training with Village Enterprise Fund He is capable of handling the loan money and refunding it.

loans.use: Increase the stock of the produce to be taken to Soroti or Mbale town for better profit.

payments.comment:
As the name of this business suggests that God helps, they have seen the help of God in their business. They have started getting some profit in their daily sells.
They have payed $50 to reduce their loan money.
Thanks for your support to this business.
Yours Moses.

This business increased their stock during their Chrismas sells such that they catch up with the demand of the people of the community.
They had very wonderful sells that resulted to very good profit.
For this reason,they have repayed $100.
More story concerning this business in coming in the Journal. Remember to read for your self.
Thanks.

There was a general complaint from all the businesses that the campaigns of the resent presidential election affected the businesses very much.
People lived in fear to do their normal activities as the government soldiers were deployed all over the villages all round Uganda.
The businesses are just picking up since the country has remain peaceful.
For this reason, this business has managed to make a payment of $30 for the loan refund.
The business opportunity is now high since all the people have gone back to their usual business.
Thanks alot for funding this business.
Moses.

loans.name: Gregory

texts.en:
The name of this bussiness is called Jehova Jireh meaning that My God is a provider. Gregory E. is married and has five children. These 5 orphan children were left by his brother who died of HIV/Aids.

Gregory started with a small eating kiosk in Kamod Trading Centre for five years and realized some profits with which he bought two goats, a bicycle and he has been able to pay school fees for the son.

Later he changed his business to livestock buying and selling. This bussiness is doing the cattle trading thus,buying and selling of cows. Right now this bussiness can buy up to 4 cows at once to take to the local market for sell.

Given a loan of $500, they will improve on their stock to 8 cows for the first purchase. These cows will be driven to Soroti town cattle market for the first time in the life of this bussiness.

This will give them enough profit for the payment of the loan and the increase of the next stock. I know this man as a dedicated person with respect among all the people in the community.

He is capable of handling the loan money and refunding it. He attended training on business skills organized by VEF.

loans.use: Buying and selling 4 cows and then other livestock

payments.comment:
This business has payed $50 out the profit they have started getting from their every day sells.
Thanks alot for supporting this business with the loan money.
yours Moses.

The people of Uganda are very active in business thus buying and selling during Chrismas season.
This was a very great opportunity for this business to gain more profit to increase the stock and refund the loan money.
They have refunded $100.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is married and has 5 children. He has more 3 people living with him in his home as well who he supports.

This Bussiness is dealing in used clothes. He started by fish mongering for two years. He later changed to buying and selling of goats. When he realized some profits, he changed to buying and selling of used clothes to attain even more profits.

Right now, they can afford to buy only two bells of the used clothes. This man is a hard working man who rides on his bicycle all around market places in the villages to sell the used clothes.

Given a loan of $500, he plans to increase the stock to 8 bells. he has big number of customers who come even to his house to buy clothes.

He will be able to handle the loan money as man of integrity. He attained business skills training with Village Enterprise Fund and is well-trained to handle the loan money and refunding it.

loans.use: To increase the stock to 8 bails of used clothing

payments.comment:
This business has started very well in their operation.
They have started realizing profits in their daily sales.
They have payed $50 for their loan recovery.
More journal on this business will come soon.

Not all Ugandans are able to afford brand new cloths during the Chrismas celebration. Since this business deals in used clothes, they had to sell more than ever before because all the people in this community needed to appear in a new attire for Chrismas celebration.
This was a great chance for this business to sell and gain profit that has enabled them to refund the loan money worth $100.
Read more about this business in the next Journal.
Thanks.

There was a general complaint from all the businesses that the campaigns of the resent presidential election affected the businesses very much.
People lived in fear to do their normal activities as the government soldiers were deployed all over the villages all round Uganda.
The businesses are just picking up since the country has remain peaceful.
For this reason, this business has managed to make a payment of $30 for the loan refund.
The business opportunity is now high since all the people have gone back to their usual business.
Thanks alot for funding this business.
Moses.

loans.name: Haggai

texts.en:
Haggai A. is married and has 9 children. He and his wife also have more 4 relatives staying with them so they care for many.

Haggai started by cultivating rice for two years. He sold it and realized some profit which he used to start a retail shop business in Serere Trading Centre. This bussiness deals in the retail shop in the main village trading centre.

I (Moses Onyango, Kiva Country Director) did the stock taking in this shop, and the total amount of money in this shop both cash and in goods is 435,000 Ugandan shillings that is equivalent to $250.

Given a loan of $500, They plan to increase the stock in their shop so that even the Items that they use not to sell can be included in the stock.

Their shop is stratagically placed and they command a high number of customers. Being faithful people to all, I believe that their bussiness will prosper. Additionally Haggai attained business skills training with Village Enterprise Fund so he is capable of handling the loan money and refunding it well.

loans.use: Increasing retail store stock to include broader array of products

payments.comment:
This business has payed $50 towards the payement of loan refund.
This business is doing very well after putting the loan money into use.
More about this business will come soon in the next journal.

The people of Uganda are very active in business thus buying and selling during Chrismas season.
This was a very great opportunity for this business to gain more profit to increase the stock and refund the loan money.
They have refunded $100.

There was a general complaint from all the businesses that the campaigns of the resent presidential election affected the businesses very much.
People lived in fear to do their normal activities as the government soldiers were deployed all over the villages all round Uganda.
The businesses are just picking up since the country has remain peaceful.
For this reason, this business has managed to make a payment of $30 for the loan refund.
The business opportunity is now high since all the people have gone back to their usual business.
Thanks alot for funding this business.
Moses.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon O. is married and has 7 children.

Simon O. started a drug shop after selling 3 goats he had reared at home for three years. He got some profits and decided to divert to a drug shop business (buying and selling of human medicines).

This business is special in that it deals in the human medicine and is located in the village. Today, so many people are sick in the community such that the small health centers in the villages doesen't have enough medicine to give out to the patients. Most medical personels just recommend their patients to go and buy medicine in private drug shops, for the Govornment really stocks medicine in the rural heath centres.

But this bussiness is strategically placed deep in the rural area. Given a loan of $500, Simon plans to increase the stock by buying more medicines that is not in his stock and yet it is very much needed by the patients in the village. This will make this bussiness to earn more profit to pay the loan and increse the stock.This will fetch him enough money and profit that can help him in his family and refund of the loan.

He attended training on business skills organized by VEF and is very capable of using this loan well and repaying it in full.

loans.use: Buying of medicine for rural drug shop

payments.comment:
This business has started receiving some profit from their sells.
They have started refunding the loan by paying $50.
Thanks alot for supporting this business.
Moses.

There was a general complaint from all the businesses that the campaigns of the resent presidential election affected the businesses very much.
People lived in fear to do their normal activities as the government soldiers were deployed all over the villages all round Uganda.
The businesses are just picking up since the country has remain peaceful.
For this reason, this business has managed to make a payment of $30 for the loan refund.
The business opportunity is now high since all the people have gone back to their usual business.
Thanks alot for funding this business.
Moses.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying improved breeds (heifers) of cattle for milk and milk products - two hessians and one bull

payments.comment:
This business is doing very well now.
They have payed a loan refund of $100. More about this business will come soon in the next journal.

It is almost a culture here in Uganda that during public holidays and Chrismas, the people of the community must take milk tea. This is a pristige that shows that I have celebrated the day in a very special way.
Another thing is that all the working class people come back to the villages to re join the family members to celebrate the day togrther.
This move was a great opportunity for this dairy farm business. They sold milk more than before.
This enabled them to repay loan money worth $100.
Read more about this business in the next Journal.
Thanks.

There was a general complaint from all the businesses that the campaigns of the resent presidential election affected the businesses very much.
People lived in fear to do their normal activities as the government soldiers were deployed all over the villages all round Uganda.
The businesses are just picking up since the country has remain peaceful.
For this reason, this business has managed to make a payment of $30 for the loan refund.
The business opportunity is now high since all the people have gone back to their usual business.
Thanks alot for funding this business.
Moses.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angella A. is a wife and mother of 4 children. She has an additional 6 people that she stays with in their home and cares for them all.

This bussiness is dealing in various types of produce. She started by planting an acre of cassava, 500 suckers (seedlings) of pineapples, 1 acre of maize, groundnuts. She sold these and realized some profit which she used for buying a pig and bicycle. She has also been able to take her children to school. The agricultural business is growing with expectation of more harvest this season.

She now buys her items in small quatity because of little money in the capital. But given a loan of $500, she plans to increase her stock by buying other types of produce that is in the market but her money is not enough to buy enough to fetch her good profit.

Right now, she can buy up to 500 Kilograms of produce. When she gets the loan money, the stock will go to 1000 Kilograms.

She is a dedicated lady in her bussiness. She attained a business skills training with Village Enterprise Fund and will be keen to use the training to handle and repay the loan in a timely way.

loans.use: Buying other types of produce that is in higher demand in the market. The stock will go to 1000 Kilograms.

payments.comment:
This business has started refunding the loan money as they continue to see some profit coming into their business.
They have payed $50 to reduce the loan money.
Thanks alot for funding this business.
Yours Moses.

The people of Uganda are very active in business thus buying and selling during Chrismas season.
This was a very great opportunity for this business to gain more profit to increase the stock and refund the loan money.
They have refunded $100.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane O. is married with four children. Village Enterprise Fund donated 100 Dollars grant to her in 2001.

She is located in Muloanda trading center in Tororo, which is just near the government county headquarters. There are many business people who come from all over Tororo to this center -- over 1000 per day.

She hires bike riders that ride to the village back and forth with produce. These bike riders go to VEF farmers in the village which is called Atangaloa

She started with very small business of selling green vegetables and tomatoes. After the VEF Funding, she started a produce business.

She has attended four different trainings organised by Village Enterprise Fund.

With the loan money she is planning to expand her business by buying the produce in large quantity e.g. Millet, Maize, Sorghum, Rice, Dry Cassava, Peas, Green grams etc. Jane is capable of handling the loan money very well.

loans.use: Buying produce -- millet, maize, sorghum, rice, dry cassava, peas, green grams

payments.comment:
This business has taken a step of refunding the loan money worth $50.
This business is showing up very well in their day to day sells.
More about this business will come in the next journal soon.

This business was wise enough to increase their stock to pull the customers who were all over the community making Chrismas shopping.
This business got enough money to refund the loan money and also to increase the stock after the Chrismas sells.
They have put in a down payment of $100.
Read more about this business in the next Journal.
Thanks.

There was a general complaint from all the businesses that the campaigns of the resent presidential election affected the businesses very much.
People lived in fear to do their normal activities as the government soldiers were deployed all over the villages all round Uganda.
The businesses are just picking up since the country has remain peaceful.
For this reason, this business has managed to make a payment of $30 for the loan refund.
The business opportunity is now high since all the people have gone back to their usual business.
Thanks alot for funding this business.
Moses.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
People in the village want to scholastic materials for school going children, reams of paper, textbooks, pens, pencils, and mathmatical sets. Mathematical sets include Compasses, protractor, and rulers for technical drawers.

Every parent must buy these supplies, they are a requirement for each child in addition to school fees. People will bring their goats to the cattle market, sell them and then get money for the school supplies.

Irene O. has knowledge in Secretarial work. She is a well-trained person.

She is married to Pastor Abraham O.. They have never been funded by VEF but still they are struggling to do their work with low income and capital.

This family is well known and I believe that they are able to handle the loan very well.

They are doing their work in Soroti town and serving the many business people there with secretarial services.

Given 500 US Dollars, they will expand their business very much such that most people in the community will benefit from their services.

loans.use: Buy Stationary and other office supplies

payments.comment:
This business has gained grip of their target by winning so many customers to themselves.
They have payed money worth $50 for their loan refund.
More about this business will come soon in the journal.

This business has gained money during Chrismas through selling season cards and many other chrismas gifts.
They have paid a loan refund of $100.
Read more about this business in the next journal.
Thanks.

There was a general complaint from all the businesses that the campaigns of the resent presidential election affected the businesses very much.
People lived in fear to do their normal activities as the government soldiers were deployed all over the villages all round Uganda.

For this reason, this business has managed to make a payment of $30 for the loan refund.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is widow with nine children.

She has been doing grocery business for very long time.

Village Enterprise Fund gave her a donation of 100 dollars in the year 2001.

She has undergone training for the beneficiaries organised by VEF.

She is capable to use and refund the loan. Given a loan of 300 dollars, she plans to expand her business by buying the following items: - cooler for her green vegetables than can go bad e.g. tomatoes, onions, cabbages, fresh beans and peas.

We have some coolers in Uganda that you can give kerosene. You light it and it is just like a deep freezer. It is very inexpensive. She has started a shop and she is going to put the cooler in her shop. These coolers are imported from Dubai and they usually cost $75-100.

Other items that she will be selling are Irish potatoes, sweat potatoes, yams, passion fruits, pineapples, paw paws etc.

loans.use: Buy vegetables and a cooler to keep them fresh.

payments.comment:
This business has started very well by gaining good profit in their dairly sales.
They have payed loan money worth $50 towards their loan refund.
Moer about this business will come in the next journal.

This business was wise enough to increase their stock to pull the customers who were all over the community making Chrismas shopping.
This business got enough money to refund the loan money and also to increase the stock after the Chrismas sells.
They have put in a down payment of $100.
Read more about this business in the next Journal.
Thanks.

People lived in fear to do their normal activities as the government soldiers were deployed all over the villages all round Uganda.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick has nine children plus his wife. He started a small scale business of food kiosk.

Village Enterprise Fund donated 100 dollars to enable them boost their business in 2001.

Right now their hotel business is doing very well. After attending several training organised by VEF, he has decided to start another business along side the hotel. This is carpentry workshop. Patrick is a carpenter by training and has a great talent for making beautiful things out of wood. Local carpenters like Patrick make items that are in high demand such as chairs, table, doors, small stools, beds, and sometimes coffins. He uses muvule timber, which is the best timber in the whole of Africa!

He is capable of handling the loan money. Given a loan of 500 dollars, he plans to buy the following materials: more muvule trees for timber, a used power saw, already splited timbers etc.

loans.use: Buy a power saw, trees and lumber

payments.comment:
This bisiness has taken a step of refunding the loan money by putting in $50.
The business is doing very well for profits are realized in every sales through out the week.
More about this business will come in the next journal.

This business gained alot during Chrismas sells because of the very many working class people who came back to the nearby villages. Most of them rushed to this business to buy funitures and many other wooden gifts for their people.
For this reason, this business gained enough profit.
They have made a down payment of $100 for the loan refund.
Read more about this business in the next Journal.
Thanks.

There was a general complaint from all the businesses that the campaigns of the resent presidential election affected the businesses very much.
People lived in fear to do their normal activities as the government soldiers were deployed all over the villages all round Uganda.
The businesses are just picking up since the country has remain peaceful.
For this reason, this business has managed to make a payment of $30 for the loan refund.
The business opportunity is now high since all the people have gone back to their usual business.
Thanks alot for funding this business.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is married with six children. They live in a grass thatched and mud house. They also rent a space in Tororo town where they can do their business.

She started a humble business in the year 2000. In the year 2001, village Enterprise Fund (VEF) gave a donation of 100 dollars. This enabled her to expand her business to this day.

She has attended training for entrepreneurs conducted by VEF, which allowed her to learn how to develop this strategic business idea. There, she also was able to understand how to give good customer service and stock her shop with the items her customers need for daily living.

She is capable of handling the loan money very well as she has already proven success with her VEF grant.

Given a loan of 500 dollars, she plans to expand her business the more by increasing the stock. Retail shops in this area usually sell such basic household goods as soap, cooking fat, and sugar.

loans.use: Increasing stock in retail shop.

payments.comment:
This business has started in their loan use by registering good profits in their daily sales.
They have payed $50 towards the clearing of their loan money.
More about this business will come in the next journal.

This business was wise enough to increase their stock to pull the customers who were all over the community making Chrismas shopping.
This business got enough money to refund the loan money and also to increase the stock after the Chrismas sells.
They have put in a down payment of $100.
Read more about this business in the next Journal.
Thanks.

loans.name: Modesta

texts.en:
Modesta has done this business, Unity Grocery, for a very long time. She has managed to make this business succeed even while she is a married woman with eight children.

Modesta was given her first chance to be a great entrepreneur when she received a donation of 100 dollars from Village Enterprise Fund in the year 2000.

She has attended business training three times. All these trainings are organised by Village Enterprise Fund. At the trainings, she learned many valuable business skills and ideas.

She is capable of handling the loan money very well, and she has proven this with how she has run Unity Grocery up until this day.

300 Dollars may not sound like very much for a grocery store but Modesta plans to expand the products she offers her customers by buying a higher quality and greater amounts of grocery items like tomatoes, cabbages, onions, green vegetables of different varieties, Irish potatoes etc.

loans.use: Increasing stock and variety in grocery store, Unity Grocery

payments.comment:
This business has payed $50 towards the clearing of their loan money.
They have started very well by registering good profits in their sales.

loans.name: Yosia

texts.en:
Yosia is married with five children.

He runs his own bakery -- baking bread, scones, some pancakes. He takes them out and supplies most of the shops within Mulanda village. He also takes some to Tororo town by riding his own bicycle. He has a big container that can be tied onto the bicycles. Also, he hires several â€˜boda bodaâ€™ bicycles to take them Tororo. â€˜Boda Bodaâ€™ is East African for â€œborder to border.â€?

He has been doing this bakery for five years. VEF helped him start the business. He needs a loan so that he can do this business at a higher quality. He wants to include eggs, jam on his products. Given a loan of 500 dollars, he plans to expand his business greatly by buying the following items: - baking powder, wheat flour, cooking oil, sugars and huge baking pans.

loans.use: Buying supplies for the bakery

payments.comment:
This business has worked very hard to raise money for the growth of the business and repayment of the loan.
Chrismas time was a wonderful moment of time to this business because of high demand of their commodities in the community.
They have payed $50 as first installment to reduce their loan money.
More about this business will come in the next journal.
Please have time to read about this business in the Journal that will be coming soon.
Thanks alot for supporting this business with loan money to enable them come above poverty level.
Thanks.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is married with six children. Moses has been a fish monger for the last five years.

. He is going to do continue doing fish mongering. He wants the loan money to expand his business such that if he goes to the lake he can buy the fish right from the fishermen. Right now he is doing the business in a smaller way because he goes to Tororo to buy fish from other fish mongers. He wants to rent a truck with his fellow businessman and buy the fish directly from the fishermen -- and cutting out the middle men.

He was given a boost of 100 dollars by Village Enterprise Fund in the year 2000. He has done wonderful training that was organised by Village Enterprise Fund on business skills.

Given a loan of 500 dollars, he plans to expand his business by buying various sizes of fish right from the fishers at the lake shores of lake Victoria in Busia District.

loans.use: Rent a truck to go to the lake

This business has worked very hard to raise money for the growth of the business and repayment of the loan.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a widow with five children.

Fish mongering is a little bit expensive to start. She is planning to buy fish of various sizes in bulk from the lakeshores of Lake Victoria. Right now she is able to buy 1 huge basket that costs around $200 US. But now, after she has got the loan, she is planning to buy 5 huge baskets. This will cost her $600 US because she is buying in bulk.

When she buys this, it can take her 2-3 days to sell all 5 baskets. The fish is preserved and it cannot get spoiled. These are smoked, not fresh fish. She is going to be a wholeseller, meaning that she sells her fish to the middleman. After deducting transport and other costs, she can make up to around $60 US dollars per trip to the lake. In a week, she can go twice. In a month, she can make a profit of $180 US dollars.

loans.use: Buy 5 huge baskets of fish

This business has worked very hard to raise money for the growth of the business and repayment of the loan.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia Omollo is a widow with seven children in her family.

Village Enterprise Fund (VEF) donated 100 Dollar grant to her in the year 2001. She started with a small business of selling greens, tomatoes, onions and cooking oil. Her business continued well for a period of eight months as she realized some profits.

Now, she is going to do a used clothing business. She is going to buy clothes in big quantities and then she will sell to the local people in the Mulanda market. She goes to Kampala to buy the clothes, they are less expensive in Kampala. This trip is around 300 KM each way and she takes a bus. The bus ride charges 18,000 shilling for the round trip and 2,000 shillings for each bell. She intends to buy 4 on each trip. This means that the transportation costs her around $30 US in total.

After selling all 4 bells of clothes, the approximate profit is about $200 US dollars, so this is a very good business to be in right now in Uganda.

These clothes are in many varieties. Skirt and blouse, t-shirts from america. Such T-shirts are pure cotton with pictures of American things -- University of Minnesota, Florida, baseball and football teams. They come in many varieties.

She is capable to handle the loan and to pay it back promptly.

loans.use: Buy bells of used cloths

This business has worked very hard to raise money for the growth of the business and repayment of the loan.
Chrismas time was a wonderful moment of time to this business because of high demand of their commodities in the community.

loans.name: Eseza

texts.en:
Eseza is a widow with nine children.

She has sold in retail for quite 4 years. With a loan she is going to switch to wholesale. To do so, she will be hiring a truck to load produce and go to Tororo to get her stock. Wholesale can give her much more profit and it helps her get rid of her stock much faster. She is going to keep in her stock in large sacks. Each sack contains 100 KG of produce. She has a house where retailers will come to her to get produce.

She got grant money from Village Enterprise Fund worth 100 dollars in the year 2002. She has also completed business training organised by Village Enterprise Fund.

She will be focusing on the following items -- sorghum, maize, millet, simsim, groundnuts, dry cassava, sun flower, beans, peas, green grams etc.

loans.use: Rent truck, buy stock in tororo

payments.comment:
This business has worked very hard to raise money for the growth of the business and repayment of the loan.
Chrismas time was a wonderful moment of time to this business because of high demand of their commodities in the community.
They have payed $50 as first installment to reduce their loan money.
More about this business will come in the next journal.
Please have time to read about this business in the Journal that will be coming soon.
Thanks alot for supporting this business with loan money to enable them come above poverty level.
Thanks.

There was a general complaint from all the businesses that the campaigns of the resent presidential election affected the businesses very much.
People lived in fear to do their normal activities as the government soldiers were deployed all over the villages all round Uganda.
The businesses are just picking up since the country has remain peaceful.
For this reason, this business has managed to make a payment of $30 for the loan refund.
The business opportunity is now high since all the people have gone back to their usual business.
Thanks alot for funding this business.
Moses.

loans.name: Max

texts.en:
Max is married with seven children.

He started his business by buying only one female pig that eventually gave birth to several others. He now has a pig business that he runs out of his home with a small pig house behind his home

Village Enterprise Fund gave him a grant donation of $ 150 in 2002, and he has done well with his business and has even received training three times by VEF. This training taught him how to make a profit through discipline and negotiation.

Given a loan of $ 500, he plans to buy high breed pigs that can give him better profit. These high breed pigs are rare in the village and often villagers must go far distances to find them. Having them in the village will be a great draw. He also plans on feeding the pigs higher quality food so that he can sell their meat for more as well.

loans.use: Buy pigs

payments.comment:

loans.name: Lovisa

texts.en:
Lovisa is a widow with five children in her family.

In East Africa, "Hotel" is a restaurant. She started her small business by baking pan cakes, chapatti and mandazi in 2000; Village Enterprise Fund gave her a donation of 100 dollars.

Then, she continued with her same business in a largr scale. Later, she received training in business skills conducted by VEF. After knowing the method of choosing a profitable business, she decided to open a eating house in the local trading centre.

Her hotel is now doing progressing in her daily service to her customers. Given a loan of 500 dollars, she plans to buy new saucepans, cartularies, plates, improve on the diet, and improve on the hotel structure.

loans.use: Buy supplies

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith is a widow with three children.

She started her business through her meagre funds after getting business training organized by Village Enterprise Fund. Her business has picked up very much because of her quality work on the hair of her customers.

Given a loan of $500, she plans to buy electric hair drier, chemicals and hair food oil, hair clips, shampoo, hair dyers and an air fan.

loans.use: Buy Supplies

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is married with eight children.

He had training with Uganda Drug Authority before he started his business.

The second training he attended was on business skills and stock control organized by Village Enterprise Fund. He was given a donation of $150 by village Enterprise Fund in 2000. He has succeeded in giving medical services to the people of his community.

Given a loan of $500, he plans to increase his stock by buying more medicine that can cure common diseases in the community like: - malaria, fever, antibiotics, body ointments for scabies, ringworms, Candida etc, stomach dewormers, flu, cough, diarrhoea. These medications are hard to find in his village He is capable of handling the loan money and refund it without any problem. The loan term will be six months.

loans.use: Selling Medication for humans

payments.comment:
This business has worked very hard to raise money for the growth of the business and repayment of the loan.
Chrismas time was a wonderful moment of time to this business because of high demand of their commodities in the community.

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Fish mongering is a great business right now in Uganda and Kiva is supporting many in this business currently.

Peninah, like Eunice Okepa, plans to hire a truck to go to Lake Victoria and buy fish for herself there. This is much less expensive than buying fish in her rural village. This loan will enable her to travel this long distance so she can bring lower prices to her village.

Most fish mongers in the village get their fish from middlemen at much higher prices. This loan will enable her to take a step most don't have the opportunity to take -- cutting out the middleman. She will get the fish smoked, in bulk, so that she can continue selling for a number of days.

Peninah is a proven businesswoman. She received a grant in 2001 from VEF to start her small business. She has been faithful with this help, and now is ready to take it to the next level.

loans.use: Buy Fish from Lake Victoria

payments.comment:
This business has worked very hard to raise money for the growth of the business and repayment of the loan.
Chrismas time was a wonderful moment of time to this business because of high demand of their commodities in the community.
They have payed $50 as first installment to reduce their loan money.
More about this business will come in the next journal.
Please have time to read about this business in the Journal that will be coming soon.
Thanks alot for supporting this business with loan money to enable them come above poverty level.
Thanks.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is married with five children. He started goat rearing after he attended the training that was organized by Village Enterprise Fund.

Later, VEF gave him a donation of $100 grant money in the year 2001.

He has been doing good business in buying and selling of goats to other business people around Soroti town. He has started with lower quality goats and now he is ready to move on to the top breeds in larger sizes. These are very hard to get, and thus it is difficult to expand your business without the help of a loan.

Given a loan of $500, he plans to improve on his stock and also buy more improved goat breeds. This will fetch him enough money and profit that can help him in his family and refund of the loan.

loans.use: Buy goats

payments.comment:
This business has worked very hard to raise money for the growth of the business and repayment of the loan.
Chrismas time was a wonderful moment of time to this business because of high demand of their commodities in the community.

Thanks.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married with nine children.

She has been doing this very business for five years. She has experience in her business. She got a grant money worth 100 dollars from Village Enterprise Fund in the year 2001.

Margaret runs a small store outside of Tororo that deals in domestic and kitchen supplies. She has the only such store in the area and people walk up to an hour just to buy supplies from her store. She deals in both wholesale and retail.

A loan will help Margaret significantly upgrade her store. She is currently supporting her family with the store, but they are struggling to pay school fees and buy medicine.

Given a loan 500 dollars, she plans to expand her business by buying the essential commodities in large quantity -- sugar, salt, bread, cooking oil, washing soap, toilet soap, rice, baking powder, baking flour, matches etc.

loans.use: Buy stock for her shop.

payments.comment:
This business has worked very hard to raise money for the growth of the business and repayment of the loan.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
This description was written by Richard Mazengo, a staff member for Village Enterprise Fund in Tanzania. He is also a partner representative for Kiva.

The name of the business is Ipagala Curios Group.

Richard started the business with his group of associated and was funded by VEF, in 2002. Their business is buying, making traditional Items and selling to the general public. In their Curio Shop in Dodoma town, they sell Knives, Pens,Fiddle, Mortors or mill, Chairs,Spears, Shoes, Drums, Calabash,and earings.

Through their business they have been making enough profit and they are to pay school fees for their children and meet other family needs. School fees are one of the most important, and difficult to afford, expenses in Tanzania. The majority of children cannot attend school because the families cannot pay these fees.

If they get $ 500.00 they will improve their business by buying more stock to expand their Shop, and this will make more profit for them to pay the loan and other profit for their own use.

Richard M. understands that he is getting a loan and is more than able to pay it back. He is the most experienced man in his region in the business of curios.

loans.use: To buy more stock

loans.name: Mathayo

texts.en:
This description was written by Richard Mazengo, a staff member for Village Enterprise Fund in Tanzania. He is also a partner representative for Kiva.

The Imani group is composed of 5 people who have been running a small store in their village outside of Dodoma called Ipagala. Swahili is the main language in Tanzania, and Imani means "faith" in Swahili.

Dodoma is one of the largest towns in Tanzania which has recently been named the capital of the country. However, currently much of the Tz government still resides in Dar es Salaam near the coast.

Those in the villages surrounding Dodoma are very poor and have no means of transportation other than walking. For this reason, it is very important that shops open up inside the villages so that the villagers do not need to walk far to get supplies.

Mathayo with his group they have retail shop selling Sugar, soap,cookng oil, used clothes, rice pens and other items. The business is making profit which supporting their families paying school fees for their Children, medication, food and clothing.

If they can get the loan they will be able to get more profit for pay back the loan and more profit for their own family use.

loans.use: Purchase more stock

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
This description was written by Richard Mazengo, a staff member for Village Enterprise Fund in Tanzania. He is also a partner representative for Kiva.

Peter M. is married with three children. His business started 2001. He has been buying fish from Mtera, which is 130 km away and selling the fishes in Dodoma town. He has a small staff who sell fish with him.

There is a large demand for fish in Dodoma, but it is difficult to find them, for sellers must travel a a long distance to the lake or coast. Dodoma is a landlocked town. Most local sellers must purchase fish from a middle man.

The business started with grant of Tsh 80.000.00 and now the business has reached a value of Tsh 500,000.00, which is over ($400). This loan will be a huge boost for Peter to rapidly accelerate the business.

The main use of the profits from the business will be to send their children to school and meet other family needs. Altogether, this loan will help send 20 children to school.

loans.use: Purchase fish

loans.name: Meru

texts.en:
This description was written by Richard Mazengo, a staff member for Village Enterprise Fund in Tanzania. He is also a partner representative for Kiva.

Meru C. is married with six Children and two in school. The business started 2001 after receiving grant from VEF of Tsh. 80,000.00. Currently, the business value is Tsh. 400,000. Currently, one US dollar is worth 1,174.90 Tanzanian Shillings. Thus, the value of this business is now over $300 US. Maintaining cash in a business is important for future purchasing. A loan will highly accelerate the possibilities for this group. Meru has a small staff and it has been observed that they are a very successful team and that is why they now qualify for this loan from Kiva.

The used clothing business is very successful in Tanzania, as it is in all of East Africa. Many East Africans have found great use for used clothing from Europe and America. It is less expensive than African clothing and of pretty high quality. Thus, you can see many Tanzanias walking around wearing t-shirts displaying American brands, schools, regions, performers and sports teams. This is just a reality here.

The loan will expand the business by openning a small shop for selling more clothes also she will be able to go to Dar-es-salaam to buy stock for the business and the business. The ability to travel this far will set them apart here in Dodoma, for most locals do not have the opportunity to make such a long voyage for business. This will allow them to buy the clothes as they come straight into the country from foreign lands.

loans.use: To buy bells of used clothing

loans.name: Agatha

texts.en:
This description was written by Richard Mazengo, a staff member for Village Enterprise Fund in Tanzania. He is also a partner representative for Kiva.

Agatha is disabled lady funded by Village Enterprise Fund with her group. They have three sewing machines and their business is growing.

Even though foreign used clothes (mitumba) are very popular in Tanzania, there is still much demand for traditional African garments. Women, especially, dress in traditional clothes very often. The local tailors keep the African styles alive.

This business started with one sewing machine and now they have three more that they have bought from their profits. She is training others from out side the group on how to start their own tailoring business. The loan will help the business to grow and make more profit. Their business is already profitable and they can be able to pay the loan on time.

I hope you will accept their request.

loans.use: To buy material for the project -- fabric, sewing machine, and other needed materials.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy fertilizers, pesticides, more seedlings and a hand pump

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Improve stocks and sell mobile telephone time to villagers

payments.comment: I collected $40 equivallent in Kenya shiilings on 1st Feb 2006.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy cows, sheep and goats for slaughter

payments.comment: Colected Ksh equivallent to $40 from Tom on 1st Feb 2006

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
This description was written by Moses, who represents Village Enterprise Fund and Kiva in Uganda

Village Enterprise Fund (VEF) donated 100$ grant to her in the year 1998. She started with a small business of tomatoes selling and onions. Her business went on well for a period of one year and she was realizing good profits.

In 2000, VEF organized a business training course for all the beneficiaries. She happen to be lucky to be one of the participants in the training.

She was able to learn a lot in a housing profitable business, marketing, book keeping and business strategies. She then divided to change to another business of produce selling. Here she has got better market where by her business is doing well and it has enabled her to buy a lot of produce and feeding together with education of her Children.

The new produce is got from or bought at the rural markets deep in the rural communities. In most cases she buys directly from the farmers who bring their produce in small quantities and sell using cups or basins. These farmers are found in deep rural areas far a way from town. Most farmers grow produce like goundnuts, millet, beans and others in very small scale on individual home basis their are no farms.

Given a loan of US $500 She will be capable of doing so well in her business by expanding her stock and also to meet the high demand of produce in the area.

Being a wife with a vision for the family, I know she will be greatly be helped to develop her family.

loans.use: Increase Stock of Produce

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase Pigs

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
This description was written by Moses Onygano, who represents Kiva and Village Enterprise Fund in Uganda.

VEF donated 100$ grant to her in the year 1999. She started with a small business of clothes selling. Her business continued well for a period of six months, where she was realizing good profits. In 2002, VEF, organized a training for all the beneficiaries in Tororo District and she was one of the beneficiaries who attended the training.

Eunice sells in a crowded market in Tororo. She ventures from her village to this market every day. She displays the clothes both in and outside the her shop.

She learned how to choose a profitable business strategies. She then decided to widen her business by beginning to sell second hand shoes and creams together with clothes.

Here she got better market where by her profit became so high in her business. A loan will help her because it will allow her to buy in bulk at prices she could have never dreamed of before. Having this loan will allow her to buy from a larger wholeseller who can give a better rate. This will easily double her profit margins on clothes she sells.

Being a focused business woman, I know that she will be helped a lot with this loan for the increase of her business and family as well.

loans.use: Buy bells of used clothing

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
This description was written by Moses Onyango, a representative for Kiva and Village Enterprise Fund in Uganda.

She got a grant of $100 from Village Enterprise Fund. She started by buying chicken and selling them right away. Most people have known his business so a number of them came to her to buy chickens.

She can now buy and sell between 30-90 chicken in a day with a great profit. The market is very open for her since most Ugandans keep Chicken for raising money whenever, need arises for other basic needs, sickness, Journey etc.

She sells the chicken mostly to families who come to buy from this poultry and some times she takes to the market where she is able to meet customers of different categories from different places.

There are three (3) basic ways of preparing chicken in this region, it can be through deep frying it, boiling with soup, and roasting but basically there are only two common ways and that is boiling with soup and the other one is roasting.

Families keep their live chickens through free range poultry system where the chickens are left to move freely all over the compound without restriction. But some times they also cage them especially for modern poultry keepers.

She has attended business training and he is capable of handling the loan and paying back.

loans.use: Buy chickens in bulk

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
This description was written by Moses Onyango, a representative for Village Enterprise Fund and Kiva in Uganda.

He got a grant of 100$ US from VEF as a kick start. He started with selling produce. After attending training on business skills twice, he got wide knowledge on how to choose and manage his business effectively.

He then started running General Merchandise business of welding, tools, work clothes, shoes and bags. He sells supplies which are used by workers who do manual labor in the region. This is a very good area. His business picked up very much and he got enough profit to stock more merchandise.

He now sells a big merchandise in one of the main market in town. The market is a main market in town built where most people go to buy all their necessities of all kinds and his shop benefits from this large numbers of customers. This market is safe, has agate with a security man and has set operational hours like from 8:00 am up to 6:00 pm monday to sunday.

I expect him to do greater business to bring development in the lives of the poor people.

loans.use: Buy tools and other work supplies

loans.name: Steve

texts.en:
This description was written by Moses Onyango, a staff member for Kiva and Village Enterprise Fund in Uganda

He got a grant of 100$ US from Village Enterprise Fund (VEF). He started with selling of Oranges and Guavas.

After attending training on business skills twice, he got wider knowledge on how to choose and run his business effectively. He then shifted to Butchery including buying and slaughtering of cattle and selling meat in his butchery. His business picked up very much and he got enough profit and opened up many other Butchers.

Now, Steve O. buys animals from the rural markets where the poor farmers bring their animals for sale so as to meet other requirements in their families.

In the rural markets he buys this animals quiet cheaply depending on the size of the animal like it ranges from 180,000/= up to 280,000/= as a basic price.

The local Government has provided some especially designed slaughter areas and itâ€™s where almost all animals are slaughtered and then transported to different butcheries and this areas are made of cement and poles to ensure that the meat is clean.

His butchery has been build with bricks and has a log for cutting meet inside, where to hang the meat and a table where cut meat is placed with a weighing scale hanging at the window opening. Â

loans.use: Buying animals for slaughter

loans.name: David

texts.en:
This description was written by Moses Onyango, a staff member for Kiva and Village Enterprise Fund in Uganda

He got a grant of 100$ US from (VEF). He started in selling Bicycle spares. Now most people know his business shop. So a number of them come to buy bicycle spares in his business.

David O. travels to buy spare parts for bicycles in Kampala the capital city of Uganda where there are very many agencies where those international companies and local bicycle companies have their tocks of bicycles and their spares.

A majority of local people ride on this local types of bicycles like Jupiter bicycles made in Japan, Roadmaster king made in Uganda, there is also Hero and many others types of bicycles.

Some people operate bicycle taxis called Boda Bodas which is East African for Border to Border. The costs differ depending on the distance with in town itâ€™s called town service they change 300/= and any distance outside town like one kilometer itâ€™s 700/= -1,000/= the longer the distance the more money one pays.

He can now buy and sell bicycles and their spare parts at great amounts. The market for his business is open since most of the Ugandans, use bicycles as a major means of transport for their Journeys within and outside town.

Given a loan, he is targeting to introduce a large stock of new bicycles of various kinds which would be for the development of his business and the beneficiaries of this business.

loans.use: Buy Bicycles and Parts

loans.name: Pricila

texts.en:
This description was written by Moses Onyango, a staff member for Kiva and Village Enterprise Fund in Uganda

Pricila is a Japadhola by tribe and she comes from the North Eastern part of Tororo District in Eastern Uganda. She lives in the grass thatched house in the village.

She got a grant of 100$ US from VEF and she started by selling of fish right away after fishing. Most fish mongers got to know her. So a number of them could buy fish from her.

After attending training on business skills twice, she got wide knowledge on how to choose and run business effectively. She then shifted to buy fish as a fish monger.

Her business picked up very much and he got enough profits to buy large number of fish and selling it. She now moves from the fishing site to come and sell the fish in town in large quantities.

I expect her to do better business to bring development in the lives of our people who are beneficiaries of his business.

loans.use: Buy Fish

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
This description was written by Moses Onyango, a staff member for Kiva and VEF in Uganda

Joseph O. is a hardworking man who buys the goats from rural areas and keeps them at his home tied with ropes on their necks and takes them to graze by pegging their ropes on the ground so that they do not disturb the neighbors he takes them water in the middle of the day and then goes to bring them back in the evening and ties them a round his Varanda of his house on the pole or pegs.

Joseph started with goat keeping and selling of goats right away. Most Butchers have known his business. So a number of them come to him and buy the goats. He can buy and sell between 10 â€“ 15 goats with great profit.

He feeds them basically on grass, potatoes pealings. For us in especially Eastern Uganda, the grass is plenty and free so he feeds the goats on grass and potatoe pealings are seasonal. The goats normally spend only eight month and itâ€™s old and grown enough for other slaughter or sell.

The market is very open since most Ugandan rear goats and cows for raising money whenever, need arises like school fees and sickness.

Joseph has attended business training and he is capable of handling and paying the loan back.

loans.use: Buy goats

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
This description was written by Moses Onyango, a staff member for Kiva and Village Enterprise Fund in Uganda

In 2001 Village Enterprise Fund organized for a business training course for all the beneficiaries in Tororo District and she happened to be one of the participants who attended this training.

She learnt how to choose a profitable business, how to market it, book keeping and many business strategies. She then decided to change her business to opening a restaurant.

Here she got a lot of customers where by the profit her business were so good which enabled her to buy and cook a lot of food in her restaurant to meet the increasing number of customers.

When she just started she used to do the cooking, but now days she has four girls and one boy helping her in her restaurant to cook and serve the customers as she supervises.

The kind of restaurant Agnes is operating is not very large, but itâ€™s a restaurant that has all the dishes enjoyed by the people in the area prepared in the standard liked by the people or customers of her restaurant.

She prepares dishes like groundnuts pasted meat stew, fried chicken, roasted chicken, rice, posho, beans, greens and the local breadÂ  made of millet or sorghum.

She has a small sign post on the road side and now many people know her and call her doctor hunger.

Because of the good foods she cooks, the fair prices she offers, and the newly acquired name to her, every body knows her by name and have made known the restaurant in the whole area.

loans.use: Buying equipment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy Tailoring materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying firewood and paying labor to make bricks

payments.comment: part of the first instalment agreed quarterly.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase spare parts for telephones

payments.comment: On May 5, Mousa made a payment of $55 toward his $600 loan, which was funded by generous Kiva lenders like you. We say congratulations -- mabruk, in Arabic -- to Mousa on the occasion of his first repayment. We hope that Mousa, a telephone repairman, is on his way toward broadening the spectrum of repairs he offers and, in turn, increasing his family income. Thank you, Kiva lenders, for sponsoring Mousa Telephone!

Mousa has had some difficulty making the repayments on his loan because many of his clients, who are government employees, have not received their salaries in 6 months and are forced to pay Mousa with an IOU.  Mousa is fully committed to repaying his loan and is doing all he can to generate enough income to make the required payments.

With this payment, he has now repaid approximately 1/6 of the principle amount.

Sorry it has been so long since we posted a payment but the situation has been very rough in Gaza. Although business has been slow, we continue to do all we can to make sure we can repay the loan.

Hope you are well,

Bryan

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase wood and other raw materials

payments.comment: On April 20, Mohammad made a payment of $50 toward his $600 loan, which was funded by generous Kiva lenders like you. We say congratulations -- mabruk, in Arabic -- to Mohammad on the occasion of his first repayment. We hope that Mohammad, a carpenter, is on his way toward increasing the income of the family business. Thank you, Kiva lenders, for sponsoring Shanab's Carpentry!

Loan Update

Dear Lenders,

We are happy to report that despite the difficult conditions in the West Bank and Gaza, our client has been able to generate enough revenue to make his scheduled loan repayment.  As always, please feel free to contact us with any questions or comments.

Thank you again for your incredible support,

Bryan
Mohammad is happy that he was able to pay the fourth installment on his loan as scheduled despite the difficult conditions.

loans.name: Anonymous
