loans.name: Zara

texts.en:
This loan will be administered with the help of Peace Corps volunteers in Sliven, Bulgaria

Zara I. works in Sliven, Bulgaria. She has run her own tailoring shop in the center of the town for the past three years, and lives in a small village on the outskirts of town with her husband and two small children. She mends and makes simple clothes for people in the neighborhood. However, her primary sewing machine has become unreliable and she does not have the financial ability to purchase a new one.

With this loan, she plans to do two things. First, she will purchase a new sewing machine. Secondly, she will fix up the back of her store where people will be able to try on the clothes she alters or makes for them. The flexibility of the Kiva loan has special significance for Zara, given her familyâ€™s situation. Her husband, who has been unable to find outside employment, tends to the familyâ€™s garden, the produce of which will be sold in the summer of 2006. With a portion of the proceeds from the harvest, she plans to repay the majority of the loan principal, the remainder of which will be repaid in the early fall of 2006 out of the cash flow of her business.

loans.use: Capital expense (new sewing machine and renovations)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Inventory, locally made crafts

loans.name: Doudou

texts.en:
This is a group loan. This group of 33 will each receive $25 to plant their own share of crops. They will share the risk of the loan together with a representative being responsible for delivering the repayments. Since this is an agricultural loan, it will be repaid in its entirety at the end of the growing season rather than in installments.

Louly Ngogom is a village of about 500 inhabitants of the Serrer ethnic group, under the leadership of Doudou D., the resident local government counsel member. Located among majestic baobab trees about 20 miles inland from the beach resort area of Mbour, Louly Ngokom is a poor village that depends on its youth in the cities to send money and rice home in the hungry months of August and September. In the summer of 2004, villagers lacked capital to buy seeds to plant their main cash crop, peanuts. For the initial lending, 15 household heads were chosen by Doudou and a counsel of village elders to receive a loan of $25 each to purchase of seeds before the planting season. After the harvest, 99.5% reimbursed the loans with an interest rate of 6%. In 2005, with continuing donations through John Fay, GENSEN and the village counsel were able to increase the loan and the number of beneficiaries to 33 persons, 17 men and 16 women selected on a rotating basis.

In its goal of becoming a self-sufficient model village, Louly has in its favor a partnership with a new modern ecovillage group, introduced with the facilitation of the GENSEN NGO, SOS Environment. In fact, the ecovillage of Louly Ngokom consists of the existing traditional inhabitants plus this new group of about 20 incoming settlers, who already have started to employ local youth to grow organic bananas and produce and to construct modern ecological dwellings.

loans.use: 33 individual loans of $25 to purchase seeds for cash crop - peanuts

loans.name: Khadyjatou

texts.en:
This is a group loan where 20 people get $70 loans and share the risk. One entrepreneur, Khadyjatou N., will be responsible for representing the group and delivering the repayments.  Please note: the agreement with this group was that they would repay the entire loan at the end of the borrowing period rather than in installments.

In the photo Mme Khadyjatou N., Women's Group Treasurer, signs for the loan. The witnesses beside her are Boubacar Sarr, President of Ecovillage Carabane, Mbaye Thior, Administrative Officer and Urbain Diatta, environment Officer. Located in the mouth of the Casamance River, Carabane is an off-shore island village with 700 year-round inhabitants. As the entry point of French rule in the Casamance Region of Senegal, and a classic mangrove ecosystem, Carabane is a natural ecotourist destination. However, tourism alone, as currently practiced, is insufficient to provide all the needs of the villagers, who also fish, grow some millet and raise small pigs.

The beneficiaries of the loan are 20 members of the village women's group, who each received $70 in July 2005 and will reimburse their loans by the end of April, 2006. The group will use the funds for their small business, processing and marketing fish and other seafoods.

loans.use: Processing and marketing fish and other seafoods.

loans.name: Foutoumata

texts.en:
This is a group loan where a group of women will share the risk of the loan together. A representative, Fatoumata D., will deliver the repayment. Please note: The agreement with the Femmes de Nder group was that they would repay the entire Kiva loan at the end of the borrowing period (January 2007) rather than in installments.  This is because the group leader wishes to give each member the opportunity to borrow a small portion of the total loan amount for her own business activities, for a length of time that is less than the total nine-month term of the Kiva loan.  The individual will then repay the loan she has taken to the group fund, which will in turn lend it to another member.  Allowing the group to repay the entire loan at the end of the borrowing period in this way allows them to take turns borrowing, extending access to more members.

« Femmes de Nder » is the women's group of the 300 person village of Nder in the north of Senegal near the Mauritanian border, also known as the ancient capital of the Walo, one of the Kingdoms of the Wolof ethnic group, conquered by the French. GENSEN has approved this group's request for credit and has received $100 in donations to open their account.

Incorporated in 1994 as a Groupement d'Interet Economique or GIE, which is the smallest type of government recognized business, the group currently has 44 members. It first created, farmed and sold the produce from a communal field, using the profits to develop a small cash fund. By collecting dues of $0.20 per month from each member, the group began a rotating credit system, lending from $10 to $50 with 5% interest. They have continued this lending system, dropped the interest rate, and increased the membership dues to a dollar every 4 months. The total in the fund is about $1,200. The group has received and repaid a substantial loan from a federation of women's groups in their regional capital city of Saint Louis.

The group also owns large cooking utensils that it rents out to members of the village for parties and ceremonies, the profits of which go back into the fund. Either as a group or through small businesses of its members Femmes de Nder cultivates sweet potatoes, harvests and processes incenses that grows as bulbous roots of an indigenous grass, raises chickens, goats, and sheep; practices local crafts, engages in commerce between Mauritania and Senegal and operates small restaurants. Each year, the group also pays for 4 members to go on a religious pilgrimage to Tivaouane, the holy city of their Muslim religious brotherhood.

loans.use: $50 for 20 people to develop saleable foods and crafts

payments.comment: The Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance Fund (SEM) is pleased to announce The 'Femmes de Nder' have repaid their loan in full 5 months after the loan after was distributed. While the original agreement was for a 8 month term loan, the group has paid back the entire amount 3 months early. We look forward to providing more loans to groups in Nder in the near future! Thanks to all who have supported the 'Femmes de Nder'!

loans.name: Piedad Portillo

texts.en:
I am a baker who can do all kids of baking to meet the needs of my customers. Honduras has many delicious baked goods to try such as Rosquillas (corn and cheese donuts), tustacas (corn cookies with raw cane sugar), vanilla cookes and semitas (another cookie).

However, my specialty which I am well-known for, is cakes and sweets. My most popular product is birthday cakes, which are ordered by my clients a few days before the birthday party.

loans.name: Maira Yessenia

texts.en:
My restaurant is in a good location, and I have been serving people for many years. This business has enabled me to provide for my children, and I am grateful for the progress of my business.

Here is a recipe from Honduras:

Honduran Pollo Con Salsa (Chicken In Sauce)

3 1/2 lbs frying chicken, whole
1/4 cup cooking oil
1/8-1/2 teaspoon hot chili powder
1/4 cup ground sesame seeds
3 whole cloves
1 cinnamon stick
1 teaspoon brown sugar
1/4 teaspoon fenugreek seeds
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon pepper
2 cups boiling water
2 tomatoes, chopped
1 green pepper, chopped
1 onion, chopped


  1. Brown chicken in oil on all sides; remove from pot.
  2. Add chili powder, sesame seeds, cloves, cinnamon, brown sugar, fenugreek, and salt and pepper; brown in oil.
  3. Add remaining ingredients.
  4. Simmer until tender.
  5. Add chicken and cook until tender, turning occasionally.
  6. Add more water if necessary.

loans.use: Working capital

texts.en: I make all different kinds of Ã­tems for my clients.  I make clothes for children, women, and men, as well as sheets and curtains.  I both take orders for Ã­tems and also sell my goods door to door to shops that I have worked with for years.

loans.name: Graciela Gomez

texts.en:
I started my business just as a take-out restaurant for local catrachos*, but I have expanded to sell other packaged products that my customers want. I think my business is successful because my customers like how I treat them.

*A Honduran can be called a Catracho or Catracha. The comes from the last name of Honduran General Florencio Xatruch, who led Honduran armed forces in defense of Honduran territories in 1857 against an attempted invasion led by a North American named William Walker. The nickname is considered complimentary, not derogatory so when you come to Graciela's we will say `Hola catracho!

loans.use: Working capital

I sell clothes for children, ladies, and gentlemen. I walk door to door around the city to visit my regular clients. On the weekends, I travel to neighboring towns to sell.

If you go to Honduras, your eyes will see something that will catch your attention - a great variety of typical dresses. This variety is composed of eight typical dresses that change depending on the occasion. In Honduras, these dresses are used to demonstrate the traditional culture, costumes, and beliefs from each region, and they are identified by their typical dresses.

I have two busineses which are both working well.

My main business is selling cosmetics from a catalog. My clients would come to my house, select the cosmetics they wanted to purchase, and I would place the order. As my businesses were doing well I decided to open a little store for additional income. I have very loyal clients which has contributed to the success of my businesses.

texts.en: My clients order Ã­tems from me when they want something pretty for their house.  I make bedspreads, pillow cases, curtains, drapes, and other Ã­tems.  Recently, I have had success selling furniture coverings door to door to shops.   I have a lot of orders pending and I need to invest in materials.  Getting this loan will help me be able to buy the materials to help a whole new set of customers.  It is difficult to grow a business without a loan, and loans are hard to get.  Thank you for your help.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
I sell prepared food in the San Juan market. In the San Juan market, fruits and vegetables are in abundance watermelons and canteloupes are available as well as pineapple, strawberries, blackberries, and papaya. I sell prepared food which includes meat and many of these fruits and vegetables

My work plan is to start offering a greater variety of dishes to my customers. They have been asking me to expand my menu. I will use the loan to purchase in larger quantities many new ingredients.

loans.name: Concepcion Aguilar

Siguatepeque is a city of about 45,000 people. Located in the Central Highlands of Honduras, the climate is considerably more temperate than the coastal area and lower elevations.

loans.use: Buy inventory

loans.name: Blanca Lidia Suazo

texts.en:
I make my cheeses in my house with my family and then deliver them to my clients door to door in the towns of Siguatepeque and Comayagua. My main buyers are corner stores, groceries, and restaurants. I have been working in this business for 10 years.

The most popular kinds of Honduran cheese are fresh, white cheeses with names like `Queso Blanco`, `Panela`, `Queso Fresco`, `Queso Del Pais`, and `Queso Para Freir`. These cheeses are all made the same way and have the same eating and cooking characteristics. They have shelf-lives of less than one week and are usually wrapped in banana leaves when they are sold.

One very interesting thing about many styles of Honduran cheese is that they do not melt when they are heated - they soften!

I sell my new clothes door to door in the sorrounding communities where my clients live.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Golden Crown group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Joan she is 30 years old. Married with 4 children. She have not gone for any formal hairdressing training â€“ However, she have gained good experience in Sedona salon where she was employed for 2 years. From the commission she received she saved to start her own small salon.

In year 2002, she received a loan of US$143 from WEEC. She was able to rent a plot and put up a structure where she operates. She was also able to provide electricity in the room. She did weaving of the hair awaiting to by other equipments to enable her serve her customers.

After completing the loan she took US$286 and bought a Drier and Steamer. This has attracted more customers. She has also been able to employ one lady. Given a loan of US$575 she will be able to expand her business and serve all her customers under one roof.

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Golden Crown group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Patricia does her printing business in her residential house. This enables her to look after her two children and husband who is ill. Due to high demand she has an idea of starting a small workshop in the nearby trading centre.

In year 2002 she joined a women self help group where she got a loan of Usd 139 for a period of 6 months earned a profit of Usd 70 which she ploughed back to the business. She was given a 2nd loan of Usd 277 for a period of 10 months, purchased printing materials and earned a profit of Usd 208. She got a 3rd loan of Usd 139 for a period of 8 months, this was not enough for the business but due to her illing husband she feared that the business would go down.

Patriciaâ€™s business is doing well and she is able to repay loans extended to her and take care of her family when her husband has asthma attacks.

Given a loan of Usd 425 she will be able to expand her business and acquire a stall in the nearby trading centre.

loans.use: To purchase paints and T- shirts

payments.comment: Patricia has paid her 1st and 2nd installments for april and may.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Golden Crown group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

I started work at Princess Salon along church road. The work load was not very much. I had to get a more competitive salon so as to gain experience. I approached Joan and requested her to offer me a job. I knew her salon was doing well. I joined her in 2003.

In year 2004 she introduced me to WEEC programme. I got a lot of training on saving and credit. I save US$ 3 per month. I havereceived 2 loans (Usd 43 & 86). Since I did not have my own I funded my husband`s Mali Mali business. However, since now I am to join Joan as a partner in the salon business, I will use my loan in our plan to get more lines of salon products so as to attract more customers.

loans.use: Hair Dressing

payments.comment: Martha did not find any difficulty in repaying the 1st and 2nd instaallments.She is able to handle her clients very well having bought new machines.

loans.name: Astring Elkid Giron

texts.en:
I am the owner of my own beauty salon. I had always wanted to have my own salon, and 15 years ago I started working to one day succeed. Now, my salon is frequented by many people, most of whom are women that work on the local government offices and private businesses in the area. My shop is in a location in a central area where security is very good, a fact of great importante to my clients.

By listening to my clients, I discovered other products that they would buy from me, so now I sell handbags, wallets, hair clips, shampoos, lotions, cosmetics, skarfs, and shoes. It makes them very happy that I offer quality in the styles they like.

loans.use: Buy inventory such as genral accessors for woman such as bracelets, hair clips, earrings, as well as hair products in general.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Dina Arely Lagos

texts.en:
I studied to be a beautician and I always hoped to have my own salon. With great effort and deliberation, my husband and I invested our savings in our salon, but we did not have sufficient funds left to invest in products.

A year ago, we made our first loan for $500 which we used to buy product inventory such as shampoos, polishes and other products. Women come to us for hair styling, massages, and nails. With this second loan, I am buying inventory in hair and nail beauty-products. Thank you for your trust in me which has provided a sustainable business and some profits to improve my sonâ€™s education.

loans.use: Invest in inventory and materials such as make-up, polishes, hair-dryers, shampoos, coloring and other products.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Eli Oved Zepeda

texts.en: My line of business is selling shoes of all types, for women, men, and children.  I have a shop in the San Juan de Siguatepeque market.  My wife runs the shop.  We have been in business for three years. Right now, we need to invest in school shoes for children because we have begun the new school year and we have lots of clients asking for the shoes. Otherwise, our family also has a taxi that I drive.  With both of the businesses, both my wife and I provide for our family.

loans.use: Purchase inventory, particularly school shoes

loans.name: Ixel Cardenas

texts.en:
I started my business five years ago in my own house. Now, I have my own location a few blocks from home. I cook chicken, home-made jueces, tacos, enchiladas y other foods. I have many diners because my place is so clean and my tastful presentation of my dishes. I personally attend to all my customers.

I made my first loan a year ago, and now I making a second investment in a second chicken fryer because I now have many more clients. Before, I only opened on the weekends, but now I am open everyday from 11am to 10pm. I decided to work so much more because I was making good profits which I am using to put my children in a good school and I hope to enlarge our house.

loans.use: Buy a electric fryer.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Tirso Meza

texts.en:
Like two of my brothers, I have been owner of a bakery, it is a familiar tradition for more than 40 years and we have all fought very hard to maintain our businesses, in my case, with the new motor I will be able to increase my production and will fulfill the orders of my clients and I will not have problems to repay the loan because my incomes will increase.

Because all the materials that I use have increased their price, I will use part of the money to buy a great amount of products to obtain discounts and to reduce my costs.

loans.use: I will invest the money in the purchase of a new motor for the machine of my factory since the motor is too old and it is already giving problems.  I Also will invest part of the money to buy materials to make my bread.

payments.comment:
Thanks to this loan my business is growing up!!
This is my 2nd payment!!!

loans.name: Oscar Perez

texts.en:
The loan will allow me to manage my goal to turn my Grocery Shop into a basic grain distributor, that will give reputation to my Shop and I will be able to increase my profitsâ€?.

Due to my experience as the owner of this Grocery Shop, I consider that the key to success is that the clients prefer me because I have a good inventory, all the products that they need.

loans.use: I will invest in the purchase of basic products for the Nicaraguan feeding (Rice, beans, Oil, Salt, Sugar, tortillas, etc.) and in other products that are sold quickly like refreshments and snacks.

payments.comment: "My grocery store is bigger now, i have more products to offer"

loans.name: Elsy Mayreth Flores

texts.en:
My business is called MISTER HOT DOG, and we started by renting two carts together with my wife. After we started to generate some consistent income, we decided to take a loan to buy our own little cart. That is how we started to have our own business, and now we own three carts which are strategicially placed around the city where our customers always ask us for â€œcarne asadaâ€?, a dish which is our â€œplato tipicoâ€? in Honduras.

With our loan, we are going to upgrade the carts with grills to give our customers what they are asking for. In the future, we will offer other new dishes using the grills. Our major expense is our childrenâ€™s education.

loans.use: Upgrade of three hot dog carts with the addition of new grills to cook carne asada

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Ada Marina Castellan

texts.en: I have had a grocery for the past 5 years.  I sell everyday household Ã­tems like chicken, sugar, coffee, butter, ham, and the like.  My business is in a good location and my costumers like how I treat them.  My business sustains our family because my husband does not make enough meet the needs of the whole family, so together we are able to provide for ourselves.

loans.use: Invest in inventory of meats, canned foods, razors, chicken, butter, tiolet paper, beans, sugar, corn, and other Ã­tems.

payments.comment: Mis ventas aumentaron por la variedad de producto que surti, ahora necesito comprar mas inventario ya que para navidad las personas buscan bastantes ingredientes para preparar y acompañar sus cenas. Por lo que necesito capital fresco para surtir mi negocio. Gracias por el apoyo recibido.

loans.name: Marta Margarita

texts.en: My business is located near the main street of our town Danli, and I have been running it for three years.  My business has grown because of both regular local clients, but also people traveling into town from the country side.  The products that sell the best in my business are beverages, bread, medicine, and milk.

loans.use: Buy beverages, medicines, and other products.

loans.name: Jose Prudencio

texts.en:
I have had my grocery store for three years. We are open all week, and I sell the household Ã­tems used everyday like butter, bread, milk, eggs, and other tasty treats.

My business is widely-known for my kindness and my unforgetable smile! We open early and stay open late, so my whole family works in the store since together we are sending the children to school.

loans.use: Buy inventory like bread, ham, pens and paper, medicine, juices, and the like.

payments.comment: Mis ventas aumentaron por el producto nuevo que inclui en mi inventario, ahora necesito comprar para la temporada navideña, por eso pago el saldo y solicito un nuevo prestamo para volver a surtir mas mi negocio y vender en esta temporada.

loans.name: Suyapa Amparo Sosa

texts.en: My business is called â€œLinda Nenaâ€? and it is a family businesss.  We sell childrenâ€™s clothes and shoes, as well as flowers, sweets, and other Ã­tems. We have a very strategic location in the city of Tegucigalpa.  Now we do both retail and wholesale business.  Business is good and we need to invest to satisfy our clients.

loans.use: Purchase of inventory: school supplies, flowers, and sweets.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.en: My business is selling cheese, beans, and corn, which I have been doing for 3 years.  My business has grown and I now distribute product wholesale to groceries, small marketplaces, and to other wholesalers.  I also sell to many of the traditional bakers who make the well-known rosquillas and quesadillas here in the town of Danli.  Due to the quality of my product and my service, demand has risen and I need to invest in inventory.

loans.use: Buy inventory: cheese, rice, beans, corn.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en: My little market is one of the biggest and luckiest in my whole community.  I sell personal-care products and school supplies for children among other Ã­tems.  I have been in business for 13 years, and I have been able to grow my store little by little each time I sell a little more.  Since school is starting, I need to invest in inventory of school supplies like notebooks, pens, and other things.

loans.use: To invest in inventory such as toys for children, school supplies, snacks, and personal-care products.

payments.comment: Gracias por su apoyo, este fin de año las ventas han mejorado mucho por lo que necesito renovar el inventario.

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en: I have been in business for 4 years because my customers perfer the service I provide them and because I have in stock everything they need everyday like milk, sugar, coffee, bread, eggs, cheese, beverages, and many other things.  I am a single mother and I have to work successfully to provide for the needs and education of my son.

loans.use: Invest in inventory like cooking oil, bread, sweets, sardines, and corn flour.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: I have been making flour tortillas for three years, and I think of myself as a fighter who has been able to earn the patronage of good customers.  My clients are groceries, market stands, and local neighbors in my community.  I know that with the loan, I can increase sales and profits.  I have two children in school, so I am very motivated to succeed in my daily and weekly sales goals.

loans.use: Buy flour.

loans.name: Rafaela

texts.en: My name is Rafaela, and my business is called Central Supplies, which I have owned and run for 17 years.  I started out selling just ice cream, and then just a few other Ã­tems, slowly growing into this little market I now have.  I sell milk, bread, oil, chicken, cheese and ice cream, and other daily use items.  My business is located on the main street in the main market in the town of Danli, so there are many people that pass by.  They stop into my little market for the delicious treats I make, but then they stay to do their monthly shopping, so that is how I have build my business.

loans.use: Compra de pollo, queso, leche, pan, dulces, papel, espaguetis y otros (Buying chicken, cheese, milk, bread, sweets, paper, spaghetti and others.)

loans.name: Alba

texts.en: In our town, most people have very few economic resources, so they perfer to buy second-hand clothing.  My business is to sell second-hand clothing imported from the United Status.  I have been running this business for 8 years and I have regular customers.  Thanks to my business, I have been able to build my little house, and now my two children are in school.

loans.use: Buy inventory of two clothing loads.

payments.comment: Este año he logrado vender mi inventario mas rapido en comparacion a otros, tambien me ayudo el surtir la ropa y vender en temporadas. Ahora se acerca la navidad y las personas por tradicion compran ropa para usarla, algunas no tienen acceso a comprar ropa nueva por lo que buscan ropa de segunda y es una excelente oportunidad para mejorar las ventas, es por lo que busco capital fresco y poder invertir mas en mi negocio, gracias por su apoyo.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en: My business is located on the main comercial street in the town of Danli, a well-traveled street which allows me to have good monthly sales most months.  The constant traffic is from the near-by bus station where peope are always coming and going, often passing by my shop.  I am married with a two year old daughter, and with my income from the business I can provide good nourishment and medical care for my family.

loans.use: Invest in inventory of pants, shirts, and shoes.

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en: My business is informal because I do not have my own store, but I do pay my taxes to the town, so I am able to keep my informal spot near the general market in Danli.  I sell cosmetics, chains, flowers, gifts, and other Ã­tems.  I also go directly to Tabacco Companies where most of the employees are women and would be interested in my products.  My wife and I run this business together, together we staff the booth, do the administrative details, and make decisions about what products we will invest in.

loans.use: Invest in inventory of cosmetics, cloths and hand bags.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members must make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Sarah is married with 6 children and she is the bread winner. Her last born is disabled and attends special school which is expensive.

She started her business with USD 7.and has since expanded it by ploughing back part of her income. She has attended various business trainings offered by WEEC and this has enabled her to manage her small business.

loans.use: Given a loan of USD 150 She will be able to include other varieties of vegetables. This will attract more clients to her business and hence increase her income.

payments.comment: Sarah is confortable having stocked a variety of vegetables. This has helped her in raising her income.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Margaret is a single lady with two children. She has educated them up to secondary school. Though they have not gotten formal jobs. She has assisted them get into the Jua Kali (informal) sector where they work as Mechanics.

Margaret has been in the Jua Kali sector for the last 15 years. Her experience has made her to be very keen in studying the market trends. She therefore engages in goods that are on high demand. Currently she is engaged in selling Pishori rice. She takes her orders from retail shops, households, festivities like weddings. She joined WEEC programme in 2005. She got a loan of USD 139 and bought more stock. She paid her loan in 10 months.

loans.use: Given a loan of USD 300 she will be able to add to her stock. This will enable her supply the Pishori rice to the adjacent Langata area where she has started getting orders from.

payments.comment: Margaret paid her 1st and 2nd installment on time. She has established other outlets which helps her in selling her rice.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members must make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Sarah has been involved in community Work both in her local church as a Sunday school teacher and also at village level as a youth counselor. This has enabled her to know many parents in the area.

Her business idea stemmed from the plight of many working parents who have had problems getting house girls who are honest. She therefore decided to start a day care centre. She Charges USD 7 per child per month. The income she gets from her work is enough to pay the room she has rented and also cater for the household expenses. In 2004 She took a loan of USD 139 that enabled her to go for a nursery school course. The course was to prepare her for her new business. In year 2005 She took another loan of USD 139 that enabled her set her business.

loans.use: Given a loan of USD 150 she will be able to pay school fees for her daughter and limit withdrawals from her business. This will enable the business to grow and be self sustainable.

loans.name: Loyce Waithera

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Loyce is a widow with 3 children and 5 dependants. She is a trained nursery school teacher. Through her training she has learnt to be disciplined and committed to her work. She is involved in church activities as a deacon and also the Chairlady of the womenâ€™s guild in the church.

Her preference of real estate (rental rooms) is because it does not take a lot of her time. She started her small project of 6 semi permanent rooms. From her rental income and loans she was able to put up 12 permanent rooms. She does not use her loans in any other way other than in her said project. To date she has 78 rental rooms. Her business has enabled her to bring up her family and also pay school fees for the five children who had previously dropped out of school for lack of school fees.

loans.use: If a loan of USD 700 is granted, she will put up 3 more permanent rooms since there is high demand of rental houses in Ongata Rongai.

payments.comment: This payment covers april and may.
Sarah has paid USD30 so far.

loans.name: Naomi Nungari

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Virtuous Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members must make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Naomi is a single mother with 5 children and 2 dependants. Naomi is an active member in the community. She is the Coordinator of the umoja road village. She is a leader of the Nambala Women group that has a project of grinding mill.

By joining the women groups in Ongata Rongai Naomi was able to attend short business skills courses. She has experience in different businesses from which she was able to raise capital buy a plot and developed it with rental houses due to high demand. She has 6 semi permanent houses and two are due for completion. She took a loan from WEEC of USD 139 in 2005 and laid the foundation of the two rooms.

loans.use: Given a loan of USD 300 she will be able to complete the two rooms and install electricity to make them more marketable.

payments.comment: Naome paid USD60, USD30 was paid in april and the other 30 in may.

loans.name: Jacinta Ruguru

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Kadisi Wisdom Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Jacinta is 43 years old, married with 4 children. She is involved in community work where she takes care of destitute children in the locality by giving free education in her private school.

Jacinta is a dairy farmer in Ongata Rongai. Currently, she has one dairy cow which earns her USD. 100 per month. This has been a reduction due to the prolonged dry season in that area. Under normal climatic conditions, she is able to raise 3 dairy cows and these can give her USD.456 per month. This enables her to take care of her family.

loans.use: She would like to buy another cow and a water tank to store enough water for her cows for such a season.

payments.comment: Jacint has paid USD60 for the month of april and may. She paid her first installment on 2/05/06.
Jacinta has paid USD60 for the month of april and may. She paid her first installment on 2/05/06.

loans.name: Oscar Geovanny Irã­A

texts.en: Iâ€™m an itinerant bread salesman.  Twice a week I go to Tegucigalpa and buy my bread supply for the week directly from the bakeries.  Upon returning to my community I travel in my car throughout my neighbouring villages selling the bread. Iâ€™ve had my business for three years and in this time my clientele has increased significantly, particularly with small grocers. At the moment I do not have enough capital to cover the demand that I have.

loans.use: Restocking his store with the most popular types of bread.

loans.name: Rigoberto

texts.en: Iâ€™ve been selling medicines itinerantly in neighbouring communities for the past year.   This business generates earnings that I use to provide for my family. I also sell low quality wood that I buy from sawmills. This wood is used as a substitute for electricity by the people the in my residence.

loans.use: Sale of various popular pharmaceuticals

loans.name: Blanca Nieves Arguet

texts.en: My family and I serve food for a living.  I have a diner where I serve traditional food.  Throughout time I have attracted many clients to my establishment.   Many people visit my business each day because it is located in front of a bus terminal. At this moment the demand for food is very high that is why I need larger credits to cover the costs of serving more clients.

loans.use: Buying rice, lard, beans and dairy products.

payments.comment: Gracias a los fondos recibidos pude mejorar mis servicios en comidas, tengo mayor clientela y mis ingresos han mejorado es por lo que puedo cancelar el saldo pendiente. Ahora necesito comprar inventario para preparar comidas navideñas para vender y entregar en algunos lugares y personas particulares. Gracias por su apoyo.

loans.name: Josã© Arnulfo Gonzã¡

texts.en: I provide transportation for people travelling from the city of El Paraiso to Las Manos in the border between Nicaragua and Honduras.  Iâ€™ve been doing this for the past seven years.  I make the journey on a daily basis, so I need to take my van to the mechanic for a check up and restore the seats in order to improve the security and comfort of my passengers.

loans.use: Repair vehicle.

payments.comment: Gracias a la ayuda recibida, pude arreglar mi unidad, ahora estoy brindando un servicio mas comodo y necesito hacerle a mi unidad unos nuevos cambios de piezas, por la temporada alta del transporte puedo pagar el saldo y requerir de nuevos fondos para hacerle a mi unidad un chequeo general de mantenimiento. Gracias.

loans.name: Santos Ernesto Mendo

texts.en: Iâ€™ve had my business for the past 5 years, I take photos in special events, frame photos and diplomas, sell film and cameras as well as well as car batteries.  My business has grown parallel with my improved experience and my knowledge of camera repairs. I also fix cameras but only on few occasions. I only have basic repair equipment and would need greater financing in order to improve my shop and my services.

loans.use: Buying films, batteries and glass for the studio

payments.comment: Los meses de noviembre y diciembre son buenisimos ya que hay bastantes graduaciones y bodas, por lo que necesito comprar material para tomar mis fotografias y otros. Gracias a la calidad de mis fotos puedo pagar el saldo y pedir ayuda fresca para equipar mi foto estudio para esta temporada.

loans.name: Alba Rosa

texts.en: For the past 4 years Iâ€™ve dedicated myself to the sale of clothing and shoes for children, women and men. I sell my products to various offices in this city.  I already have a set clientele and I get paid every 15 days or upon delivery. I also sell from my residence with the help of my kids.  This business generates some earnings that allow me to better provide for my household.

loans.use: Buying shoes, blouses for women and girls, sock, menâ€™s undergarments amongst others.

loans.name: Santos Cornelia Casc

texts.en: My name is Santos Casco and I make and sell delicious nacatamelas, one of our typical foods.  In the last months my business has grown since I have received many more orders.  My business clients say that the flavour of my nacatamales is unique which is made better by my kind, charming customer service.  I also sell my nacatamales to my neighbours.

loans.use: Buying corn, banana leafs, raisins, potatoes, lard, string and condiments

loans.name: Ramona Suyapa Zeron

texts.en: I bake and sell bread (rosquillas and quesadillas) and receive orders from my clients, housewives or owners of small grocery shops. I have done this for the past three years and with the help of one of my sons Iâ€™ve managed to grow significantly.  My demand is now so large that I need to buy more ingredients.

loans.use: Buying flower, lard, condiments and firewood.

loans.name: Dirminda Sorto

texts.en: My name is Dirminda Sorto, I am the owner of a mill that grinds corn for household production and consumption of tortillas. Iâ€™ve had my mill for the past 13 years, and since itâ€™s the only mill in my community I have a lot of clients, therefore it has deteriorated.  The mill is one of the primary income sources of my family. I would like a credit in order to buy an electric mill and be able to continue with my business. Also, during school session, I sell candy to the students in my community and at the entrance of the school.

loans.use: Buying an electric mill

loans.name: Rosa Idalia Del Carm

texts.en: I am the owner of a small grocery shop that sells basic staples and other popular products such as milk, bread, lard, soda, candies amongst others. Iâ€™ve had my business for the past two years and itâ€™s the only shop in my community. Because of this I have a high demand and I need to restock with products that will be easily sold. I use the earnings from my store in order to keep my children in primary and secondary school.

loans.use: Buying lard, soap, candies, cookies, soda, bread and gum

loans.name: Luis Alonso

texts.en: I am the owner of a carpentry shop that builds beds, doors, wardrobes, dinning tables, chairs amongst others. I have lots of clients and most of my work is done by order.  I get paid 50% when we sign the contract and 50% when I hand them the final product, which makes it harder for me to sell furniture to other clients. This area has lots of demand for the elaboration of furniture and wood therefore I decided to work with PRISMA.

loans.use: Buying wood, nails, glue, varnish amongst others

loans.name: Suami Dolores

texts.en: Iâ€™ve had my shop for the past seven years. Iâ€™ve managed to administer it and increase my number of clients.  It is my only source of income so I take care of my sales. I am a single mother of two. One of my sons is in school and the other is two years old. I think if I invest more capital in restocking my store Iâ€™ll get more earnings

loans.use: Buying bread, candy, corn flakes, milk, spaghetti, sauce, salt, corn flour, medicines, etc.

loans.name: Angelina Lopez

texts.en: My name is Angelina LÃ³pez and I sell accessories for sewing;  I also tailor clothing for women.  Iâ€™ve been tailoring for the past fifteen years and selling the accessories for the past two. I need the credit in order to buy the necessary cloth to make school uniforms.

loans.use: Buying cloth, zippers, buttons and lace

loans.name: Norma Leticia Gonzal

texts.en: I've had my business for two years.  Before my salon I worked for a private company and when I retired I invested the money in my own business. At the moment Iâ€™m working towards getting more clients and in order to do so I need to get good quality products to satisfy them.  The earnings of the salon help me with my family.

loans.use: Buying dyes, nail treatments, nail polish and a hair drier

loans.name: Iris Azucena

texts.en: Both my husband and myself run the business.  We both keep the store that generates income that covers the expenses of my family. My business is one of the largest in my community and once in a while visitors ask me to cook for them, which provides some extra earnings.

loans.use: Buying fruits, vegetables, sugar, soda amongst others.

loans.name: Pastor David Suarez

texts.en: I sell popular medicines for headache, diarrhea, fleas, stomach aches amongst others.  I sell my product in neighbouring communities. My wife and my two sons sell the medicine from my house. Iâ€™ve had this business for the past two years.  My wife also sells products from catalogues. The main source of income in my household is the medicines.

loans.use: Buying Panadol (aka Tylenol), Vicks cough drops, Mentolina, Ibuprodol, Alicol, Sal Andrew, Alcohol, amongst others.

loans.name: Nolvia

texts.en: For the past 5 years Iâ€™ve had my store. I have a lot of clients because of the great diversity of products that I offer.  Iâ€™m located at the exit of the city and because of this I get a lot of business from the people travelling to the surrounding villages.  They buy their weekly provisions in my store. One way in which Iâ€™ve increased my sales is by allowing customers to pay every 15 days rather than on a weekly basis.

loans.use: Buying sodas, common medicine, sugar, lard, soap, oil, bread, broth amongst others.

loans.name: Alfredo Hernandez

texts.en: I own two car that I use as a taxis to provide tranportation in the city of Danily.  I work from 6:00 am â€“ 7:30 pm therefore I have to give maintenance to both my cars. I need to keep using at least one in order to retian my daily earnings.  I also need to change  the tires in the other.  In my family we are four, two kids, my wife and myself.  I mainly use the income for our everyday life.

loans.use: Maintenance of the taxi

loans.name: Maria Felix Sosa

texts.en: I sell clothing and shoes for children, men and women.  My business is in  one of the main streets of Danili.  Iâ€™ve had my stand for the past two years and my sales are good given that my main clients are people from other communities that visit Danili.

loans.use: Buying hair ties, shirts, t-shirts, blouses, pants, skirts, clothing for babies, and undergarments for men and women

payments.comment: Toda la ropa que tenia en existencia la he vendido en este fin de año, por lo que necesito comprar y renovar el inventario de mi tienda, gracias a su apoyo he logrado mejorar mis ingresos.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a barber's chair, scissors, and other equipment

payments.comment: On April 20, Rami made a payment of $50 toward his $500 loan, which was funded by generous Kiva lenders like you. We say congratulations -- mabruk, in Arabic -- to Rami on the occasion of his first repayment. We hope that Rami's work has been facilitated by purchasing additional equipment for his barber shop and that his income, which supports his five-member family, has increased as a result. Thank you, Kiva lenders, for sponsoring Rami's Barber Shop!

Loan Update

Dear Lenders,

We are happy to report that despite the difficult conditions in the West Bank and Gaza, our client has been able to generate enough revenue to make his scheduled loan repayment.  As always, please feel free to contact us with any questions or comments.

Thank you again for your incredible support,

Bryan

Despite the extremely challenging environment, Rami was able to make a repayment of $45 on his loan.  He thanks you for your help during this difficult time.

Please feel free to contact me with questions or comments,

Bryan
After another difficult month, Rami was able to repay his loan.  The situation continues to remain extremely bleak.
Rami wishes all his supporters a very happy holidays!

Hello Lender,

We are really happy to announce that we have received another repayment from our borrower.  We also have some good news from Basil, who states:

"I hope that in the few coming months the situation will be better and all borrowers will pay monthly.  The situation in Gaza is calm and there has been no fighting since the Maca agreement."

Glad that we could share some good news with you.

Hope you are well,

Bryan and the Shurush Team

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To Purchase Cloth

payments.comment: On April 20, Adham made a payment of $50 toward his $600 loan, which was funded by generous Kiva lenders like you. We say congratulations -- mabruk, in Arabic -- to Adham on the occasion of his first repayment. We hope that Adham, a traveling salesman, is on his way toward increasing his sales in Gaza and, in turn, increasing his family income. Thank you, Kiva lenders, for sponsoring Adham Sales!
