Dear Lenders,

We are happy to report that despite the difficult conditions in the West Bank and Gaza, our client has been able to generate enough revenue to make his scheduled loan repayment.  As always, please feel free to contact us with any questions or comments.

Thank you again for your incredible support,

Bryan
Adham is happy that he was able to pay the fourth installment on his loan as scheduled despite the difficult conditions.
Adham's repayment in the amount of $45 for the month of September was recently repaid.

loans.name: Lucy Njeri

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Melody Mothers group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Lucy is a widow with one dependant. Despite being a widow she is very active.

Lucy grows and sells vegetables and poultry farming on a small plot. She started her farming business with a loan of USD 280. She sells her vegetable products to the neighbors and the nearby markets. Due to the prolonged dry spells, the demand for her products has increased since she is among the few using irrigation method of farming.

For poultry, she gets orders from hotels in Nairobi though due to lack of enough capital she is not able to meet the demand from her clients.

loans.use:
Given a loan of USD 700, she will be able to buy a water pump to facilitate her vegetable farming and meet the high demand.
She will  be able to add more poultry stock and meet the demand from her clients and get new customers.

payments.comment: She had not experienced any problem so far.Her 1st and 2nd installments were paid promptly.

loans.name: Mary Nduta

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Melody Mothers group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Mary Kunyua is married with 3 dependants. She is involved in community work and takes care of the orphans in her locality.

Mary sales fresh milk from her own cows and also buys from farmers in the same area. She distributes it to hotels in Nairobi. The income from her business is basically used in expansion of her business and feeding the orphans. Lack of a permanent stall for her business has been a major challenge since new customers canâ€™t locate her.

loans.use: She intends to open up a milk collecting centre after being given a loan of USD 1000. This will enable her buy a freezer for her milk to serve customers better.

payments.comment: Mary paid her 1st and 2nd instalment on time and she is committed to her business.She pays USD83 per month.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is single and an active member of Kandisi Wisdom Women Group. She has been a member of Women Fighting Aids in Kenya (WOFAK) since 2003.She trains the youth in HIV/AIDS related matter to minimize the spread of this scourge.

She has a small retail shop where he sells phone accessories, and operates a payphone. As a trainer with WOFAK, she is given an allowance of USD.4 per day 3 days a week. Late last year, she had her business in Nairobi unfortunately; thieves broke into her shop and cleaned it.

loans.use: The loan applied for will be used for re-stocking the shop to catch up with the demand in the area.

payments.comment: Elizabeth like other group members paid very well her loan and she paid USD.42.

loans.name: Ruth Muthoni

texts.en:
Ruth is the Chairlady of Kandisi Wisdom Womenâ€™s Group. She is married with 4 children.

She is in the business of screen printing with the husband. They have been able to buy a plot of land on which their permanent house is and can afford to send their children to school. Currently, her business is housed in her residence and intends to rent a shop in the town centre to increase her clientele.

loans.use: The loan applied for of USD 300 will be used to buy more materials thus increase capacity to supply all orders received. This will increase her income and improve her standard of living.

payments.comment: Ruth being the chairperson of this group, wants to be the example by paying well her loan. she paid USD60 in the month of april and may.

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en:
Teresia is married with 6 dependants. She is a very active lady and a treasurer of Ole Roimen Women Group.

Teresia is the sole supplier of Furniture in her locality. She gets orders from the schools and residents since she does quality work. Though she is not able to meet the demand of her clients on time due to limited capital and lack of wood curving machine. In addition to the furniture business, she sells vegetables and milk from her zero grazed cows. Her income from farming is steady throughout the year.

loans.use: Given the loan of USD.1100 She will purchase a wood curving machine and increase the stock of timbers.

payments.comment: Teresia has paid USD.183 and she is currently saving USD14 per month to atleast be self sustainable in a few years to come.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly is married with 5 dependants. She takes care of the whole family, the husband has a poor paying job.

Nelly sells used clothes and her stock is USD 100.She does not have a permanent stall as it is expensive to own one for the time being. Her business is not enough to cater for her family basic needs and education.

loans.use: As a result of increased clientele, she is to increase her stock and rent a stall for her business. Given a loan of USD.300 she will be in position of increasing her stock and serve her clients well. This will improve her sales as well as her income.

payments.comment: This payment is for the month fo april and may. She hopes business will remain as it is today to anable her pay on time.

loans.name: Marcos

texts.en: Marcos is a single father who owns a small store that sells chickens and other meats. He averages about 16 hours of work a day and depends on his family to take care of his daughter. With the money received from the loan Marcos plans to increase his inventory so that he can diversify his products and buy in bulk at lower prices. He plans to use the increased income to provide better health care, education and clothing for his daughter.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Walter

texts.en: Walter is originally from ManabÃ­ but has lived in Guayaquil for 15 years. He owns a small store where he sells groceries and other food items. He learned the business from his parents who provide some support for him but cannot give him credit. His wife also helps out at the store, but in order to grow he needs a source of capital other than the loan sharks. With the credit he plans to increase and diversify his inventory. Currently his profits average about two dollars a day.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Melecio

texts.en: Don Melecio is a tailor who produces menâ€™s suits and other clothing. He has 6 children who he cares for all by himself because of a wife that abandoned the family. His dream is to support his children so that they may receive a college education that will help them make a better life from themselves. Although he has over 25 years of experience the lack of capital does not allow him to produce at higher quantities. He is terrified of the loan sharks but is confident he can handle the loans.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Luz

texts.en: Luz owns a store that sells school, office and party supplies. She is a single mother of one child who is currently still in school. She mainly sells notebooks, pens and party items for children and adults. The loans will help Luz purchase increased volume of products in times when demand is high such as carnival, Christmas and other holidays. She has over 25 years of experience in this business.

loans.use: Increase inventory in time for Carnival

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en: Vicente owns a shop in his house where he sells shoes and other sports equipments. He and his wife manage the store while taking care of their only son. He is in need of capital in order to be able to access better and more attractive styles for his client base. He will use the capital to try out different vendors of apparel and purchase products at higher quantities.

loans.use: increase inventory

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en: Rogelio owns his business on the outskirts of Guayaquil, but his neighborhood has many people that are potential clients. He has 3 children and a wife who helps out in their store whenever necessary. Rogelio has 5 years of experience in the business but needs capital in order to buy from wholesalers at cheaper prices. He also states that he will use new capital to invest in products that are in high demand at his store but he cannot currently afford. Rogelio says loan sharks charge above 20% interest and he cannot afford to repay those loans.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Isaias

texts.en: IsaÃ­as owns a store where he sells items of first necessity such as food and hygienic products. He is 46 years old and has 4 children. His business is well placed in a corner and is accredited by the government but IsaÃ­as does not have access to credit. With increased capital he plans to add variety and volume to his inventory in order to increase sales and profits. He also seeks to add an employee who may be able to help him in his sotre. He wants to use the money he makesto provide a better education for his four children.

loans.use: Increase inventory and add stock variety

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en: Francisco is 48 years old and owns a shop for veterinary and agricultural products. He provides foods and medicines for domestic and farm animals in the neighborhood. He has over 25 years of experience in this business and is seeking loans in order to acquire better quality and higher quantity of products so that he may serve his clients better. He comments that the only access to credit he has charges 10% to 20% monthly interest and is way beyond what he can afford. He hope he can use profits made from his business in order to provide a better living for his two children who he cares for by himself.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en: Carmen has lived in Guayaquil for over twenty years where she owns a small grocery store. She is a widow with three children that she cares for by herself. She lives in a remote area of Guayaquil but she knows her business well as she has over 13 years of experience. With the loan she will be able to purchase products in bulk and lower costs.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha owns a small stand that sells chickens to the public. She learned the business from her parents and has been in this line of work for over 15 years. Although she earns money from this business and her husband has a humble but stable salary they are often short of money and do not have enough to invest in her business. With the loan money Martha plans to invest in more products and better tools. Currently she begins work at 6 a.m. and usually dedicates 16 hours a day to her business.

loans.use: Invest in tools

loans.name: Julian

texts.en: My business consists of the reparation of parts for agricultural vehicles and machinery, lathes and everything related to lathes. I have 8 years of experience and regular clients that supply parts from various shops in the community and from surrounding communities. I need this loan to complete the purchase of a lathe machine now that I enough have jobs and with a single machine it is difficult to complete all the orders quickly. The parts will also be useful for increasing sales.

loans.use: Buy a lathe machine

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en: For 5 years my business has sold clothing and shoes for women, men and children, distributing the merchandise door-to-door among my neighbors and friends that prefer to do business with me at the moment because I offer them affordable prices with methods of payment. I also have clients who are teachers and factory workers and I visit some villages around Danli. Maintaining good clients and administration has generated a good income for me, but I need the loan to improve my business and cover the costs of labor.

loans.use: Purchase of a larger assortment of clothes for women, men and children as well as school and dress shoes.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: My business sells electronics such as: TVs, irons, video recorders, microwaves, etc. I use the money to help pay for the education of my family and to improve the conditions of the business so that there is always an assortment of products. My business relies/benefits from a good location and regular clients that come to me for their purchases. I need the loan to offer more products that are requested by clients.

loans.use: To buy TVs, stereo equiptment, blenders and toasters.

loans.name: Maria Orfilia Salgad

texts.en: I have had my business for 12 years, maintaining good clientele and management. My best clients are students, lawyers and some offices. The money I have made through my business has helped me to improve the business and cover family expenses.

loans.use: To buy toner, paper, staples, folders, clips, pencils, etc.

loans.name: Karla Patricia Aguil

texts.en: My name is Karla Aguilar and I have a business selling clothing, shoes, and cosmetics door-to-door and by request for 5 years. I visit government offices, private companies, my largest buyers being teachers in urban and rural schools and employees of different institutions. I am requesting this loan in order to buy school clothes to increase my sales. With this money I can pay family and educational expenses.

loans.use: To buy shirts, blouses, shoes, socks, etc

loans.name: Deysi Araceli Rivera

texts.en: For 4 years my business has sold paper and office supplies. I decided to become independent and run my own business in order to cover family expenses. I have a good location and the preference of clients who can find a complete assortment of paper and supplies. For this school year I want to sell more school supplies and for this I need the loan to provide a complete assortment.

loans.use: To buy notebooks, pencils, markers, printer ink, printer paper and posterboard.

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en: I have had my business for 10 years and I am dedicated to repairing electronics Duch as TVs, stoves, DVD players, toasters, and others. I have good clients that provide me with work. Currently I have 2 helpers in my shop. The gains are considerable as they help me to have my business and maintain my home.

loans.use: To buy tools and materials.

payments.comment: Gracias a la ayuda que me brindo pude hacer que mi negocio creciera, estoy cancelando antes de tiempo el saldo porque necesito comprar otro equipo. Nuevamente gracias por su ayuda.

loans.name: Rita Maria

texts.en: I have been selling assorted second-hand clothing for 17 years. In this area there are many similar businesses but the important thing is to have a greater variety of clothing than the competition and that it be of higher quality. Thanks to the profits from my business I can look after the health and education of my children.

loans.use: To buy 2 bundles of assorted clothing.

payments.comment: Gracias por su ayuda, mi negocio esta mejorando y necesito capital nuevo para invertir.

loans.name: Angel Asenov

texts.en:
Angel is a 29-year-old resident of Sliven, Bulgaria. Angel is a member of the Roma minority, also referred to as gypsies. He lives in the Roma neighborhood in a small, 2-room house without running water with his mother and brother.

For the past 15 years, Angel has worked in a bike shop in the center of Sliven tuning and repairing bikes. This year, Angel wants to start his own bike repair shop in the Roma neighborhood, "Nedeshda". Bikes play an important role for transport for members of the Roma community for two key reasons: 1) very few Roma own functioning vehicles and 2) public transport does not serve the Nedeshda. As such, the Roma without donkeys predominately get around by riding their bikes and walking.

The focus of Angel's business will be fixing punctured tires and tubes, broken chains and petals. The seed capital provided by this loan will be enough to cover the equipment he needs (welding tools, wrenches, screwdrivers, saws, hammers and a number of bike-specific tools), inventory (rubber, spare parts) and the modest renovation he needs to perform on the part of his house where he will have this shop (shown in photo).

loans.use: Investment in equipment and renovations to shop (shown in photo)

payments.comment: This payment should have been a bit larger.  Angel will need an extra week to generate the cash for the full payment.  We are not charging him any late fees for this.
Angel made his November payment early.

This completes Angel's loan, but we will be putting up another shortly for his new metalworking equipment.  Send me an email at greg dot kelly dot business at gmail dot com if you'd like to be notified when it is up.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica A. is a very active member of Life in Africa who came to Kampala as a result of the war in Northern Uganda.

Monica's husband was seriously wounded by rebels before they came to Kampala. He survived his wounds but has been left permanently disabled and unable to do physical work. Monica made ends meet making paper beads from glue and recycled paper, and working in a stone quarry next to the Internally Displaced camp in the outskirts of Kampala where they live.

In August of 2005 Monica joined Life in Africa and now earns a good living making solidarity bracelets that raise global awareness of the situation in Northern Uganda. She employs others to work at her place in the quarry, and finally has enough income to maintain her family's basic needs. She now has enough income to service a small loan of shs. 800,000 ($475), with which she plans help her husband participate in supporting the family again.

They have a small room at their residence which Monica and her husband plan on turning into a food shop. Her husband will run the shop while Monica continues to work.

Below is her budget; Sugar 3 bags @ 70,000/= 210,000/=
Maize flour 3 bags @ 50,000/= 100,000/=
Peanuts 1 bags @ 150,000/= 150,000/=
Soap 2 boxes@ 15,000/= 30,000/=
Cooking Oil 1 j/can@ 30,000/= 30,000/=
Simsim 1 bag @ 150,000/= 150,000/=
Weighing Scale 1 pc @ 70,000/= 70,000/=
Transport 50,000/=
Contingencies 10,000/=

Based on her current income, she will be able to repay the loan in 12 months. Monica has desig-nated the community impact portion of the interest she pays to support the new Life in Africa WE Center in Gulu, her wartorn home.

loans.use: Purchase of commodities & weighing scale

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!
Monica has made her last payment and is complete.

loans.name: Ocola

texts.en:
Ocola J. is 52 years old and is married with 5 children. He is Acholi and is one of the many thousands of people who were forced to flee their homes in the North because of the war that has been going on for the last 20 years. His family lives in an Internally Displaced People's camp in the outskirts of Kampala called the Acholi Quarter. Six months ago J. joined Life in Africa and has been an active member ever since. He started as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet Project but his hard work and determination quickly earned him a promotion to a sanding processor.

He has acquired a piece of land from the King of Buganda who has sympathy for the people of Acholi and who has set aside free land for them. Knowing that the people of the Acholi quarter have to go long distances to look for water, he has a plan to install a water tap on his land. The current water sellers who bring water in to this hilltop area are charging five shillings per litre for water which makes it very hard for the people to purchase water for their needs. With a water tap installed on his land, J. will be able to purchase water for only one shilling per litre and he plans on selling this water for a reduced rate of 3 shillings per litre to his community.

Not only will this provide a steady income for his family needs, but it will also offer a valuable service to his community at a more affordable price than they can currently get. This will insure that he has a secure source of buyers for his water, and it is likely to have a great impact on those living in the Acholi quarters.

To accomplish this project, J. is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 800,000 ($475). He es-timates that once he acquires this loan it will take approximately one week to have the water tap installed. Below is his budget:

16 metal pipes @ 12000= each =192000=
connection fee to national water=300000=
labor charges & other expenses =200000=
building of small house so that the tap can be locked to avoid theft =100000=
The whole total is 792000=.

Based on his current income, J. will be able to repay this loan in 12 months. J. loves music and dance, and has designated the community impact portion of the interest he pays to support Life in Africa's Talent Discovery program.

loans.use: Installation of water tap & water company fees

payments.comment: After getting his loan Ochola started setting up his tap water system and he has started repaying his loan.

Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!
Life in Africa has paid this loan back in full for Julius since he was no longer paying back, we shall arrange his repayment to us according to our own schedule.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace A. is a mother of four children and has been an active member of Life in Africa for the last four years. Five years ago she was faced with the problem of earning enough money to support herself and her children. As with many women in her situation, she turned to something she knew to try and earn money. She happened to know how to make good peanut butter and so she started her small business. Her main goal was to be self reliant and to serve her customers well while earning an income to support her children.

In the beginning she used the age old method of grinding the nuts using a mortar and pestle. This method worked but it was a very slow process and she found she was not able to make the peanut butter fast enough to earn adequate money. To remedy this, she carefully planned and saved to purchase a processing machine. This enabled her to process enough to meet the de-mands of her customers and her business grew.

But her good business sense tells her that she can do more. She now has the capability of pro-ducing large quantities but still must produce smaller batches because she has no way of storing it until it is sold. This will require the purchase of a refrigerator which will allow her to always have a supply on hand and will also enable her to increase her number of customers. To accomplish this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000us. This amount will purchase a refrigerator, additional packing materials needed and the necessary capital to expand her production. Below is her budget:

800,000/= LOAN BUDGET
FRIDGE 400,000=
PACKING MATERIALS 200,000=
ADDITIONAL CAPITAL 200,000=
TOTAL 800,000=

Based on her current income, Grace will be able to repay the loan in 6 months. She has desig-nated 1/4 of the interest she pays on this loan to support educational opportunities for Life in Af-rica member children.

loans.use: Purchase of fridge, additional packing & raw materials

loans.name: Zarina

texts.en:
Zarina A. is a widow with three children. When her husband died unexpectedly she had just given birth to the third child and she was left with the sole responsibility of providing for herself and her children. This is no easy task for a woman in Uganda but Zarina was determined and remarkably managed to obtain a job as a housekeeper in Kampala. It was through this job that she was introduced to Life in Africa and she has been an active member for the last five years.

Zarina saw value in building rental properties as a way to provide for her children's education. She managed to secure several loans through Life in Africa and built a solid housing unit in a poor section of Kampala. She has several tenants living in her property now and she was able to responsibly pay back all her loans. She earns an income from this property of shs. 200,000 ($111) each month. But the house is not yet plastered. She wants to finish the outside properly now to ensure that her tenants have quality housing for their families and to insure the value and durability of her investment.

Zarina is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 800,000 ($475) to complete the plastering of the property. Her budget is listed below.

20 bags of cement @ 17000= 340000=
sand 80000=
labor 300000=
transport 50000=
other expenses 30000=
Total 800000=

Based on her current income, Zarina will be able to pay off this loan in 4 months. She has desig-nated 1/4 of the interest she pays to support craft skills development workshops at Life in Africa, which she enjoys taking part in.

loans.use: plastering

payments.comment: Zarina has started paying back her loan.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter has just been promoted to Foreman at the Life in Africa WE Center in Kampala. His hope is to eventually return to University for further studies, but in Peterâ€™s family itâ€™s become urgent that he starts to think about finding a wife â€“ two of his younger brothers have serious girlfriends they would like to marry, but it is against custom for them to marry before their older brothers do. With his recent promotion, Peter also believes itâ€™s time he started to think seriously about his future, and a wife is definitely part of the plan.

In Uganda, however, marriage is not a day long event but a long process that begins at the point Peter finds himself now. Since itâ€™s taboo for any girl Peter brings home to enter his fatherâ€™s house, the first thing that must happen is that Peter builds a house of his own on his fatherâ€™s land in Tororo (Eastern Uganda). Peter has been saving for this purpose and would like a loan of shs. 800,000 ($475) to add to what he has saved and complete the house quickly.

Peter is an extremely sincere, hardworking and capable young man, and very popular with the Life in Africa members - who are all now wondering who his choice of bride will be!

Below is Peterâ€™s budget:
Cement 20 Bags @ 17000 = 52000
Sand 2 Trips @ 30000 = 60000
Doors 4 @ 50000 = 200000
Windows 4 @ 15000 = 60000
Nails 4kg @ 4000 = 16000

Based on his current income, Peter will be able to repay this loan in 8 months. He has designated a portion of the interest he pays on the loan to support Life in Africaâ€™s Internet4change Program.

loans.use: building materials

loans.name: Nighty

texts.en:
Nighty A. is one of the most active Life in Africa member from the displaced Acholi quarter in the ouskirts of Kampala. In addition to working in a stone quarry, she also now earns a part time income making solidarity bracelets to increase awareness of the war in her home of Northern Uganda.

Nighty's husband has deserted her but she has struggled for the welfare of her family. She has managed singlehandedly to send all her children back to school and has also managed to save a little bit for further development.

With this savings she has acquired a small piece of land at the acholi quarters , where she now plans to build a two roomed house that will create more space for the children.

Below is her budget in full:
Bricks 5,000/= @ 60/= 300,000/=
Cement 10 bags @18,000/= 180,000/=
Iron sheets 20 pcs @10,000/= 200,000/=
Timbers 20 pcs @ 5,000/= 100,000/=
Transport 20,000/=v Total 800,000/=

Based on her current income, Nighty will be able to repy this loan in 12 months. She has desig-nated a 1/4 of the interest she pays on this loan to support educational opportunities for Life in Af-rica member children.

loans.use: purchase building materials

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en:
Teopista joined Life in Africa in February of 2005. Since then she has been a very active member and has become a leader at the WE Center. She is a single mother raising three children and she always works very hard to provide for them and to keep them in school. As they get older, the school fees increase and she is looking for a way to insure that she will be able to pay all the fees so they can complete their education. She does not think that being a single mother should be a barrier to her children's education.

Even with all the demands for their needs, she has managed to save enough money to acquire a plot of land. She plans to build a house on this land that she will rent out. The income from this rental property will be specifically used for her children's education. Housing is in high demand so this will be a sound investment.

She is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 800,000 ($475) to assist her in starting the first phase of her project. She has savings that she will add to this loan to purchase the necessary materials to lay the foundation and build part of the walls.

Her total project budget is shs. 3,252,000/=
With the 800,000/= that Teopista is asking to borrow for the first phase, she plans to buy:
Bricks 7,000 @ 60/= 420,000/=
Cement 20 bags @ 18,000/= 360,000/=
Transport 20,000/=
TOTAL 780,000/=

Based on her current income, Teopista will be able to repay the loan in 12 months. She has des-ignated 25% of the interest she pays on the loan to support Life in Africa's Internet4Change training program.

loans.use: Purchase building materials

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is an awesome lady. She is a widowed mother of three beautiful children. She joined Life in Africa in 2003 and is now the WE Center Manager. She is loved and respected by all who work with her.

5 years ago, Monica's husband died of injuries he suffered in a trucking accident. After he died, his family came and claimed all his property, including their family home, leaving Monica and her children left on the street to start life over from scratch. This sort of thing happens far too often in Uganda and there was nothing legal that Monica could do. When she found her way to Life in Af-rica she was destitute, but realized that she could learn new skills that might improve her situation.

Monica learned quickly and worked hard. She is now the Manager of the Life in Africa WE Center and earns a steady income. Her children are all in school and their lives have greatly improved. But they still have no home to call their own, and this is a painful memory for the whole family. Monica feels it's important to give her children a home that no one can take away from them or evict them from.

She has sold some property her family owned in her village and has managed to buy a plot of land in Kireka on the outskirts of Kampala. Here she plans to build a solid family home. She has carefully planned and the project will be completed in three years using money she saves from her salary and a series of loans. The total budget for the house she wishes to build is shs. 13,000,000 ($7220).

She is seeking a loan in the amount of shs 800,000 ($475) for the first phase. This will build the foundation of the house. Once this loan is repaid, she will start on the next phase and continue until the house is built. The loan she is requesting will enable her to buy: hard core stones, bricks, sand, and cement, all for laying the foundation of the house.

Based on her current income, Monica can repay this loan in 12 months. She has designated 1/4 of the interest she pays on her loan to support Life in Africa's Internet4Change training program.

loans.use: Purchase building materials

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!

loans.name: Marco Tulio Morales

texts.en: My name is Tulio Morales, my business is the making and selling of cement blocks.  My operation is located on my property where I live, near the town of La Entrada a Copn.  We live in an area where there are a lot of cement shops like mine.  Right now, I have several good orders from people that live in neighboring townships, people who have their own construction businesses.  Peolple come to me for my good quality and fair price.  I have four children of school age, so I work hard to have a good businesss.

loans.use: Purchase of materials such as cement, sand, and gravel.

loans.name: Dionicia

texts.en: My name is Dionicia B., and I have been selling furniture out of my home for ten years.  I buy my inventory in Honduras comercial center, the city of San Pedro Sula.  My store was nothing when it started, now it is the biggest furniture store in my area, I have very good clients and people know me.  I have three children of school age and I know I have to keep my business prosperous in order to provide an educated life for my family.

loans.use: Buy inventory: furniture and other household Ã­tems.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

texts.en:
This business is a member of Enkakenya Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Joyce is an active member of Enkakenya Women Group which started five years ago. She is married with two children not yet ready for school.

Joyce attended WEECâ€™s livestock programme training and later was given a livestock loan. She has managed to pay it back. Meanwhile, she has been saving small money with the group and this has made her qualify for yet another loan.

loans.use: She plans to buy 4 steers, rear them for some few months and sell. She says the current season is good for them as there is enough pasture.

payments.comment: Iam glad to inform Joyce's lenders that she paid USD.100. This payment covers the month of april and may.

loans.name: Mokoine Sinkooi

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Enkakenya Women Group. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Mokoine is married and a mother of four. She is an active member of Enkakenya where she is the rules controller. She is disciplined and hardworking.

Traditionally, she is a Masai and these are cattle keepers. She joined the group five years ago and has been saving with the group for all this time. She attended livestock training and thereafter was given a loan of USD.300. She bought three steers which she later sold and a profit of USD.150. Currently, she is raising four steers hopefully they will be sold in two months time. There is ready market for them in Nairobi and nearby towns.

loans.use: She wants to buy a diary cow to at least be getting daily income from the sale of milk.

payments.comment: Mokoine paid her 1st and 2nd installments on 17/05/06. She is happy for this achievement.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
This business is a member of Naretoi Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Patricia is an active member of Naretoi Women Group. She is married with 3 children.

Patricia received her first loan from WEEC of USD.300 in 2001. She bought two steers and started her business of making handicraft at home, selling them in Isinya. She then received a loan of USD.600 and bought 4 more steers. To date, she has over 20 steers. She able to pay her children school fees and meet all family requirements. The demand for steers is very high because this area was hit by prolonged drought which forced some cattle keepers to relocate.

loans.use: They plan to improve the type of feeds to counter natural disasters. Therefore, this loan will enable them to buy the improved feeds and buy more steers.

Grace is married with 6 dependants. She was educated up to college school level and an adult education teacher in Isinya. She is the current group treasurer and merry go round in the area. She is a member of Mothers Union where she is the treasurer.

Grace started her business of rearing steers in 1996. She received her first loan from WEEC of USD.450 in 2001. She added 6 more steers. In November 2001 she was given another loan of USD.600 which enabled her to buy 8 more steers. These replaced the six which were sold.

loans.use: She plans to maintain stock at a level of 10 steers to match with the demand in the area. This loan will be used to buy more steers.

This business is a member of Naretoi Women Group. She is an active lady and has experiences in various businesses such bead work. Hellen is married with four children.

Hellen joined WEEC in year 2001, received a loan of USD300. She started buying and selling Goats and sheep. The business went on well, paid up the first loan and there after, applied for a second loan. She was given a loan of USD.450 which she used to add more stock. She is unable to supply the required number to customers thus a need for more funding to increase stock.

loans.use: The amount requested for will assist her to boost her business such that she maintains and possibly add new clients.

The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Joyce is married with 3 children. She was educated up to primary school level. She was later trained on livestock management. This enabled her to work on improving the cattle for marketing. She is also a devoted member of catholic church.

Traditionally the family has always kept cattle because it has a large area for grazing. Instead of keeping large herds of cattle, Joyce has turned to purchasing of good quality steers and rearing them for 6 months using modern improved methods. She later market the steers at Enkirgirri market at USD 205. Currently Joyce has only 3 steers out of 5 as two died out of prolonged drought.

loans.use: Given USD 450, Joyce will be able to purchase 3 steers and rear them for the market. She will also buy feeds and also graze them in her land now that the rains has come.

payments.comment: Joyce's business is doing very well and paid her first and seond installment of USD.75.

loans.name: Lucy Ene Lantei

This business is a member of the Enkakenya Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

She is married with 5 children. Family owns grazing land. She has acquired business training from WEEC and also attends business forums organized to train on livestock management; she is able to keep livestock records and all business records.

In year 2003, Lucy took USD 441 and bought 3 steers. WEEC organized for training on livestock management for the clients. Since then Lucy has taken up a USD 588 loan and used the amount for buying 4 steers of which she later sold them at USD 883 after. Lucy is now capable of keeping a number of steers due to the trainings she has had modern livestock management.

loans.use: She intends to buy 6 steers restock her farm to be ready for the season in July when the demand is very high.

payments.comment: Lucy successfully paid USD.150 on 17/05/06 being payment for her 1st and 2nd installments.

loans.name: Mosompa Kapita

texts.en:
Masompa is married with six dependants .she did not have formal education though she was able to educate her children by keeping dairy cows. She is a devoted   Christian and a member of Ack church Mothers Union. She is the chairlady of the group.

She started by buying two dairy cows when given a Mifugo loan by WEEC in 2001.she later started Zero grazing. Today her Dairy cows produce enough milk to be consumed at home and twenty litres to be sold to local hotels. Her Dairy farming business enables her to educate her children.

loans.use: If a loan of USD.900 is given to her, she will be in a position to buy two more Dairy cows and a steer, thus increasing milk production as well as income.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
This business is a member of Queen Esther Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Lucy W. is a client of WEEC and a member of Queen Esther Women Group. She is a widow who has been self independent for some years. She lives in Ole Roimen where her business is located. She is a mother and a grandmother to several off springs.

Lucy is a successful business woman with rental houses which bring for her a substantial amount of income. Apart from this she is a farmer who rears goat and also cultivates food crops.

With various loans that have been advanced to her by the group and WEEC, she has been able to build more rooms for rental. These rooms do not have electricity and this reduces the amount of money that is charged.

loans.use: Lucy intends to install electricity in her rental houses. She views this as one of the ways to increase her income, as tenants will be paying much more than before.

payments.comment: She paid on may 18th her 1st installment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The loan applied for will be used for improving the business premises to increase appeal and attract more customers.

payments.comment:
This loan has not been disbursed and is being refunded to you now.

After further consultation with the group, the partner representative felt it best not to administer the loan to this particular borrower.

Salome W. is a business woman, married and living in Ole Roimen. Most of her business skills have been learnt through years of practice by which she has acquired various businesses.

Salome operates her business of rental houses located in Ole Roimen area. She has a number of rental houses which provide income for her family. In addition to rental houses, she operates butchery and a shop in the same place. She sells kerosene, owns a kerosene pump and a grocery store.

loans.use: Salome intends to get a loan of USD 700 which will be used to renovate her rental houses. This will enable her increase income by increasing rent.

Phyllis M. is a very hardworking. She is married and has five children. She is the assistant secretary of the group.

Phyllis operates three businesses jointly with the husband that is selling water, paraffin and welding. While the husband is mostly based at the paraffin pump which is far from the home stead, she manages both the welding and water supply which are at their area of residence. Her businesses are performing well as she is the only person doing the welding and sale of water business in the area.

loans.use: With the money that Phyllis has requested, she plans to improve her welding business and the paraffin one.

Jacinta is a married woman. She has no professional business training but she is very hard working in her day to day business life. She lives in Kiserian where she operates her business.

Jointly with her husband, Jacinta a business of sale of fruits at Kiserian opposite Ngong stage. The business is both retail and wholesale fruits that are sold are mostly bananas but other types can also be found there. Jacinta also operates a door to door business of selling used clothes which she buys from Gikomba Market in Nairobi. Her business outlet is Kiserian where most of her clients reside. Her products are mostly ladies wear; dresses, skirts and blouses. Jacinta has previously taken loans from the group are used to expand both of her businesses.

loans.use: With the USD 300 that she has requested, Jacinta will be in a position to further expand her business.

Mary comes from Ole Roimen area. She is the chair lady of the group and has shown excellent leadership skills over the duration she has been the leader to the group.

Her business has expanded from operating a community phone to sale of other domestic food stuff. Her customers are those people who reside in the rental houses near by. Her business is doing well and it has enabled her to pay up her previous loans promptly.

loans.use: Mary intends to put up a room which she will use as a shop since the one she is operating from is jut a small structure. This will create room for expansion.

Nancy is a member of Queen Esther Women Group and she is married. Nancy has no professional training in business and also farming but uses indigenous farming methods.

Nancy takes farming as her sole business venture. Mostly she cultivates food crops that range from maize, beans and other types of cereal. Her activities have been affected over the last seasons because of the prolonged drought. She has been straggling with irrigation using local means on a small piece of land but it would have been better if she had a water pump. This is costly and thus would like to buy a dairy cow for zero grazing.

loans.use: She plans to buy a dairy cow to enable her diversify her income.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: She intends to increase the variety and quantity of foodstuffs to match the demand. So a loan of USD 425 will help her meet the desired demand.

payments.comment:
This loan has not been disbursed and is being refunded to you now.

After further consultation with the group, the partner representative felt it best not to administer the loan to this particular borrower.

Rachel is married with 4 dependants. She did not have formal education but she was able to educate her children by keeping steers. She is a devoted Christian and a member of Anglican Church of Kenya (ACK) and a Mothers Union member. She is a chairlady of several merry go rounds in Olturoto.

She was given a loan of USD 300 by WEEC in 2001and bought two steers. She later bought She paid very well and qualified for another loan. She sold them and made a profit of USD.200.Her 2nd loan of USD.450 was used for the same business. Right now, she has 10 steers which are about to be for sale.

loans.use: She is planning to add more three steers such that she maintains a steady supply to her customers.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Naretoi Women Group. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Hellen is married with 4 children and 6 dependants. She has been a member of Naretoi women Group for five years. She is a devoted Christian and a member of ACK church.

Hellen was given her first loan of USD.300 by WEEEC in 2001. She Started her business of buying and selling of sheep and goats. She paid very well and was later given another loan of USD.450 in 2003. She is able to buy and sell a minimum of 15 goats and sheep once a week. She is doing very well so far and targets to sell at least 25 per week. This will give her enough income to provide for her family without much strain.

loans.use: Hellen plans to increase stock and be able to sell to buyers from the nearby town because they normally miss out on market days.
