loans.name: Edidah

texts.en:
Edidah is a wonderful woman and is a very active member of Life in Africa. She is the sole breadwinner for seven children. She is very talented in the art of handicrafts and earns her living by making and selling beautiful basket, bracelets, shopping bags and many other items.

She faces several challenges in her work. The first is that she is an asthmatic. This makes it very difficult to work during the cold and wet season. However, she does not let this fact stop her and she works hard even when she is sick. These skills, her determination and her good business sense allow her to provide the basic needs for her family. Her other challenge is providing the school fees to educate all her children. Their education has become her number one priority.

To overcome this last challenge, Edidah has devised a plan to constuct a two room house that she will rent out. She owns a plot of land located at Mutungo near Kampala and she has family there to help in the constuction of this house. This project will take about three months to complete and once it is finished, she will use the income from this property to pay the school fees that will insure the education of her children.

She is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 500,000.

Below is her budget:

  • Cement - 12 bags 200,000/=
  • Doors - 2 pcs 90,000/=
  • Wood - 20 pcs 100,000/=
  • Labour - 85,000/=
  • Bricks ((3500in number) 24,500/=

Total 500,000/=

Loan Amount 500,000/=

Edidah will be able to repay her loan in 10 installments. She has designated 25% of the interest she pays on the loan to support the WE Team for developing self-sustaining project at LiA, which she currently leads.

loans.use: Purchase building materials.

loans.name: Agnes Wakiruru

texts.en:
Agnes is married with four children. She has trained on secretarial, computers and an accountant by professional. She is a CCI member.

She started her private computer college eight years ago. She is the Managing Director of the college which has 170 students. Thika is a densely populated town and most school leavers have missed vacancy in her college due to lack of enough computers and training materials. The college has employed 8 members of staff.

loans.use: A loan of USD.750 will help her to buy a new computer to easy her work and good storage students’ data.

loans.name: Eunice Muthoni

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Eunice Muthoni is the current chairlady of Revelation women group. She has been the Women Coordinator of St Stephen Anglican Church of Kenya for the last five years. She is married with 5 children.

She started her small shop in 2003 after being given her first loan of USD.300 from WEEC.Landless area is a dry area and sodas and other cold drinks sale easily. The population of the area is growing very fast and at times runs out of stock of some items which is not good if you are to attain and retain customers.

loans.use: Her wish is to buy a refrigerator so as to provide cold drinks and stock the different items which are frequently asked and are not there at present.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Edith is married with 4 children. She is hardworking and a good member of PCEA church.


Edith has a banana plantation in Maragua District in central Kenya. She also grows and sells maize and beans. Edith has been in this business for the last two years. She also has a lorry for transport business. It is normally hired to carry building materials in Thika. Thika is an industrial town where construction works is at an increase. This business has built her a house and is about to be completed.

loans.use: The loan applied for will be used to repair the lorry.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Grace is a pastor of Regeneration church in Thika, Kenya. Through her church ministry, she has traveled to Uganda, Tanzania, Sudan and Rwanda. She has been a member of Revelation women group for the last 4 years. She is a mother of four.

In 2005 she received a loan of USD.300 and bought a cow. To date she has two dairy cows. She also practices horticulture farming on a small scale. She sells milk, onions, and cabbages to her neighbors and in Thika town.

loans.use: Grace wants to start up community phone services and a retail store near her church to bring services nearer to the people.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
This business is a member of the Revelations Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

Jane is married with six children. She joined the group in 2003. She is an active member of the group and the local self help group.

Jane started her business of selling cereals in 2003. She was given her first loan of USD.300 by WEEC and had trained in hair dressing. Therefore, she started her own salon in Thika town. The business has grown and handles mores than 10 people a day.

loans.use: Given a loan of USD.300, Jane will be able to upgrade her salon and increase stock of her shop.

loans.name: Fredah

texts.en:
"This business is a member of the Revelations Women group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Fredah is married with one child. She is an active member of Revelation Women Group .She is enterprising and multi skilled, she makes shoes, belts, dresses, trousers and shirts.

Fredah got her first loan from WEEC in 2004 of USD 150.
She started selling rice after resigning her job in a leather factory. Her wish was to own a business however small it was in order to be independent.
She sells over 200kgs per month earning her USD 71 as profit.
In addition, her tailoring business brings in extra income. She is to open up a bigger stall in thika town for easy merchandising.

loans.use: She plans to increase stock of rice as well as buy materials for ladies wear because they have ready market. Therefore, a loan of USD 300 will contribute to realizing her dream.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Jane intends to invest the USD 300 into her business and use it to buy paint. There ready market hence she will be able to pay her loan with ease.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: They own a small plot in Kware and want to construct rental rooms. A loan of USD 300 will assist them to start up the project. At least they want to start with three rooms and rent them at USD 10 each per month.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Margaret wants to rent a semi permanent stall to enable her display her finished work and tap more customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The loan that has been requested will assist Jennifer to buy malaria drugs because it affects a number of people in the area. She also wants to develop her plot at Gathiga.

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
"This business is a member of the Kandisi Wisdom Women group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Miriam is married with two children who are in lower primary. She had to start a small business to assist the husband cater for the household expenses as well as household development.

In year 2005, Miriam received USD 27 from her husband that enabled her to start a small business of used baby clothes. She used to select assortment of baby jumpers, truck suits, socks that could move fast. This enabled her sales turnover to be high. She ploughed back the profits and this enabled her stock to grow. At the end of 2005, Miriam joined WEEC program. She got USD.55 and added more baby clothes plus baby shoes. Miriam has also received trainings especially on business skills and management; she is able to keep her business records. Miriam saved USD 3 per month and has saved a total of USD 38. So far, her profit per day is about USD 7 per day.

loans.use: Given a loan of USD 300 Miriam will enable her to have a permanent stall and also add stock of new baby clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The USD 600 loan will be used to include other soft drinks in her retail shop to meet her customers’ needs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: With a loan of USD 550, Mary plans to buy more pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Given a loan of USD 450, Mary will add her stock to enable her give her customers better services.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The loan of USD 600 will be used to increase her stock and use the rest of money will be put in milk business.

loans.name: Peris

texts.en:
"This business is a member of the Future Fruits group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Peris is 40 years old, married with 6 dependants. She is the chairperson of Future fruit.

Peris started dairy farming way back in 1992. From the sale of milk, she was able to construct rental houses.
She distributes her milk to hotels both in Nairobi and Kiserian. She also rears chicks for sale. There is potential market for chicks and milk. Withdraws from the business to pay school fees retards business growth.

loans.use: A loan of USD300 will help her maintain the chicks and allow a normal growth of this business.

loans.name: Bethua

texts.en:
"This business is a member of the Future Fruits group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Bethua is 40 years old, married and has five dependents. She is educated up to secondary level and she lives in Ole Roimen, Kiserian Town. She is the secretary of this group.

Bethua started her business in 1996 as a sole proprietor. She borrowed before from the groups’ revolving fund and used the money to expand her business. She operates her small shop at the same place she resides. With proper training on business and credit management, from WEEC, she has been able to run her small business well.

loans.use: With the USD 225 she will increase stock and this will attract more customers.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
"This business is a member of the Future Fruits group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Lydia is a 32 year old and is married with four children. She is the treasurer of this group.

She has been operating this business for the last two year. The business is growing steadily and sales are improving day by day. She has been getting small loans from the groups’ revolving fund to finance her business. But, she now feels that she needs a bigger loan since her business is growing rapidly.

loans.use: If a loan of USD 150 is given, she will increase her stock so as to attract more customers to her stall.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
"This business is a member of the Future Fruits group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Beatrice is 42 years old. She is single, has 6 dependants and lives in Matasia.

Beatrice sells maize and beans. She also has a dairy cow and sells milk. Due to the prolonged drought that has hit the country; she plans to concentrate on Zero grazing of Dairy cows because she is assured of income daily.

loans.use: Sale of Produce and Milk

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
"This business is a member of the Future Fruit Women group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff"

Jane is single and lives in Kiserian. She is 42 years old, a secondary school graduate.

She has been in this business of rearing chicken for the last 6 years. The business has been doing well and she sells chicks, layers and broilers in Kiserian town. She is now an established supplier of broilers in the area.

loans.use: A loan of USD225 will be used to expand her rearing area and to add on the number of chicken.

loans.name: Maria Olinda

texts.en: Maria G. is originally from Azuay but has lived in Guayaquil, Ecuador for more than 30 years. She has owned this store for 23 years with the help of her husband and only son. Her husband is in charge of buying merchandise for the store, but he can only buy as much as the store sells in the short term. Therefore, the store has very little in stock and cannot buy at larger quantities with cheaper prices. She has made efforts to seek loans from banks but has been rejected and she cannot pay the 20% monthly interest rates that local informal lenders offer. With the $500 loan she will be able to take advantage of better deals from her wholesale providers and also diversify her products.

loans.use: Improve Inventory

payments.comment: Agradece a los prestatarios y pide que le sigan aportando con un nuevo microcredito para continuar trabajando con la ayuda del prestamo. Su esposo les manda muchos saludos.

loans.name: Cesar Hugo

texts.en: Cesar Hugo is a 58 year old blacksmith who specializes in the production of metal doors, window frames and fences. These products are in high in demand in poor sectors in order to protect businesses and homes from robbery. Cesar has 4 sons who work with him on his business which is operated out of his mother’s home. Currently he can only work when he receives an order because he does not have the money to buy materials so that he can make products in advance. He hopes that this loan will allow him to make some doors and gates he can display in order to attract more clients and sell at faster rates.

loans.use: Purchase Materials

loans.name: Angel

texts.en: Angel Conforme is 52 years old and has 3 children. He’s owned this store for about four years and counts on the help of his wife who also works part time for a bakery and of his kids when they are not in school. He sells all kinds food items but concentrates on selling candies, snacks and other foods for people on the go. He is in need of capital so that he may improve his current product offerings and sell at lower prices. It is very difficult for him to maintain his inventory without the power to buy in bulk.

loans.use: Improve Inventory

loans.name: Sotero

texts.en: Sotero P. is 45 years old, was born in the province of Manabi in Ecuador, is married and has a 6 year old son. Sotero is a tailor who makes suits and uniforms of all types. He operates his business out of his home for over 32 years and has the help of his wife and a partner who purchases some of the suits he makes in order to resell them. He is in dire need for capital in order to increase production for the upcoming school year. He expects that demand will be high because students will need new uniforms and teachers will also be looking for new work attire. In order to meet the demand he must buy more materials to make the clothing. He is hopeful that he will receive the loan in time to make these products.

loans.use: Purchase Materials (Fabrics)

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is married with three children. She has been in business over the past ten years. She runs a stationery and schools supplies shop in Dar es Salaam. Her shops stocks general stationery (files, ball pens, maker pens, counter books, flip charts, office pins , paper clips, paper punches etc). Recently she introduced primary and secondary schools textbooks. The new line of business requires high capital because the number of schools has increased in Dar es Salaam due to the high priority now given on education by the government. The new line requires high lumpsum of money to meet seasonal demand for textbooks especially in June and December/January before new semesters starts.

Given a loan of $1000, she plans to increase his stock by buying more stationery and textbooks. The loan term will be twelve months. She has a well established credit history with Microfinance Institutions.

loans.use: Stationary Services

loans.name: Dossy

texts.en:
Mossy Doss runs two business, decorations at functions/ceremonies (weddings, business meetings etc) and a boutique. She was educated up to secondary education. She could not get a job because employment opportunities are limited especially for girls. Her parents decided to send her for a tailoring course, where she completed and started her own tailoring mart. Later she discovered that during weekend there is high demand for decorations business. She decided to learn the skill through apprenticeship. The new line of business keeps her busy particularly on Fridays and Saturdays when weeding and other cerebrations takes place.

The loan of US$ 1000 will assist her purchase up to date decorations materials and equipment. The materials are locally available through importers who normally get them from Far East. She an experienced borrower and she is confident that she will repay her loan on time. Her business makes her move from one venue to the other every time. She works hard to meet clients orders and meet their expectations.

loans.use: Purchase of decoration lamps, artificial flowers, table cloth

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria M. was born in Guayaquil, Ecuador. This 40-year-old single mother of three opened her restaurant 10 years ago. Her clients are all regulars from her neighborhood, and they all enjoy the tasty food she offers day-in and day-out. Gloria works from 6am serving breakfast to the morning crowd until 4 pm when she serves lunch. This $400 loan will allow her to accomodate her devoted clients better and expand her business.

loans.use: Gloria plans to use her $400 loan to expand her local restaurant and satisfy her regular customers by accomodating them better. She intends to buy more tables, utensils, as well as cooking items like oil, sugar, and rice...

loans.name: Luis

texts.en: Frutas Don Luis, which has been open for 29 years now, would like to thank Mifex and Kiva for advertising the need for business capital. He moved to Guayaquil, Ecuador from Cotopaxi (sierra region) 40 years ago to start a new life for himself and his family. At the age of 53, Luis has plenty of experience selling his fruit, but he needs vital capital to expand. He runs his shop along with his wife, so they can continue to provide a better life for their children. His three children are grown up now and live independent from the family, and he would like to improve their lot. Until now, Luis has been unable to gain access to credit from any institution.

loans.use: Luis plans to diversify his fruit inventory with this loan capital, and he also will be able buy more items in bulk. Because he will have enough cash to purchase more fruit, he does not have to buy his fruit on credit (which can be very costly)

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Mónica S., 39 years old, was born in the province of Manabi. She is married with 2 children that are in school. The bakery which is located downstairs from her house is in a part of town where there is not an overabundance of bakeries. Also, the business lies along a main thoroughfare, so plenty of traffic passes by their store. From 6am until 10pm Monica and her husband sell bread and other bakery items. They know how to run their business efficiently, but they lack the capital to expand.

loans.use: Monica and her husband, who helps the run the bakery, would like to use the $600 to be able to buy ingredients including flour, sugar, butter, and oil. Both she and her hasband run the business, while one of them typically handles the finances. They would like lenders to know they are excited.

loans.name: Bosco

texts.en:
C. Bosco has been an active member of Life in Africa since 2005. He currently works at the WE Center as a gatekeeper and he also makes bracelets for the Invisible Children Bracelet Project.

Like so many others who have been forced to leave the war torn Northern Uganda, he and his family live in the displaced persons camp known as the Acholi quarters. He supports three children and working in the stone quarry made it impossible for him to earn enough money. Since coming to Life in Africa, he now earns enough money to make their lives much easier since they now have money for food, rent, and more important, for the school fees for his children. Now he feels proud and for the first time, he can start to see a future for his family again.

His first priority is to build a family home. He wants his children to have the security of having their own home again. He has a plot of land that the King of Buganda donated to the Acholi some years ago. He has already started to build his home but was forced to stop due to lack of funds. He is now seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to finish this home. He will be able to repay this loan in 6 months.

LOAN AMOUNT: 800,000

PLAN: BUILDING

He wants to buy the following materials

1: 12 iron sheets @----------------11000--------132,000/

2: 12 bags of cement @--------------18500-----201,000/

3: 3000 bricks @ 60-----------------------------180,000/

4:13 pieces of timber for roofing

(3x4)- 3000----24,000/

(4x2)-----5000-------------------25,000/

5: 2 trips of sand @----------60000----------------120,000/

6: transporting materials to the site-------------- 40,000/

7: Labour-------------------------------------------78,000/

TOTAL: 800,000/

C. plans to pay back this loan in 6 Months in amounts of 147,335 per month and he saves Ushs 170, 500/= per month. He has designated the community impact portion of the interest he will pay to support Life in Africa's Talend Discovery team.

loans.use: Finish walls and roofing

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en: Manuel A. is a blacksmith who has a relatively young business. He learned his skills from his job with another metal worker but had decided to venture on his own and begin offering these products in his own neighborhood because the demand is high. Currently he operates from the backyard of his home working on projects from the clients in his area. He must ask them to provide 50% of the costs upfront because he cannot afford the materials otherwise. Obviously this slows down his business and he could use the loan to buy tools and supplies that will allow him to make doors, gates and window frames in advance to increase sales.

loans.use: Buy tools and materials

loans.name: Jose

texts.en: Jose R. is a 52 year old store owner who has had his shop for about 14 years. He is not married but has the responsibility of taking care of his 11 year old adopted son and his mother. His store is on the bottom floor of his home and is located well in order to attract clients from the area. With the loan Jose will buy more merchandise to sell at lower prices. Jose is completed dedicated to his business which is open from 6am to 11pm. His hard work and perseverance have allowed him to buy his home and fulfill the responsibilities of being a father.

loans.use: Buy in bulk to improve inventory

payments.comment: Cancelación del mes de agosto, pago atrasado por problemas con su camión de trabajo.

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en: Vicente R. is a 50 year old father of two boys. For over 11 years he and his wife have owned a bakery that is very popular in his neighborhood. They begin baking at 6 am every morning and continue to sell throughout the day and night until about 10 pm. They will use the loan to buy ingredients for their bread like flour, butter and baking soda and will also consider purchasing complimentary goods that they can sell with their current product. This business has provided a living for them and their children and allowed them to build their current home.

loans.use: Buy flour, butter, baking soda etc.

loans.name: Simona

texts.en:
My name is Simona M.. I am owner of a small local grocery store for seven years. This is located in front of the soccer fields in this community, which strategic for my sales. With the gains that I obtain from my business , it helps to pay for schooling for my three children. My children also help with the running the business in their free time after school and on weekends. 

Descripción del Negocio: Me llamo Simona M., soy dueña de una pulpería desde hace siete años, esta ubicado frente a las canchas de foot ball en esta comunidad, lo que estratégico para mis ventas, ya que a partir del jueves mis ventas aumentan.. Con las ganancias que obtengo de mi negocio ayudo a mis tres hijos en sus estudios, ellos también colaboran en el negocio en sus ratos libres y fines de semana.

loans.use: Purchase of bottled soft drinks, various refreshments, chicken, juice, milk, hygienic paper, basic sugar, grains.

loans.name: Blanca Olga

texts.en:
I am Blanca P., I have a local grocery store in which I sell soups, bread, sugar, drinks, chicken, and other products for daily need. I have the store for fourteen years, my clients ask me to sell meat; which would be profitable because in this area there are no butcher shops and my clients have to go all the way to the market. With my earnings I help care for my four children, who also help in the store.

Descripción del Negocio: Yo soy Blanca P., tengo una pulpería en la que vendo sopas caseras, pan, azúcar, refrescos, pollos y otros productos de consumo diario. Lo tengo desde hace 14 años, mis clientes me piden que venda carne; que seria rentable ya que en esta zona no hay carnicerías y tienen que ir hasta el mercado. Con las ganancias que obtengo ayudo a sostener a mis cuatro hijos los cuales también colaboran en el negocio.

loans.use: Buying Botelled refreshments, sausages, chicken, juices, milk, 				toilet paper, sugar, basic grains.

loans.name: Eduardo Alonso

texts.en:
My name is Eduardo B., I have a shop located next to the highway that goes to the city, for five years I have provided services such as tire repair, I also buy second-hand tires and sell them as spare tires. With my earnings, I support my family of three children, all of whom are in school.

Descripción del Negocio: Me llamo Eduardo B., tengo un taller ubicado a la orilla de la carretera hacia la ciudad, desde hace cinco años doy el servicio de reparación de llantas, también compro de segunda para venderlas como llanta de repuestos. Con las ganancias que obtengo sostengo a mi familia de tres hijos los cuales están en la escuela.

loans.use: Lubricants, tires, products to repair tires.

loans.name: Agueda

texts.en:
My name is Agueda M. and I have been selling  underwear and sportswear for nine years, my clients prefer me because of the attention I give them and my good prices. This business permits me to help support my family and finance the higher education of my three children.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es Agueda Mejía me dedico a la venta de ropa  interior y deportiva desde hace nueve años, mis clientes me prefieren por la atención que les doy y por los precios. Este negocio me permite ayudar al sostenimiento de mi familia y a financiar los estudios superiores de mis tres hijos.

loans.use: Buying children’s underwear, men’s, women’s and children’s summer shirts, socks of various sizes and bathing suits.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Santos

texts.en:
I am Santos S., I have been selling clothes for six years. My store is located in the market in my city, which is heavily visited by people traveling through town, the majority of my sales are to people who sell my items in other cities. With my earnings I support my wife and my two school aged children.

Descripción del Negocio: Soy Santos S., me dedico a la venta de ropa desde hace seis años. Mi negocio está ubicado en el mercado de mi ciudad por lo que es bastante visitado por personas en transito, vendo al por mayor a personas que se dedican a vender en otras ciudades. Con las ganancias que percibo mantengo a mi esposa y dos hijos en edad escolar.

loans.use: Buying children’s clothes, trousers for women, men and children, underwear.

loans.name: José Victor

texts.en:
My name is Victor S., I have been working in my clothing store for eight years. It is located in the market of my city and is frequently visited by neighbors and people traveling through town. At this moment in time I would like to have more summer clothes. My family consists of my two children and my wife and we have to work to support our small family.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es Víctor S., me dedico a la venta de ropa desde hace ocho años. Esta ubicado en el mercado de mi ciudad por lo que es bastante visitado por vecinos y personas en transito. En este momento quiero tener mas ropa de verano. Mi familia es de dos hijos y mi esposa por lo que tenemos que trabajar para mantener a mi pequeña familia.

loans.use: Buying underwear, trousers for men, women and children, beach towels and bathing suits.

loans.name: Ramona

texts.en:
My name is Ramona A. and I have been working in my shoe store for eight years, I need a loan to supply my store because we are beginning the school year, but also for sandals for the summer and for the large amount of tourists. With my earnings I receive I help to support my family of three children.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es Ramona A. me dedico a la venta de calzado desde hace ocho años, necesito el préstamo para surtir mi negocio ya que todavía estamos iniciando la época escolar y para sandalias para época de verano ya que hay bastante visita de turistas. Con las ganancias que obtengo ayudo al sostenimiento de mi familia de tres hijos.

loans.use: Buying new shoes for men, women, and children as well as clothing for children and women.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Enoe

texts.en:
My name is Enoe L. and I have been working in my clothing store for twelve years, even now I continue to have many clients because they like my manner of attending to them and my prices. In the summer months I have a large demand for shorts, short sleeve shirts, towels with scenes of our city, because we receive many tourists here. I have three school ages children who help me in their spare time.

Descripción del Negocio: Me llamo Enoe L., me dedico a la venta de ropa nueva hace doce años, hasta ahora tengo mucha clientela ya que les gusta mi manera de atenderlos y los precios. En esta época de verano tengo bastante demanda en la ropa como short, camisetas, toallas con paisajes de nuestra ciudad ya que nos visitan bastantes turistas. Tengo tres hijos en edad escolar quienes me ayudan en sus ratos libres.

loans.use: Buying trousers for men, women and children, summer clothes and underwear.

loans.name: César Josué

texts.en:
My name is César C., I am twenty years old and I have been working in this shoe and book bag store for five years. I inherited this job when my father passed away and I continued the business, attending to customers, trying to give them good products and affordable prices. Right now, I am finishing high school, which I have to quit for a short time when my father died, because I had to take care of my mother and three younger siblings, who also go to school and help in other way to help support our family.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es César C.,  tengo veinte años de edad, me dedico a la venta de zapatos y mochilas desde hace cinco años. Recibí este puesto cuando falleció mi padre y continué con el negocio atendiendo a la clientela, trato de darles un buen producto y precios accesibles. Actualmente estoy terminando mis estudios secundarios los cuales abandoné por poco tiempo cuando murió mi padre, ya que me hice cargo de mi madre y tres hermanos menores, los cuales también estudian y ayudan en otras actividades para sostener a la familia.

loans.use: Buying new shoes, book bags, and briefcases.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: José Ramón

texts.en:
My name is Ramón H., I have a job selling products of daily consumption in the municipal market of the city. I have had this this job for two years, I depend on my loyal customers and I go out of my way to help them and give them good products and fair prices. I have two children and my wife, to whom my earnings go to, to help with expenses and food.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es Ramón H., tengo un puesto de venta de productos de consumo diario en el mercado municipal de mi ciudad, Tengo dos años de tenerlo activo por lo que cuento con mis clientes fijos ya que me preocupo por atenderles y darles buenos precios y productos. Tengo dos hijas y mi esposa por lo que los ingresos que percibimos me ayuda con los gastos y alimentación.

loans.use: Buying bottled refreshments, sausages, chicken, ham, milk, toilet paper, sugar, basic grains, milk products.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
My name is Antonio M., I have been selling rush-hats, leather belts, backpacks and briefcases for five years, I get my products from local artisans in my city. They are products that are produced primarily in this part of Honduras and are distributed on the national level, our city is one of the most visited by tourists and has tourists  year round. With my earnings from my business I support my three children who are in college.

Descripción del Negocio: Me llamo Antonio Mejía, me dedico a la venta de sombreros de junco, fajas de cuero, mochilas y maletines hace cinco años, mis compras las realizo a artesanos de mi ciudad ya que son productos que se producen mayormente en este departamento de Honduras y son distribuidos a nivel nacional, nuestra ciudad es una de las mas visitada por turistas y el movimiento es de todo el año. Con las ganancias de mi negocio mantengo a mis tres hijos que estudian en el colegio.

loans.use: Buying book bags, briefcases, belts.

loans.name: Cleotilde

texts.en:
My name is Cleotilde B.. My store is in the municipal market, I sell clothes, book bags, pañaleros ( a type of clothing), baby clothes and other things, for five years, with my earnings I get from my business, I pay for my personal expenses, now that I am advanced in age, it is the only income I have.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es Cleotilde B., tengo mi negocio de venta de variedades en el mercado municipal vendo ropa, mochilas, pañaleras, ropa de bebé y otros hace cinco años, con los ingresos que percibo de mi negocio pago mis gastos personales ya que soy una persona de edad avanzada y es el único ingreso que tengo.

loans.use: Buying underwear for men, women and children, book bags and briefcases.

loans.name: Julio

texts.en:
I have been working selling shoes, clothes and belts in my community market for three years. I started this business when I retired and I found it difficult to find a job because of my age. With my earnings I receive I maintain my wife and three children who study at the university.

Descripción del Negocio: Me dedico a la venta de zapatos, ropa y fajas en el Mercado de mi comunidad hace tres años. Este negocio lo inicie una vez que me jubilaron y me ha sido difícil encontrar trabajo en alguna institución por mi edad. Con las ganancias que obtengo mantengo a mis esposa y mis tres hijos que estudian en la universidad.

loans.use: Buying tennis shoes, summer sandals, short sleeve shirts, shorts, and belts.

loans.name: Marcelino

texts.en:
My name is Marcelino B., in my business I sell plastics, market baskets, cups, disposable silverware, bags for wrapping, tablecloths, napkins and other items for four years. My biggest clients are restaurants and canteens. With my earnings, I finance my personal expenses and those of my wife as we no longer have our children in our home.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es Marcelino B., mi negocio es la venta de plásticos, canastas de mercardo, vasos, platos, cubiertos desechables, bolsas para envolturas, manteles, servilletas y otros desde hace cuatro años. Mis mayores compradores son los restaurantes y comedores. Con las ganancias que obtengo solvento mis gastos personales y de mis esposa ya que no tenemos a cargo hijos.

loans.use: Buying plastic silverware, flowerpot holders, glasses, cups,  plastic cooking items, wastepaper baskets.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
My name is B. S., I have been working in my clothing shop for nine years, my store is at the entrance to the municipal market of my city. My husband and I run the store, but since we are both older in age, our children help us, our earnings are enough to cover out expenses.

Descripción del Negocio: Mi nombre es B. S., me dedico a la venta de ropa nueva desde hace cinco años, tengo mi puesto de venta en la entrada al mercado municipal de mi ciudad. Este negocio lo administro junto a mi esposo ya que ambos somos mayores y nuestros hijos ya no nos ayudan, las ganancias que nos genera son las suficientes para cubrir nuestros gastos.

loans.use: Buying knittings, underwear for men, women and children, trousers for men, women and children and beach towels.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Reason for Borrowing- Pedro M., who was born in Guayaquil, is a 49-year-old bicycle salesman who has been in business for 3 years. His small enterprise is located in the house that he and his brothers inherited from his father. His bike shop is strategically located because there is not another similar business like this nearby. Working from 9 am until 7 pm, Pedro desperately needs this capital to serve his clients better. He would like lenders to know that he is running a professional bike shop and that he is very responsible.

 

Justificacion de Credito- Pedro M. nació en Guayaquil, tiene 49 años de edad, es soltero, posee un negocio de venta de repuestos y arreglos de bicicletas desde hace 3 años, el negocio esta ubicado en su domicilio que fue herencia de sus padres con otros hermanos, la ubicación es estratégica porque no hay ese tipo de negocio en la zona y esta muy bien ubicado, atiende de 9:00AM hasta las 7:00PM., el esta solicitando el crédito para comprar más repuestos y surtir su negocio y atender mejor a sus clientes. Se pudo observar que Don Pedro es una persona que conoce del negocio y muy responsable.

loans.use: Pedro is posting on Kiva because he needs capital to buy more bike parts, improve the appearance of his shop, and attend to his clients better.

payments.comment: Don Pedro pago su cuota conforme esta establecido en el contrato.
Don Pedro pago su cuota conforme esta establecido en el contrato.
Pago de la 3/6 correspondiente a Agosto el contrato se inicio mayo 4/06

Pedro agradece a los prestatarios que le farorecieron su microcredito, espera muy pronto le sigan apoyando con otra operacion para seguir operando  su negocio. Los clientes estan contentos por la atencion que les da y para El es una importantisima ayuda el contar con capital de trabajo para generar mejores ingresos que afectan directamente a la familia.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy K. is a lady who believes in hard work, she joined Life in Africa in August 2005 and ever since she has worked hard to make ends meet in her life. She has since scheduled herself to both her jobs, selling her shop of ladies fashions and also working for the bracelet project for the Invisible Bracelet Campaign at Life in Africa.

She wants a loan to restock her shop with new fashions so that she can be able to capture more customers. She needs a loan of Ushs. 800,000 and her budget is indicated below.

  • 1 bale of ladies' Cotton skirts @ 200,000
  • 1 bale of ladies' silk blouses @ 170,000
  • 1 Bale of ladies' cotton dresses @ 180,000
  • 1 bale of ladies'double breast coats@ 220,000
  • Transportation @ 30,000

She wants to repay this loan in 12 months at a rate of Ushs.80,000 and her expenses verses income is Ushs.225,000. She saves Ushs.80,000 per month on her account.

She has designated the community impact portion of the interest she pays to support Life in Africa's Internet4Change Team, who need more computers. Read more about Joy at http://lifeinafrica.com/4/joyK.

loans.use: Restocking shop for ladies' garments

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!

loans.name: Ismeal

texts.en:
Ismael has a small room at his home in Bukoto which is suitable for a Laundry. He has done this business before. He has tried it out with rudimentary methods, which has limited him to certain customers. The clients with heavy woolen clothings like blankets, coats, bedcovers,etc which require the use of a washing machine. What he needs now is to improve on the standard of his work and also be able to cater for all these customers. He needs to buy the necessary equipments and this is the reason why he is requesting for a loan. The number of people who require his services have also increased. This is because his only competitors got their houses demolished after their landlord selling off the land where they were operating.

Ismeal lives in Bukoto, this is the next place to Ntinda where Life in Africa is situated. He has a wife and two children living with him. He joined life in Africa in october 2005, as a trainee internet4change Uganda. He got ajob with invisible children as a bracelet maker in Febuary 2006. Before he was doing this work but since he got another job as mentioned above, his cousin will help him do the laundry work. He has already saved 100,000/= for detergents and some few things he may need to add. He will also pay his cousin 30,000/= per month for helping him. He is requesting a loan of 700,000/= payable in 12 months. He will be paying 70,000/= per month.

Below is his budget:

  • Washing Machine 500,000/=
  • Counter Board 80,000/=
  • Ironing Board 30,000/=
  • Flat iron 30,000/=
  • Polythen Covers/coat covers (12) 6,000/=
  • Metallic Hangers (12) 5,000/=
  • Installation of machine and Labour 50,000/=
  • Total 701,000/=

Ismael's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by his community of peers at the Life in Africa WE Center in Kampala. He has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest he pays on this loan to support LiA's Internet4Change Team. For more about Ismael, his life and his world view, visit him online at http://lifeinafrica.com/4/lubingaismael

loans.use: Buying washing machine

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
A. Grace is an active member of Life in Africa working as a bracelet maker in the invisible children bracelet project. She lives with her husband and child in the IDP camp know as the Acholi quarters. Her husband works as a carpenter.

They, like so many other families, had to flee their home in Gulu because of the war. They find life in the camp difficult. They are able to earn enough for the basic needs but they know that they would be much better off if they could eliminate the rent which is one of the biggest expenses.

They have acquired a plot of land from the king of Buganda who donated free land to the Acholi. Here A. and her husband plan to build a two roomed house and, once it is done, this will free up a good part of their income to be used for other purposes such as food and helping their relatives. The husband is a carpenter and is able to mobilize his colleagues to help in the construction thereby saving the labor costs.

For this project she is seeking a loan in the amount of 700,000/= that she will repay in 12 months at a rate of 58,333/= per month.

Below is her break down:

-99 poles both for the wall and the roof @ 2000 each = 198,000/=

-18 iron sheets ‘gauge 23’ @ 10,000/ = 180,000/=

-4 bags of cement @ 72,000/=

-water to be used in the construction =30,000/=

-transport =30,000/=

-sand 1 trip= 50,000/=

-2 wooden doors @ 50,000 =100000/=

-2 woodenwindows @ 20,000/= 40,000/=

Total=700,000/=

Grace's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her peers at the Life in Africa WE Center community in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Life in Africa's Adult Education program. For more about Grace, her life and her worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/graceA.

loans.use: Family house

It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!
Grace has completed her loan, congratulations Grace for finishing your loan repayment.

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred T. is an active member of Life in Africa. He has proved himself to be a very hard worker as a sander and bracelet maker for the Invisible Children Bracelet project.

Fred is a father of four children. It is very expensive raising children and providing them with school fees, food, medical care and housing. He manages but knows that there are ways he could improve their standard of living.

When his father died, Fred inherited three, two room houses in Makindye which is a suburb of Kampala. His family currently lives in one of the houses and he rents out the other two. But the houses are only partly finished and so he can only charge a small rent. If the houses were properly finished, he could rent them for more money and this extra money would enable his family to live an easier life. It would also provide better housing for his tenants.

For the reasons above, he requests a loan in the amount of 700,000/=. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months. He will be paying 70,000/= per month.

He will use the loan as below:

Cement 10 bags each bag at 19,000/=............................190,000/=

Sand 2 trips each at80,000/=...................................160,000/=

Doors 3 each at 60,000/=...................................... 180,000/=

Windows 3 each at 40,000/=.....................................120,000/=

Labour..........................................................50,000/=

Total..........................................................700,000/=

Fred's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by his community of peers at the Life in Africa WE Center in Kampala. He has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest he will pay on this loan to support the Community Guaranteed Lending Team at Life in Africa. For more about Fred, his life and his worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/fredT.

loans.use: Buying Materials to complete house

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website, but the current state of the payment records is discouraging. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!
Fred's loan has been cleared through his saving which he was having with Life in Africa. So this is his final loan repayment.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is an active member of Life in Africa. She joined in November of 2005 and currently works as a wire sorter for the Invisible Children Bracelet project. She is one of the younger members being only 20 years old. She is an orphan. Her parents died when she was only 8 leaving her and her two brothers alone.

They were taken in by an aunt but life was very hard. The aunt, who was a widow herself, was taking care of many children and the grandmother who is blind. With very little money, food was often scarce and the only schooling Monica could afford was a tailor course. She did manage to get a job but could not earn enough money to exist on. Then she came to LiA. She now earns enough to help with food, rent, school fees for her brothers and support for her grandmother.

With encouragement from her determined aunt, she is learning to be independent and to forget that she is an orphan. She has managed to save enough to set up a small shop. Her cousin runs the shop during the day while Monica works. Now she would like to do more. If she adds more stock to the shop, her profits will increase. She also plans to use her tailoring skills by purchasing a sewing machine. Since her shop has a big veranda, she will put this sewing machine there and use on the weekends to earn money. For this project she is seeking a loan of 800,000/=. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months at a rate of 66,667/= per month.

Below is her budget:

  1. A sewing machine @ …………. 250, 000/=
  2. adding stock:
  • 100kgs of rice @ 900/= ………………90,000/=
  • 50kgs of sugar ……………………70,000/=
  • 20 liters of cooking oil…………….40, 000/=
  • 100kgs of maize flour @ 600/=……60,000/=
  • 60kgs of beans @ 1,000/=………….60,000/=
  • 50kgs of groundnuts @ 2,000/=…….100,000/=
  • 50kgs of Simsim @ 1,500/= …………75,000/=
  • 1 box of washing soap ………………...25,000/=
  • Transport ………………………………30,000/=

The total is 800,000/=

Monica's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her peers at the Life in Africa WE Center community in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Life in Africa's Internet4Change team. For more about Monica, her life and her worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/atimmonica

loans.use: Retail shop and tailoring

This is Monica's last payments. Congratulations Monica  for finishing your loan

loans.name: Grace Filda

texts.en:
Grace is an active member of Life in Africa. She joined through the Acholi Quarter Satelite Center. She moved to Kampala from the Gulu in the North to escape the war but she does not live in the quarters. However, she went there each day to work in the rock quarry. This was very hard on her since she had no money for transport and this forced her to walk 3 kms each way. She earned barely enough money to survive on but she had no choice since the survival of her family depended on what she could earn. Many days they had no food and they lived under the constant threat from the landlord of being thrown out of their home.

Grace's move to Kampala also has another reason. While still in the North, Grace and her husband had divorced and she was left with her eight children to fend for themselves.

Life in Africa has given Grace and her family new hope. The association with others and the sharing of knowledge and skills has given Grace the idea and desire to start a business. School fees for eight children is almost impossible and she worries, especially about the older girls. Her plan is to open a maize flour shop near her home. She has a 25 year old daughter who will work the shop. I talked to the daughter is she is very excited. It will not only give her work to do but she is happy that she will be earning money to help her mother and perhaps help pay school fees for her siblings. For this project Grace is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is her budget in full:

1- Maize 10 bags @ 50,000/= --------------------- 500,000/=

2- Grinding 10 bags @ 6,000/= --------- 60,000/=

3 - Rent for 3 months @ 50,000/= --------- 150,000/=

4- Transport --------------------------------------- 90,000/=

TOTAL -------------------------------- 800,000/=

Grace plans that with all she will save, she can send all her children back to school.

Grace's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her community of peers at the Life in Africa WE Center in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Educational opportunities for LiA member children. For more about Grace, her life and her worldview visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/gracefA.

loans.use: Buying and grinding the maize

With the problems that  Filder Grace went through, ( when she could not buy more products because there was almost no stock due to the Sudanese repatriation and were buying everything that they could to help them resettle back home) she was not able to finish her loans by herself. So life in Africa has paid it up for her. This will be settled from within.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
L. Irene is an active member of Life in Africa working in the invisible Bracelet project as a bracelet maker. Before coming to LIA, she earned her living working in the stone quarry near the Acholi quarters.

She was forced to flee Northern Uganda because of the war and, as most displaced Acholi, she settled in the displaced persons camp. Life there is very hard and basic needs are hard to come by. One such need is water. There are few tap water supplies and this makes it very expensive for the people to get water and they have to walk very far.

Her plan is to install a water tap in the part of the quarter where she lives. She will be able to provide the water at a less expensive rate and it will also benefit the community by shortening the distance they have to travel to get water. There has recently been another installation of a successful water tap but the quarters are very large and one tap will not fill the needs of so many people. This will give her a strong customer base and make it a profitable business venture. For this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000/=. She will be able to repay the loan in 12 months at a rate of 66,667/= per month. Once cash is at hand, the whole processes to have tap water is only one to two weeks.

Below is her break down:

35 pieces of metallic pipes @ 10,000 =350,000/=

Labor charges ……………………… 300,000/=

Construction of shelter against wastages….100,000/=

Charges from national water authority ……30,000/=

Transport……………………………………10,000/=

Other ……………………………………….10,000/=

The total amount is 800,000/=

Irene's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her peers at the Life in Africa WE Center community in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Life in Africa's talent discovery team. For more about Irene, her life and her worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/labongirene

loans.use: community water installation

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!
Irene has completed paying back her loan, sorry for any inconvenience caused by not posting her last payment earlier.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
L. Mary is an active member of Life in Africa. She works as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet Project. Here she earns enough to support herself and her children.

She is Acholi and was born in Northern Uganda. Eight years ago she was forced to flee the brutal war in the north and since then she has been living in the camp known as the Acholi quarters in Kampala. Here she lives in a small rented house. However, she has acquired a plot of land which was donated by the King of Buganda because of his sympathies for the Acholi. She now wishes to apply for a loan in order to build a two roomed house for her family. Growing up during 20 years of war and living eight years in a camp have made having a permanent safe home a priority. For this she is asking for 600,000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Poles for the wall 120 @ 2000/ = 240000shs

Iron sheets 12 @ 10000 = 120000shs

Roofing timbers 15 @ 5000 = 75000shs

Nails 10kgs @ 2000 = 20000shs

Labor = 120000shs

Total = 575000shs

Mary's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her peers at the Life in Africa WE Center community in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Life in Africa's Talent Discovery team. For more about Mary, her life and her worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/lalammary

loans.use: Building Family House
