loans.name: Adrine

texts.en:
K. Adrine is an active member of life in Africa. She is a single mother of two children. She was deserted by her husband and left to make a life the best she could. Being poor and a single mother is very difficult but she works hard in spite of the challenges to provide for her children and give them the education she never had.

She works for Invisible Children Crew as a bracelet maker. This helps her provide for the basics at home and even pay school fees for her children. Her son will be joining Kyambogo University this coming year. The greatest challenge she has, is having no house in the village. She had to leave her children in the village with her family while she came to Kampala to earn money. When she goes to the village to visit them, she has to share a room with her brothers. It is not easy to get one family to share their home with another family when they are already crowded. In Kampala she is only able to rent one small room for herself and she dreams of the day when she will be reunited with her children.

Her plan is to build a house in the village where her children will live comfortably and where she will stay on her visits. Her son and her brother will supervise the construction for her. She owns two cows which she plans to sell. They are worth 900,000/=. In addition to this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000/= to complete the project. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months. Her payment will be 50,000/= per month.

Below is her budget:

Bricks 3000 @ shs. 60...........................................180,000/=

Cement 15 bags @ shs. 18,000................................... 270,000/=

Sand 2 trips @ shs. 60,000..................................... 120,000/=

Timber, nails and iron sheets.................................. 303,000/=

Shutters....................................................... 200,000/=

Transport....................................................... 70,000/=

Labour..........................................................200,000/=

Total.........................................................1,343,000/=

Adrine's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her peers at the Life in Africa WE Center community in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Life in Africa's craft product development team. For more about Adrine, her life and her worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/adrinekyalisima

loans.name: Evalyn

texts.en:
kwero Evalyn has been an active member of Life in Africa since 2005. She is employed as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. She has three children and she lives in the Acholi quarter which is a camp for displaced persons from the north.

She and her family were forced to flee their home in the north because of the war. They settled in the camp as did most Acholis who fled to Kampala and she earned what little money she could by selling bananas. She would tie her baby on her back, carry a basket of bananas on her head, and she would walk all day trying to sell enough to make ends meet. She barely earned enough to pay the rent and feed them so school was just not possible. Since coming to LiA, their lives have greatly improved. Now she has no problem paying the rent, her children are not hungry and they even go to school.

The King of Buganda has great sympathy for the Acholi and has donated land to them. She has acquired a plot of this land and she now wishes to build a two roomed house for her family that will be permanent and safe. For this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 600,000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

below is her break down:

3000 bricks @ 45shs = 135000/=

10 bags of cement @ 18000shs = 180000/=

15 pieces of iron sheets @ 10000shs 150000/=

16 pieces of poles @ 1000shs = 16000/=

Labour =100000/=

Nails 5 kgs @ 150 = 7500/=

Total = 588500/=

Evalyn's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by her peers at the Life in Africa WE Center community in Kampala. She has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest on her loan to support Life in Africa's Talent Discovery team. For more about Evalyn, her life and her worldview, visit http://lifeinafrica.com/4/akweroevalyn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying a new motorbike

loans.name: Sokhim

texts.en:
C. Sokhim is one of CREDIT oldest clients. She is cooking and selling food in her neighborhood for quite a long time. She is living with her husband, her mother and four children in a house she ameliorated with her previous loans. “My living standards have been improving steadily since I borrowed for the first time with CREDIT”, she said. “I was never late in my repayments, because I want to deserve CREDIT’s trust in me.

 

C. Sokhim used to borrow small amount in Riel, Cambodia national currency, but this time she is requesting $700.

 

As she heard that a new factory was going to be opened in her village, her plan is to build a house to rent decent rooms to the workers, who will come from the provinces to work in this factory. This is a big investment but Sokhim is planning to go step by step: this first loan will be used to prepare the land before having the house built. Eventually, she is expecting a good income for her family.

loans.use: Build a house to rent rooms

loans.name: Toncho Petrov

texts.en: Toncho graduated from the local technical college in Sliven, Bulgaria, with the U.S.-equivalent of an associate's degree in electrical repair in the mid-1980s.  He began work at a large, state-run electrical repair shop until the fall of communism in 1989.  Like many Bulgarians, he soon found himself out of work.  In early 1991, he struck out on his own and started his own electrical repair shop.  He sells spare parts and fixes a broad range of electrical devices, usually TVs, VCRs, and radios, although he sees the occasional kitchen appliance.   Toncho also sells a small selection of new and used appliances, and this loan will help him expand that part of the business.  The loan proceeds will be used to expand his shop to include a separate showroom and increase his inventory.  The Chinese industrial revolution has had a dramatic impact on the sales of low-end electrical appliances in Bulgaria, as their costs have dropped to the point where an increasing number of Bulgarians can afford them.  While DVD players remain rare (a $100 player is 2 weeks salary for most here) many families are using small credit programs to finally replace 20-year old appliances.  We think Toncho is well-positioned to address this growing market in Sliven.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Ivan Kirilov

texts.en: In 1989, after the fall of communism in Bulgaria, Ivan began to drive a taxi.  He initially began working for another company, although several years ago was able to put together enough money for his own car and strike out on his own.  He now is a member of a cab co-op, which allows Ivan to work for himself, while having the infrastructure he would enjoy working for a larger company; the co-op provides its members with centralized dispatch, discounted repair and maintenance, and other services.   He is in need, however, at this point of a new car.  He has found a used Opel Astra for approx. $4,000, which fits his needs nicely.  This loan will fund half the cost, while he will be using his own cash for the remaining cost.  He has two children, one of whom is currently taking an auto mechanics course (which may come in handy at some point for dad…)   His wife is a seamstress and his daughter is still in school.  The S. family lives in Sliven, Bulgaria.

loans.use: Capital expenditure; the purchase of a new(er) taxi.

loans.name: Bahar Hasanova

texts.en: Bahar and his wife own a café in the Turkish quarter of Sliven, Bulgaria.  It is a modest spot, predominately offering drinks and simple foods, such as crepes, and a well-worn pool table.  The café seats up to 12 people.   In conjunction with the café, Bahar’s wife runs a business importing textiles from Turkey.  She makes the trip to Turkey monthly, bringing back predominately clothes, which she then sells in a corner of the café and a variety of local markets.  She typically makes the trip to Turkey on the night train with two of her three grown children for safety’s sake. The loan proceeds will fund two things: 1) working capital for the café and 2) inventory and transportation expenses for the clothing business.   As a historical aside, after the brutal Ottoman occupation of Bulgaria (15th century to late 19th century) the Turks who remained in Bulgaria for the most part either cloistered themselves or moved east to be again inside Ottoman lands.  10% of the Bulgarian population is of Turkish descent, and is often excluded from mainstream society due to their religion (Islam) and residual resentment many ethnic Bulgarians still feel against the Turks, nearly 150 years later.

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Fana Mihkalova

texts.en: Fana owns and runs a small grocery in one of the Roma neighborhoods in Sliven, Bulgaria.  She has had this small store for 15 years, and has built up enough of a capital base to enable her to extend credit to many of her customers in difficult times.  However, she has found herself with a surprising expense – a new refrigerator. Her current cooler has started to leak badly, and has become prohibitively expensive to operate, increasingly so as the summer approaches.  Unplugging it is not an option – yogurt is a staple of the Bulgarian diet, accounting for a significant amount of her sales year-round, and in the summer, ice cream sales become a major revenue contributor.   Fana’s daughter and husband work for her.  Her daughter typically works in the store while her husband focuses on sourcing inventory from the lowest-cost provider in the region.   Lenders interested in learning more about the Roma culture in Bulgaria might find “Bury Me Standing: The Gypsies and Their Journey” by Isabel Fonseca to be helpful.  The book was published in 1995 and is widely available.

loans.use: New refrigerator

loans.name: Kurte

texts.en:
Kurte is a vocalist from the Roma minority in Bulgaria.    He began his career with a local group, the Kitka Orchestra.  He then moved around, working with the Lulugi, Melodia and now the Kozar Orchestras.     

Kurte’s dream is to record his own solo album with the songs he has written.  This money is going to be used for the costs of producing his new album.  The costs include studio time, CD pressing and licensing for the covers he will record. 

Lenders interested in learning more about the Roma culture in Bulgaria might find “Bury Me Standing: The Gypsies and Their Journey” by Isabel Fonseca to be helpful.  The book was published in 1995 and is widely available.

loans.use: Album recording

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Instrument tuning, uniform

loans.name: Mihail

texts.en: Mihail had been a soccer player in Bulgaria for 10 years, before, in his own words, “things started to fall apart.”  For the past several years, he has been playing the drums in several bands in Sliven, performing at weddings and other celebrations.  While he has no formal music education, his entire family was comprised of musicians growing up, and it seems as second nature to him.  He is 30 years old and has two kids.  When not playing music or touring, Mihail and his wife operate a hamburger-like stand in the Roma section of town.   Every summer for the past several years, Mihail and his wife have gone to the Black Sea coast for work.  Last summer, Mihail began to play with “Southern Nights” orchestra in Sunny Beach.  While Mihail plays, his wife does hair braiding and styling on the street for tourists.    This loan will be used to finance the upfront costs for this summer’s work; travel expenses, instrument tuning and the purchase of this year’s uniform.  The loan duration is 1 year, although we expect the preponderance of the loan to be repaid in a shorter time frame.   Lenders interested in learning more about the Roma culture in Bulgaria might find “Bury Me Standing: The Gypsies and Their Journey” by Isabel Fonseca to be helpful.  The book was published in 1995 and is widely available.

loans.use: Instrument repair and uniform

loans.name: Metodi

texts.en: Metodi is a 54-year old piano player living in Sliven, Bulgaria.  He is a member of the Roma minority, and works as a keyboardist in a Roma band.  He began playing music as a child, tapping anything that would make a good percussion beat.  He attended a government-run music high school in on the west coast of Bulgaria in Burgas and then in a military academy in Plovdiv, where his training focused on classical music.  He began working in the Bulgarian Army Band where he played the accordion and other instruments as needed.   Since the massive military cuts of the post-Cold War era, Metodi looks for work feverishly, both as a solo performer and in a group.  Last summer, Metodi began to play with “Southern Nights” orchestra in Sunny Beach.    Sunny Beach is a new tourist destination for western Europeans on the Bulgarian Black Sea coast.  This loan will be used to finance the upfront costs for this summer’s work; travel expenses, instrument tuning and the purchase of this year’s uniform.  The loan duration is 1 year, although we expect the preponderance of the loan to be repaid in a shorter time frame.   Lenders interested in learning more about the Roma culture in Bulgaria might find “Bury Me Standing: The Gypsies and Their Journey” by Isabel Fonseca to be helpful.  The book was published in 1995 and is widely available.

loans.use: Instrument repair, uniform

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en: Alexander is a musical jack-of-all-trades.  Having studied at an institution in Bulgaria, Musical Academy “Tschakovsky” in Sofia, he plays all sorts of wind instruments – Trombone, Clarinet, Trumpet, etc. – as the situation requires, in addition to the piano and accordion.    Upon graduating, he worked as an Army musician for 28 years.  Once he reached the mandatory retirement age, Alexander joined the Karandila Orchestra, a Roma group based in Sliven, Bulgaria, which plays weddings and tours as often as they can.  One of the most unfortunate aspects of the transition from communism to capitalism is the lack of savings of the eldery, coupled with the low support from the state.  For those currently in the 65-85 age bracket, their entire working years was during communism.  During that time there was little money to be saved, but there was little perceived need; the government would take care of them.  As that paradigm has shifted dramatically, many of those who have "retired" have returned to the workforce to supplement the $50 the government gives them monthly.           This loan will be used to finance the upfront costs for this summer’s work; travel expenses, instrument tuning and the purchase of this year’s uniform.  The loan duration is 1 year, although we expect the preponderance of the loan to be repaid in a shorter time frame.   Lenders interested in learning more about the Roma culture in Bulgaria might find “Bury Me Standing: The Gypsies and Their Journey” by Isabel Fonseca to be helpful.  The book was published in 1995 and is widely available.

loans.use: Instrument tuning, uniform

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: I am 26 years old, married with three children. I have been selling vegetables in Mukuyu Market for the last four years. As i worked, i faced different challeges in raising enough money to support my family. Also, the little that i saved, it could not last long.I joined a women group which assisted me to save some money with it, which later would be lent to some one. I have used three small loans from this group, the first one was USD.60, then,USD 165 and USD 225. I paid all these loans promptly and i hope to get another to push me forward. I have been able to send my children to school and look forward to a better life.

loans.use: She wants to include a variety of vegetables and rice to her current stock.Currenly she sells tomatoes,spinnach and onions,thus she hopes if she adds others and rice,she will be able to tap more customers who bypass her stall because of not having these food stuffs.

loans.name: Purity

texts.en: <font size="2">I am a young lady aged 26, married with two children. My business is at Mukuyu market in Muranga District, Kenya. I have been in this business for over four years and for all this time it has been growing steadily. My current stock is about USD.325 and need to be boosted to increase the rate of return. By stocking new clothes, i will be in a position of pulling more customers because of having a variety which ar</font><font size="2">e of high quality and </font><font size="2">pocket friendly. I have been using loans from the group but because of not being enough to cover all members, i have opted this funding. I had an opportunity of using three loans and paid them back. </font>

loans.use: I would like to stock new clothes. I have been selling used clothes but of recent my clients are requesting for new clothes.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 47 years married with six children.  She is a nutritionist in the village where she lives.  She educates other members within the community of the importance of growing and eating vegetables for a healthy living.

 She started her business in 2003, grows and sells vegetables. Her main customers come from Muranga town who sell the vegetables as far as the city Nairobi. She is assured of the market because of the high quality of her vegetables. She has been receiving loans from the group but the group is unable to handle the demand because of her demand for a bigger loan.

loans.use: The loan applied for will be used to buy pesticides as well as fertilizers to get a high yield on a small piece of land.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
I am 42 years old, married with three children. I am the treasurer of a self help group called Konguini Thayu Women Group. Our major activity is savings and credit done by all members of the group.I have been the treasurer of this group since 2003.

I started my business in 1998 and have been able to construct a small shop and bought a dairy cow. Having a big space and on a strategic position at the centre of town coupled with the demand for soft drinks in this part of town, i believe it will be a good venture. This will bring in more income which wilgive me the opportunity to give my children better education and improve my standard of living.

loans.use: I would like to start selling sodas.I have been selling other packed juices but of recent i acquired a big space and the number of clients for sodas have been increasing day by day.This money will help me buy fifty crates of sodas which i anticipate to sell in about two weeks.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
I have been a chairperson for a self help group called Kaganda Magdalene Mothers for three years. I am married and have five children.

I started my business in 1987 and it is always improving. I sell a variety of household commodities at Kaganda shopping centre in Muranga, Kenya. I have been able to look after my family as well as educating my children.

Also, i have been able to repay four small loans which I received from my group.

loans.use: The money am requesting for will be used to buy more stock such as sugar, wheat flour, household commondities which are used frequently. The demand for household commodities keep changing and this calls for one to keep monitoring the market in order to  stock what is highly demanded by customers.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
I have been a secretary of Konguini Thayu Women Group for the last three years. Prior to joining the group I could not take minutes but now I have been empowered and been able to take the minutes for the group and come-up with an Agenda. I am married and have three children

I have been selling cereals as a business in a small town called Mukuyu in Central Kenya. The business has been progressing very well and the profits I get I have been able to venture into buying and selling sand and stones for building.

loans.use: I have been selling maize and beans and I want to increase stock and also sell other cerals like millet, rice, sorgham and groundnuts

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
I am married with three children and am the Chairlady of Konguini Thayu Women group. When I joined the group I did not realise that I have leadership qualities. I have managed to improve the groups activities and empowering other members of the group.

I run a restaurant and sell produce in Embu Central Market in Kenya.  I have been in this business for more than 20 years and it has enabled me educate my children and my last born in Secondary school.  My first loan was Usd.300 and the 2nd one wasUsd.600. All loans were paid promptly because of good profits from my business.

loans.use: To renovate the restaurant and increase my stock in cereals i.e. Maize, beans, millet, groundnuts and rice

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
I am 46 years old and an active member of Konguini Thayu Women Group and my activity in the group is rules controller which I have held since the group was formed in 2003.  Prior to joining the group I did not know that I can enforce group rules and regulations. 

I  sell my rice in diffrent parts of Central Kenya that is in Kagio, Kangari Karatina and Embu.  I buy as a wholesaler and sell to other retailers who inturn sell to small towns and individual customers.  The group revolving fund is not swift enough to cater for all members at the same time and this calls for external funding to cover the gap.  The business currently needs support to maintain the level of stock so that I do not dissapoint my customers because the demand is very high.

loans.use: To increase my stock of Rice to meet the demand of my customers.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
I am 50 years old and married with four children and a member of the Loans committee in charge of appraising members for group loans in Kongoini Thayu Women Group

 I have been running this business with my husband since 1970.  In addition to the business,we have a dairy cow which produces 15 litres of milk per milking and this supplements our income and also been able to feed my family with the milk at the same time selling to the milk vendors.  My first loan was Usd.300 and the second one was the same and I managed to pay promptly

loans.use: Business is very good during the month of June and July because the farmers will be receiving mini bonus for tea and I would like to increase the stock before then

loans.name: Denis

texts.en:
Denis T. is married with five children and taking care of three Orphans who live with them in their family.
He started his business by selling firewood.  He did very well in this business.
 
In 2002 he got a loan from WITEP worth $ 200 and he changed the business to selling of used cloths.
 
He got enough money and he has started a new business of selling New Cloths.
Given a loan of $ 900, he plans to expand his business by stocking New Cloths for Gents, Ladies, Children and Girls / Boys.
 
This business will fetch him enough money for refunding the loan money, meeting the basic needs of the family.
This man is of integrity and he is capable of refunding the loan money.

loans.use: Purchasing stocks of new cloths for gents, ladies, children and girls / boys

payments.comment:
This business has made the first payment of loan refund with money worth $50.
The profit is being realized in every day today sales because of the high stock that was put in place with the loan money.More Journal about this business will come soon.
Janet.

loans.name: Ochomi

texts.en:
Ochomi N. is married with eight children.
 
He started a small business of retail shop in the village.  The business grew steadily and the stock expanded after getting a loan of $ 200 from WITEP.
 
He now wants to expand the business to meet the high demand from customers in the strategic place in village.
 
It is 15 kilometers to reach the main town of Mbale.  So people of the community refer buying essential commodities from him than going to town.
 
Given a loan of $800, he plans to expand the business to meet the stock.
 
He is man of integrity and respect who will be in position to refund the money.

loans.use: Expanding business stock

payments.comment:
This business has started very well with profit coming on every day sales.
They have put in the first payment of $50 as the first installment.
More about this business will come soon in the journal.
Janet.

loans.name: Omutia

texts.en:
Omutia M. is a married woman with nine children. She has done charcoal business for five years now.
 
She started by buying one sack and then sell it in a small groups of bundles put together at 500 shillings Uganda money.
 
She got a loan of $200 from WITEP  that enabled her to increase her stock to ten bags now.
 
Uganda is a rainy forest country where by charcoal is the major fuel for cooking both in towns and villages.
 
The demand of charcoal is very high during this period when there is too much rain. Given a loan of $800, she plans to increase the stock by hiring a lorry then can buy up to 80 sacks of charcoal.
 
This will fetch her enough money to pay for the loan money and take care of her family.
 
She is a respected woman in the community.

loans.use: Increase stock of charcoal

payments.comment:
This business is showing postive attitude in their sales because of the increased stock of about 320 bags of Chacoal.
Because of the good profit coming in, they have managed to put the first installment of loan payment of $50.
We will keep you posted on every progress this business will make.
Jane.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is married woman with a five children.  This is a business oriented woman who believes in achieving her goals.
 
She started by selling produce e.g. Maize, Millet, Sorghum, Rice, Groundnuts, Pease from WITEP worth $200 that helped her to increase her stock.
 
Given a loan   of $1,000, she plans to expand her business by opening up a store in Mbale Town in order meet the middle man with her produce.  She will increase the quantity and quality of each item that, she sells.
 
This is a woman of high dignity who is able to refund the loan money without any problem.

loans.use: Increasing the stock of produce, opening a store in Mbale Town.

payments.comment:
Grace received the loan money with great joy and this time she is again very happy to refund the loan money.
Her business is doing well with profit coming in.
She has payed money worth $50.
More about this business will come soon in the Journal.
Janet.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon started by selling of chicken in the market. After doing this business for two years, he got some more money to venture into more paying business.  He started selling goats in the village markets.
 
He got a loan money of $200 and this expanded his business to selling cows in the local markets around.
 
He can now afford to buy up to 3 bulls of 300,000 shillings each.
Given a loan of $1000, he plans to expand his business by buying up to 15 Bulls that can fetch him enough profit to meet his basic needs and pay the loan money.
 
Uganda being a rainy country, cows have enough grass to feed on freely.
 
Simon is a respected a man in the community who is able to refund the loan money.

loans.use: Buying livestock

payments.comment:
This business has started realizing profit after increasing the stock on their weekly sales.
Today they have payed a loan refund of $50.
Will keep you informed on more about this business in the next journal.
Janet.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en: Wilson Hernandez is a 41-year-old native of Guayaquil who is married and has 3 children. He owns his home and rents a location for his business where he sells, repairs and refurbishes furniture. He sells all types of items, including popular outdoor pieces made with wood perfect for beach conditions. His business is located near his home in a popular business sector. He opens from 8:30 AM to 6:30 PM and counts on the help of one employee and his oldest daughter. He is in need of $575 dollars in order to buy materials (such as wood and paint) necessary for the production and refurbishment of new items.

loans.use: Furniture sales and repairs

payments.comment: Paga la ultima cuota de su microcredito.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa C. is a 47 year old single mother of four children. Although only two of her children still live at home she has the responsibility of supporting one of them who is currently enrolled in a University. Her dream is to have her children attain college degrees and become professionals.

 

Her beauty salon has been established for over thirteen years. She has a dedicated group of clients but she is looking to expand her business in order to increase profits. She is interested in hiring another employee and offering new services. Therefore, she will use the capital in order to help her hire a new employee and buy products that will help her diversify her offerings.

loans.use: Hire new employee and expand product base

payments.comment: 4/12 Rosa paga su cuota correspondiente al mes de diciembre. esta bien con su negocio les manda saludos.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en: Carmen H. is a mother of 3 and is 42 years old. Although she lives in Duran, her dental office is located in Guayaquil. She has just a little less than 20 years of experience in the field and is interested in investing in new tools that will help her be more efficient and offer better service to her clients. She currently opens at 6 AM and works diligently until 8 PM. She seems to be very responsible and highly dedicated to her work.

loans.use: Dental tools

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase new tools and materials for car repair

loans.name: Boris

texts.en: Boris P. is a 39 year old computer technician in Guayaquil. At his shop he repairs computers with hardware and software issues and sells computer accessories. He also helps his clients get connected online and shows them how to use the power of the Internet to their advantage. This in itself is a valuable service to the community as he is helping to bridge the technology gap and break paradigms in computer literacy.  Currently he counts on the help of two employees who all help him run his shop from 8 AM until 10 PM. He intends to use the loan to add another employee, buy accessories in bulk and buy newer tools for computer repair.

loans.use: Buy computer accessories and tools for repair

loans.name: Ervin

texts.en: Ervin L. is 27 years old and has three children. He owns a small location where he sells ceviche, a common Ecuadorian dish made with seafood, lime, onions and tomatoes. He is near a very popular market that creates high traffic around his area and helps him sell. He has an assistant who helps him along with the mother of his children. He is in need of a loan in order to buy more seafood so that he can meet the increasing demand he is experiencing. He is also eager to add chairs and tables for his clients in order to create a more inviting dining environment.

loans.use: Buy tables and chairs for seafood restaurant

payments.comment: El cliente pago el 10 de Agosto, fecha que vence su crédito, se contabilizo el 10 de Julio .

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en: Lourdes R. is a 46 year old mother of five, although she now only has the responsibility of her 11 year old daughter. She owns a small restaurant that serves breakfast and dinner mainly to her loyal customers who are workers in the area. She opens at 6 AM and closes at 4 PM. She is in need of this loan in order to buy food in bulk and make some minor improvements to her location.

loans.use: Buy food in bulk; make improvements on restaurant

payments.comment: Paga 2 cuotas el credito se le otorgo en mayo 17

Lourdes, agradece a  todos los prestamistas por el dinero recibido y pago su crédito a tiempo conforme el contrato de  crédito acordado. 
El préstamo le fue de mucha ayuda le ayudo a poner su negocio en un mejor nivel de atención. los ingresos generados fueron  de mucha ayuda para atender los estudios de sus hija en el colegio.

Espera realizar otra operación para continuar con el negocio  y seguir cosechando logros

loans.name: María

texts.en: Maria C. is 41 years old, is married and has 3 children. She owns a business where members of the community make long distance and local phone calls. This is a valuable service in her area because many people cannot afford to have their own phone lines in their home. Recently the city made her move back part of her business in order to abide by local regulations. She is in need of a loan in order to repair the floor that was damaged in order to comply with the local government. The current condition is having a significantly negative effect on her business.

loans.use: Repair floor

loans.name: Oswaldo

texts.en: Oswaldo C. is 33 years old, has three children and owns a restaurant that he opened about a year ago. He is encouraged by the progress and popularity of his venture and is seeking to invest in improvements to the location and to take advantage of buying food in bulk. The restaurant is conveniently located on a main street where he gets plenty of attention and business. He works from 8:00 AM until 10:00 PM.

loans.use: Buy food products in bulk

payments.comment:
Cancelo la 2da cuota a tiempo, en la primera cuota se realizó un seguimiento por que se atraso en el pago se realizo una nueva inducción del manejo de crédito para hacerle ver la responsabilidad de manejar un negocio y ser cumplido con las operaciones financieras.

Luis

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa P. has two children and is 35 years old. She owns a store in 
Guayaquil where she sells food in large amounts like rice, corn and sugar. The business is located in her parents home which is conveniently located on a main street. She is seeking to diversify her product offerings and buy in larger quantities for her clients. She also sells women’s clothing and perfume as a side job in order to bring in extra income for her home. She will use the loan primarily for her store in order to increase her inventory and boost sales.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en: Edgar P., originally from Riobamba, Ecuador, is a 39 year old salesman with two children, eight and five years old. Mr. P. is a homeowner. His business is located in a section of Guayaquil called Bastión Popular, and it has been in operation for seven years. His wife helps him with sales and administrative work from 6:00 am until 6:00 pm. Edgar is in charge of managing some customers’ weekly credit tabs, although most customers pay cash for his goods on the spot. He needs this loan money to be able to buy other products like watches, lamps, bed sheets, and other home items. Mr. P. thinks this loan will also help financially because he can receive a discount from wholesalers if he buys in bulk and pays in cash. Lastly, Edgar wants lenders to know that he is a hard-working entrepreneur.

loans.use: Buy more inventory and diversify supply

loans.name: Felipe

texts.en: Felipe Guterrez is a 45 year-old businessman from Manabi, Ecuador with one son. Mr. G. is a homeowner who runs a seafood restaurant in the busy market called Municipal de Bastión Popular. His clientele is mainly locals from the neighborhood. With 11 years of experience at this particular business, he and his wife who also helps run the operation work from 6:00 am until 1:00 pm. Mr. G. needs this loan to be able to buy more seafood and a display case to show off the meals of the day. Don Felipe is a persevering self-starter who loves managing his small seafood restaurant.

loans.use: Purchase display case to show food to street traffic

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana F., who was born in Quevado, Ecuador, is a 22 year-old single woman who resides with her parents. She runs a small gift shop in the Municipal de Bastión Popular that is known for its selection of perfumes. She has been in business for 5 years. Every morning from 6:00 am until 2:00 pm Diana and her mother operate their shop. Ms. F. wants this loan to buy more products and diversify her stock. This hard-working young woman not only runs this business; she is wrapping up her studies at the University in Business Administration.

loans.use: Diversify supply of perfume

loans.name: Cesar

texts.en:
Cesar P., who was born in Chimborazo, a region in Ecuador known for its famous extinct volcano. Mr. P. is married with one son, he is a homeowner, and his forte is preparing a delicious South American soup called encebollado. His restaurant is located on one of Guayaqil’s major avenues and has been serving up Don P.’s famous recipe soup for 8 years. Before starting his own business, Cesar worked at a restaurant for 12 years. When he thought he was ready to open his own business, he used what little savings he had and rented a small storefront along a well-positioned thoroughfare in downtown Guayquil. He and his wife work hard every day from 6:00 am until 1:00 pm, and they are requesting $1035.00 to be able to buy key ingredients in bulk. For instance: oil, dressing, cola, etc… He also would like to buy some uniform utensils and dishes to serve up encebollado.

 

For more information about the history and culture of Riobamba, the largest city in the province of Chimborazo, read here.

loans.use: Ingredients for encebollado and dishes

payments.comment: Cesar Pilco cancelo sus cuota con 2 días de atraso, las causas que ocasionaron el atraso según manifestó fue por que tubo un accidente y las circunstancias no fueron favorables par realizar el pago.
Cesar Pilco cancelo sus cuota con 2 días de atraso, las causas que ocasionaron el atraso según manifestó fue por que tubo un accidente y las circunstancias no fueron favorables par realizar el pago.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is an active member Kabuta Ladies in Action a group she joined in 2001. She is married with 2 children who go to primary and secondary School.

She started her business with her husband in 2001. The business has grown over the years to be the best in Muranga Town and this has led to the opening of another outlet on another street. On average the butchery sells 100kgs per day and at every end of month the demand is so high and this calls for attention.

loans.use: Inorder to match with the demand every end of month,she want to increase the number of cows slaughtered from the current 4 to 6

loans.name: Salydia

texts.en:
Salydia has been a good member of the group since it was started in 2001. She is a single mother aged 44 years with one child who is in college.

She started by selling maize and beans in Sagana market in 1990. In 1998, she realized that people wanted meat but it was not enough in the market. She started rearing cows and goats for sale. In 2001, she borrowed USD.150 bought goats which she later sold and paid the loan back. The small profit she earned was used to pay her child’s school fees and home upkeep

loans.use: She wants to pay school fees for her daughter because the business can't provide all the money required at once.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is the chairlady of Kabuta Ladies in action a post she has held since 2001. She is also a treasurer of her local church in Kabuta and a retired Primary school teacher.

She has been in this business for over 20 years and this gives her confidence in soliciting for more funding because she is sure and understands market trends.  The group manages a revolving fund and she has been able to pay back two loans of USD 300. Her produce is sold in muranga town as well as to middle men who take it to Nairobi because of the cheap railway transport.

loans.use: She intends to increase the purchases such that she can directly sell to Nairobi because she will earn more than what the middle men give.

loans.name: Felicina

texts.en:
Felicina is an active member both in group and her church where she is a prayer leader. She is married with nine children, four are working while other four are in college and one in secondary school.

She has been in business for more than twenty five years. She has a stall at Githma market. She has been able to educated her four children who are already working but the conditions have changed and for the business to keep running normarlly, some funding is needed.

loans.use: She wants to buy a dairy cow because there is ready market for milk in Githima.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a widow with four children all in Primary school. She is hard working and very active in group activities.

With the husband they started with two rooms in 2004 and in June 2005 they added two more to be four all together. She gets USD.88 every month and in addition she sells bananas, maize and vegetables.

loans.use: She wants to construct another room because there is enough space and demand for rental rooms in Nairobi.

loans.name: Benedette

texts.en:
W. is the chairlady of this group. She is a widow fortunately her last child is in college. She is also the treasurer of rural Electrification project in her area and a retired Primary school teacher.

She sells milk in Thika Town and Saba Saba town ship. She sells about 150 litres every day earning about USD.37 per day. She has created a big clientele in Thika because of being honest and maintaining the quality of her milk.

loans.use: She wants to buy another cow to increase milk which increases income aswell. Also, she says coffee brings in some income and thus will buy fertilizers to give high yield.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is married with three children and an active member of the group and her church. She is aged 30 years.

She has been selling handicraft and milk for one year and two years respectively. She sells 6.5 litres every day earning USD1.6 and the craft shop brings in about USD.55 per month. The business is growing day -by- day however, cash withdrawals affect it very much.

loans.use: She would like to use this loan for school fees. Monthly loan repayments will not affect her business but rather allow it to grow and build capacity to support her family financial requirements.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a good member of Kahumbu Kwirera Mothers and she has been a member since the group started in January 2005. She is married with three children who are still in primary school.

She sells milk and maize to clients in Kirigo tranding centre. The reason why she started selling maize is that; it is the staple food for the Kenyans and therefore at any time you are assured of making a sale. She borrowed a loan of USD.300 from the group and repaid it and it has pushed her to selling over 100 kgs in two days.

loans.use: She wants to buy another dairy cow to increase milk supply which will automatically increase her income.

loans.name: Robina

texts.en:
Robina is married with 4 children all of them in college. She is a Chairlady of a home cell in her church and a retired primary teacher.

She has a stall at Mizizi market where she sells vegetables while carrying on her teaching profession. She says she would not have managed to educate her children to university level had it not been the income from this small business. Her husband comes in once in a while when she needs help and this has helped her very much.

loans.use: She wants to buy a dairy cow to start selling milk because in her area there aren’t many people who sell milk yet the demand is so high. This will give her the opportunity to improve her diet and earn extra income.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is the Treasurer of Kahumbu Kwirera Mothers. She is a hard working lady, a widow with six children all working.
She sells milk from her two dairy cows and bananas. She sells ten litres of milk every day giving her USD.2.5. There is a ready market for milk in Maragua, as well as Thika, which calls for increase in supply.

loans.use: She intends to increase supply of milk by buying more litres from farmers and also buy a dairy cow to at least be assured of constant supply.

loans.name: Albert

texts.en:
Albert W. is a dedicated and talented young artist who joined Life in Africa in 2005. He was very excited to join since LiA offered him the opportunity to develop and use his artistic talent as well as to earn an income. He proved to be a fast learner and very quickly earned a job with the Invisible Children Bracelet project where he works as a sander.

This income is very important to him. He is just a young man but when his father died he was the oldest and it was up to him to take over the responsiblity for his mother and younger siblings. He tried at first to do this by selling his artwork. He quickly found that selling art is not like selling food or charcoal which are needed on a daily basis. Art is more of a luxury and this made their life very difficult. But he is determined to do right for his family and he came up with a plan.

His plan is to cash in on the high demand for decent housing by building three rooms to rent out. He and his brothers have worked very hard and have made 7000 bricks by hand that are now ready to be fired. He knows that once this project is complete the income will greatly improve their lives and will insure that there is sufficent money for school fees and medicine for his younger siblings. He is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 which will fire the bricks and build the house up to the beams. He will be able to repay this loan in 10 ,months.

His budget is as indicated below:

Burning Bricks --------- Ushs.150,000

Cement 10 bags --------- Ushs.190,000

Sand 2 trips --------- Ushs.160,000

 Concrete stones -------- Ushs.100,000

Tranport --------- Ushs. 60,000

Water --------- Ushs.20,000

 Labour --------- Ushs.100,000

Incidentals --------- Ushs. 20,000

Total --------- Uhs.800,000

He wants to repay this loan in 10 months and his expenses verses income is 100,000.

WE Team to Benefit: Internet4change

loans.use: Buying material for building setting up rental rooms.

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website, but the current state of the payment records is discouraging. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce K. joined Life in Africa in August of 2005. She is a very happy and dedicated member who loves what is happening at LiA and all the opportunities that are made available to people just like her. She is currently working in the Invisible Children Bracelet project creating bracelets and this has greatly improved the lives of her family by providing a steady source of income.

She has a large family and this means that the needs are also large. Her younger brother lives with her and together they have come up with a good plan to increase their income. Their plan is to purchase a motorcycle which her brother will operate as a a bodaboda (for hire). Transport is very needed in Kampala and bodaboda drivers can do quite well.

The money earned from this business will help the family but Joyce also realizes that as a young man, her brother also needs to have some money of his own. They have agreed that one day a week he will keep the money as his salary which will allow him to start saving for the time when he will have his own home and life. The family has already saved 500,000 towards this project. She is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to add to this to make the purchase. She will be able to repay this loan in 8 months.

She wants to pay this loan in a period of 8 months and her income verses expenses is Ushs.190,000

She saves Ushs. 50,000 per month and remains with Ushs. 140,000.

WE Team to Benefit: Internet4change

loans.use: Buying a Motorcyle for hire commonly known as boda-boda.

loans.name: Gilbert

texts.en:
Gilbert M. joined Life in Africa in 2005. He started as a volunteer working with visual images. His hard work and dedication has earned him a full time paid position as Visual Images Manager at the WE Center.

Gilbert has a passion for computers and he wishes to pursue a higher education majoring in computer studies. In order to accomplish this goal he has devised a plan to open a business.

This will give him the necessary funds to complete his education. The business he has chosen is a secretarial service.

He has already secured a space for this business and has one computer in place. The location of the space is near the University and services such as this are in high demand by the students which will offer a strong customer base to support the business. The services to be offered include photocopying , scanning , typing and printing , plus spiral and book binding. Eventually he is also going to venture into CD writng and music recording.

Gilbert has already saved Ushs.900,000 and he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to get the business up and running. To start this business, he is seeking a loan in the amount of Ushs.800,000. He will be able to repay this loan in 10 months.

Loan amount 800,000

Photocopier 1 - 1,000,000 - 1,000,000

Paper 10 reams @7000 ----------70,000

Files 10 @1500 ----------------15,000

Diskettes 10 pkts @5500--------55,000

Pens --------------------------10,000

Pencils------------------------10,000

Rulers--------------------------8,000

Empty video tapes------------- 32,000

Rent 4 months @90,000---------360,000

Labour 1 month @ 70,000 -------70,000

Transporting-------------------15,000

Empty CDs--------------------- 30,000

Black books--------------------15,000

Maintenance 1 month @10,000----10,000

Total ----------------------1,700,000

WE Team to benefit:

loans.use: Buying materials for setting up a secretarial bureau.

This amount was paid by Life in Africa after Gilbert failed to pay his loan in full. It has been very difficult for him to pay back his loan , so we  decided to settle this from within, after paying for him.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
M. Rebecca is a young woman full of hope for the future. She is an active member of Life in Africa and is employed in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. In addition she also participates in many of the other activities offered by LiA and her positive attitude affects all those she comes in contact with.

She also is very responsible and has a good and generous heart. She supports her brother financially as well as two Aids orphans. These children are currently staying with relatives and even with the money she sends, they live under very poor conditions. She really wants to be able to give them a better life and longs to earn enough to provide school fees so these children can be educated.

She has a sister living in Kampala who is not able to go to school herself. Together they plan to open a second hand clothes business. Rebecca has worked in this type of business before and knows that she can make a good income once she gets it going. Her sister will help by working this business while Rebecca continues on at LiA. The business will be located at Kisasi trading center but they also plan to ocassionally shift to other locations to increase their business. She is so determined in this plan that she has already saved 150,000 towards the start up. She is seeking a loan in the amount 500,000 to add to this. She will be able to repay this loan in 6 months.

Below is her break down.

Rent 4 months 200,000/

2 Shocks @ 150,000/ 300,000/

Transport 10,000/

Hungers 20 @ 2000 40,000/

K.C.C licence 20000/

Total 650,000/

WE Team to benefit: Advertising and Marketing

loans.use: Buying second hand clothes for sale

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Kyaziike Joan is a remarkable young woman. She is very responsible and dedicated even for her young years. She joined Life in Africa in November of 2005 and has been an active member being employed by the Invisible Children Bracelet project. She has just finished her secondary schooling and she now longs to go on to the University to complete her education.

She lives at home with her parents and she is the eldest of their four children. Her father's income in somewhat unsteady so she gladly helps financially using her salary. Her father wisely worked hard and built a two room house next to their family home. This is rented out and the income from this rental has paid the school fees for Joan so far. However, the University fees are much higher and they are looking at ways to increase their income to provide for this.

The plan is to add two more rooms to the existing house. This will double the amount of rent they will earn. Housing is in great demand in Kampala so they know they will have no problem finding tenants. The money from this rental will be used to pay the University fees for Joan's education and for her younger siblings who will follow her. She has carefully saved as much of her salary as she could and has 400,000 to put into this project. She is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to complete it. She will be able to repay this loan in 10 months.

Below is her break down.

1: 16 Iron sheets @------11000------------176,000/

2: 16 bags of cement @--------18500-------296,000/

3: 4000 bricks @--------------60----------240,000/

4:15 Pieces of timber for roofing 8(3x4)-3000-24,000/

7(4x2) -----5000------35,000/

5: 2 trips of sand @---------60000-------120,000/

6: 2 windows @ 10,000-------------------20,000/

7: 1 door ----------------------29,000/

8: Labuor ------------------------------200,000/

9: Transporting materials to the site-- 60,000/

Total ------------------------------1,200,000/

WE Team to benefit:Internet4change Team

loans.use: Buying materials to expand tenant's room

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!
Congratulations on finishing your loan Joan.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet N. has been an active member of Life in Africa since 2005. She started as a volunteer working in the arts and crafts center and then moved to a paying job working with the Invisible Children Bracelet project. She enjoys working on this project and at LiA because it offers the workers a way out of poverty. She is a single woman living on her own without the help of her family and her salary sustains her.

She has been fortunate to be able to live with friends who agreed to help her. Out of kindness toward her they have not charged her any rent. But she knows that this cannot continue since their own situation is very unstable. While she is very grateful for their kindness, she is now looking for a way to provide housing for herself as well as to add to her income. She has realized that housing is in great demand all the time in Kampala and she has decided to invest in property for herself and to rent out for income.

The first phase of this project will be to secure a plot of land. She has found the plot she wants and she has successfully negotiated a deal with the landowner. If she can come up with the money needed by the end of June he will sell her the property. Once she has paid for the land, she will then build a house on it to live in and also apartments that she will rent out. In this way she will be able to secure her future. To succeed at this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to add to the 2,200,000 that she has managed to save herself. She will be able to repay this loan in 10 months.

This is her budget: Land Aqcuisition --- 800,000/= Total 800,000/=

WE Team to benefit: integrated Adult Education

loans.use: Purchasing a plot of land for construction

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
A. Rose is an active member of Life in Africa working in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. She is 34 years old, is married and has 6 children. She is Acholi and originally lived in the Pader District in Northern Uganda. It was there that the rebels attacked her village and abducted two of her children. Her children were gone for two years but were finally rescued by government troups and were returned to her in the camp she fled to in Kampala. Rose and her husband both started working in the stone quarry but they were not able to earn enough to sustain the family. When she joined LiA their lives took a turn for the better. They have more money and they have been able to save enough to build a modest home which also helps financially since they no longer have to pay rent.

Their plan now is to enlarge the stone quarry work that her husband still does. By making it their own business they will be able to hire others so her husband does not have to do all the work himself and their production will increase giving them more income. To do this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is the budget in full:-

  1. Buying stone site 200,000=

  2. Labour digging up stones 150,000=

  3. Pulling out from pit 60,000=

  4. Cracking stones 60,000=

  5. Loading onto vehicles 30,000=

    Total 500,000=

WE Team to benefit: Adult Education

loans.use: Bying and hiring people to work at the site.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is an active member of Life in Africa. She is young, dedicated and very determined to make a secure future for herself. She originally came from Western Uganda but moved to Kampala where she lives with an aunt who agreed to help her with her education by taking her in and paying the school fees. She finished her secondary schooling but going on to the University became impossible due to lack of funds. But she would not be stopped.

She found the Womens Vocational Education Center where she managed to enroll in a course to learn catering. She graduated after 2 years and is determined to use what she learned to start a business. She currently works Monday through Friday at Life in Africa and runs a small scale catering service on the weekends. She saved carefully and has been able to buy things she needed such as warmers, plates, forks, knives, and table cloths which she rents out to her customers.

Her client list has grown and now she is ready to expand her small business. This will entail the purchase of more equipment so she will be able to cater to more customers and handle larger gatherings. For this reason she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is her budget

300 plates @ 1000/ ------------300,000/

150 forks @ 1200/ -----------180,000/

150 knives @ 1000/-----------150,000/

4 big saucepans @ 40000/ -----160,000/

Transport----------------------10,000/

Totals ------------------------800,000/

WE Team to benefit: Transport 4 liA

loans.use: Buying Catering Equipment
