PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!
Thanks Margret for finishing your loan.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
A. Esither is an active member of Life in Africa. She lives with her family in the Acholi quarters which is a camp for displaced persons from the wartorn North. Life is very difficult in the camps and the thousands who live there have very inadequate facilities and few services available to them. As a very observant person she has studied her community to see what services she could provide.

As a result of her observations, she decided that the people living in the camp need to raise their self esteem. They need to be as smartly dressed and groomed as any other people living in Kampala. To this end she plans to open a men's saloon (barber shop). Her husband who currently toils in the rock quarry would run the business while she continues with her work at LiA.

Her plans include erecting a small room adjacent to her house where there is power available. She also will purchase a small generator so that the business can still run even with the current power crisis in Uganda. Currently there are only a few such businesses and customers have to wait a very long time to have their turn to get shaved. She will be able to service more people and can keep the prices low so they can afford it.

To complete this project she is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000/=. She will be able to repay the loan in 12 months at a rate of 41,667/= per month.

Below is her break down:

  • Small generator ………………….250,000/=
  • Machine for shaving……………...70,000/=
  • A large mirror…………………….60,000/=
  • One arm chair……………………..30,000/=
  • One bench …………………………5,000/=
  • installing power....20,000/=
  • Building saloon shack…………….20,000/=
  • 4 iron sheets............. 40,000/=
  • others......................5000/=

Total = 500,000/=

WE Team to benefit: Talent Discovery

loans.use: Buying chairs, Shaver and constructing a Shack.

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!

loans.name: Auma

texts.en:
B. Auma is an active member of Life in Africa. She is married and has six children. Originally she lived in Northern Uganda where there has been war for twenty years. Her father was killed in this war and soon after she came to Kampala in search of a safer place to live. Here she earned what money she could by working in the rock quarry and also by selling yellow bananas. These she carried in a basket on her head and she would walk miles each day in hopes of finding customers.

Her life was very difficult and she barely earned enough to provide food for her children much less to pay school fees. But happily, she found Life in Africa and there she now earns a good living. Life has much improved for her and her family and money is now there for rent, food and even school fees for the children.

As her life improved, she started to have hope and allowed herself to start seeing a future. She carefully saved money and has acquired a plot of land in the Acholi quarters where she lives. On this land she plans to build a two room house for her family to live in. This will not only improve their standard of living but will enable the family to save the rent money they now pay each month. With this saved money the family hopes to build a permanent house in their home land when it is safe to return. For this project she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000. She will be able to repay this loan in one year.

Below is her budget in full:

1- Bricks 4000 @ 50/= ------------------- 200,000/=

2- Iron sheets 20 @ 10,000/= -------------- 200,000/=

3- Roofing poles 20 pcs poles @ 1500/= ------ 30,000/=

4- Nails required ---------- 20,000/=

5- Cement 10 bags @ 18,000/= ----------------- 180,000/=

7- labour ad water ------------------------- 100,000/=

8- Transport -------------------------------- 70,000/=

TOTAL ----------------------------- 800,000/=

The rest of the items not indicated above is going to be contributed by the husband.

WE Team to benefit: Educational program for Children.

loans.use: Buying Building materials

After failing to pay her loan back, Life in Africa as a guaranter has paid back for Betty in full, and will now recover her money from Betty in our own schedule and arrangements.

loans.name: Doreen

texts.en:
A. Doreen is an active member and worker at Life in Africa. She is currently employed in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. She enjoys her work and the companionship she finds with the other workers and is happy that she is making a good living.

She came to Kampala in 2003 when she had to flee her home in Northern Uganda because of the war. She was quite bored just sitting in the camps and so she tried working in the stone quarry to earn money. She found this work to be extremely hard physically. She still works the quarry but now hires others to do the actual labor.

She is a good business woman and knows that she can make a success of a business that offers a needed service in her community. She plans to open a salon/barber shop. The profits from this business will allow her to save so that someday she can build a permanent home and possibly another house to rent out. To do this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below are the budget in full:-

  1. machine 2@ 80,000 /= 160,000=

  2. Chairs 2 @ 20,000= 40,000=

  3. Mirror 2 big pcs @ 15,000/= 30,000=

  4. Rent 3 months @ 30,000= --- 90,000=

  5. transport ----------- 30,000/=

  6. Labour 2 @ 40,000/= ---- 80,000=

  7. Aprons 4 pcs @ 5,000= ---------- 20,000=

  8. Cosmetics ---------------------- 60,000=

    TOTAL 500,000=

WE Team to benefit: Talent discovery

loans.use: Buying materials for setting loan use

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
A. Pamela is an active member of Life in Africa. She is currently working in the Invisible Children Bracelet project making bracelets and she is earning a good salary for her efforts.

She live in the camp known as the Acholi Quarters where thousands who were forced to flee the war in the North have settled. She lives with her uncle but he has no work to do and so they are dependent on her income. She realizes that if there were some work for him to do their lives could be so much better and he would be happy to have work that would bring income to the household. And so she studied their situation and came up with a plan.

Groundnuts are consumed in great quantities by the Acholi. They grind these nuts and use them in sauces and nuts that are already ground are in good demand. Therefore, a local small scale business of grinding and packaging the groundnuts would be very suitable for her uncle to do. To accomplish this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to start the business. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months. Her break down:

1, Large paste miller @ 600,000/=

2,100kgs of groundnut @ 80,000/=

3, Transport 15,000/=

4, House rent for one month with power @ 45,000/=

5, packaging 30,000/=

6, others 30,000/=

Total is 800,000/=

WE Team to benefit: Community quarrantee lending

loans.use: Ground paste wholesale and Retail Business

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!

loans.name: Kiwanuka

texts.en:
Kiwanuka M. is a talented young artist working as an active member of Life in Africa. He joined LiA as an artist and he quickly earned the respect of the other members who elected him the Manager of the WE Center during the last elections. He is a man full of ambitions and talent and he is ready to see his visions come true.

His dream is to start a custom framing workshop near LiA so that customers who buy unframed artpieces can be able to get them framed at reasonable costs.

He has hired a room in the neighbourhood of the LiA Center to operate his custom framing services. He will in this way be able to monitor his business as well as his duties at LiA. This business will provide him with the additonal income he needs to further his own artistic talents.

To launch this project he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to purchase the necessary equipment. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

He has the following budget below to do his work.

Wood saw Manual------50,000

Wood saw Electric--------200,000

Nails 3kgs--------10,000

Glass-------------80,000

Glass cutter----- 10,000

Mounting paper----100,000

Ply wood --------20,000

Mounting paper cutter------20,000

Vanish---------10,000

Wood/ frame panels-----100,000

Rent 4 months----------200,000

Giving a total of Ushs. 800,000

His monthly income is Ushs. 670,000 and his surplus after his monthly expenses is Ushs.270,000, he wants to pay his loan in 10 months at a rate of Ushs. 93,333.

WE Team to benefit: Advertising and marketing

loans.use: Setting up a Customs Framing work shop

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!

The total amount LiA has repaid to Kiva for this loan is now equivalent to payments received by LiA from the borrower. Visit LifeInAfrica.com/kiva/2006loans.htm to view the current repayment status of all Kiva loans disbursed at Life in Africa in 2006. A journal update about this particular borrower's performance is next on our Kiva reporting agenda - thanks for your patience!

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard O. has been an active member of Life in Africa since August of 2005. He works as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. In his spare time he works at the rock quarry and he and his wife both make paper beads and hope to someday find a market for them.

He is 36 years old and has four children. They live in the Acholi quarters which is a camp for people displaced by the war in the North. They have been their eight years arriving with nothing since they lost all their possessions when the rebels burned their home. Before joining Life in Africa, their life was horrible. They barely existed on one meal a day and had no money for things like clothes or school. His children now are amazed at how their life has changed. They now have clothes, shoes, mattresses to sleep on and they are able to eat three meals a day. But more important, the contact with other positive people and the sharing of skills and ideas have given them the courage to dream and plan for a future.

Their dream now is to have a proper house. Richard has saved enough to acquire a plot of land and he now plans to build a family home. Then with the money he saves on rent, he will save to build a second home to rent out which will add to their income and give them a more secure future. He has the skills to provide the labor himself and has already saved part of the money needed for materials. To complete this project he is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000/=. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is his budget in full:

1- Bricks 2000@ 60/= ------------ 120,000/=

2- Cement 6 bags @ 18,000/= -------- 108,000/=

3 - Iron sheets 20 pcs. @ 10,000/= 200,000/=

4 - Roofing poles 10 pcs. @ 3,000/= 30,000/=

5 - Transport --------------- 42,000/=

TOTAL -------------- 500,000/=

Through his savings, He will buy the sand and the fittings. He also has some building skills, so he will be responsible for the labour.

Richard's loan has been reviewed and guaranteed by his community of peers at the Life in Africa WE Center in Kampala. He has designated the 25% community impact portion of the interest he will pay on this loan to support the WE Center Gulu.

loans.use: Building Family House

loans.name: George

texts.en:
B. George is an active member of Life in Africa. He works in the Invisible Children Bracelet project as a sander and he is finally earning a good income for his family. He is a humble man and is dedicated to creating a new and better life for his family. His family was forced to flee the North where the rebels are waging war and they live in the camp known as the Acholi Quarters. He has a wife and six children he is supporting and he also has a brother who lives with them.

His brother needs work to do and the additional income his brother could earn would greatly improve the life of the entire family. They have a plan to start a groundnut business which the brother can operate from their home. Groundnuts are a great favorite of the Acholi and as such are in great demand especially if they are already ground and packaged in small quantities making it affordable.

This business will be local and small scale but has the potential to grow. To start this business he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000 to purchase the equipment necessary. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is his break down:

1, paste miller small size @ 350,000/=

2, Small generator @ 250,000/=

3, Groundnuts 100kg @ 150,000/=

4, Renting one room with power for three months @ 25,000/= = 75,000/=

5, Transport 10,000/=

6, packaging 40,000/=

Total 800,000/=

WE Team to benefit: self sustaining development.

loans.use: Setting up groundnut paste business
