Life in Africa has paid this amount for George since he was not paying back any more . We have paid back so far $182.With this, we have already cleared all the loan balance for him, though we shall now recover this from him.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
S. Sok is married and father of two children. He is self employed as a moto-taxi. He came to CREDIT office to request a $500 loan and explained his plan: “I would like to buy a motorbike”, he said, “so that my wife can start her own business”. She will use the motorbike for buying and selling eggs to the local market.

S. Sok expects the motorbike to cost around $250 and his wife will use the remaining $250 as running capital for the eggs business.

He detailed the household forecasted daily income and expenses as following:

 

Moto Taxi:

25,000 taxi fare

 -8000 Petrol

=17,000 Riel ($4.12)

 

Eggs Business:

80,000 sale

-50,000 cost of eggs

-2000 petrol

=28,000 Riel ($7)

 

S. Sok is confident, but also concerned about this new business. “I am working from 3pm to 4 am while my wife will start her working days at 4am; I will hardly see her face.”

“Hopefully we will improve our standard of living and sometimes be able to build a proper house and buy a cow”, he added. His is also dreaming about his children going to the high school and the university.

loans.use: Buying a motorbike

payments.comment: Sun Sok was able to pay off his loan early. Thank you for lending to Sun Sok and enabling his family to improve their lives!

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
L. S. Ros, a traditional medicine manufacturer and seller, is applying for his first loan from CREDIT MFI in the amount of $400.   L. S. Ros received training on making traditional medicine five years ago, and he has been making and selling medicine ever since. Currently, he is selling the medicines from his home, and he is periodically making home visits when someone calls on him. His medicines are traditional herbal medicines that he makes from a variety of plants to treat multiple illnesses. L. S. Ros’s wife assists in the production of the medicine in their home.

 

With this loan L. S. Ros plans on purchasing a motorcycle ($300) so that he may drive around with his medicines, thus expanding his business. He will spend the other $100 to purchase raw materials for the medicine production.  Currently, L. S. Ros is making about $2 a day from his traditional medicine business. L. S. Ros is hoping to improve his family’s standard of living through the growth of the business. L. S. Ros and his wife have three children who live with them in their home. Two of their children currently attend school, and L. S. Ros desires to increase their income enough to be able to send their third child to school as well.

loans.use: Purchase motorbike and raw materials

loans.name: Hing

texts.en:
N. K. Hing lives with her two adult sons and one daughter in Phnom Penh. She is starting an air conditioning sales and repair business to help support her family. N. K. Hing is requesting her first loan from CREDIT MFI in the amount of $1,000 to pay for the import taxes that she incurred when importing the air conditioners from the United States. The taxes totaled $2,500, but she is only requesting $1,000 for her loan. Her two sons will be working in the business, and one of them currently works for a different air condition company where he has received much training.

 

With this loan N. K. Hing plans to open her new air conditioning shop in June. She is excited about this new opportunity, and she hopes to be able to continue to invest into the business and grow to the point where she can hire other people in her community. She would also like to raise her standard of living enough to be able to build a new home for her and her family.

loans.use: Pay for taxes of imports

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
P. Mom is currently a moto taxi driver in Phnom Penh. He is requesting a loan of $800 in order to change his moto taxi into a tuk tuk (a passenger cart that is pulled by a motorcycle). The cart costs $700, and he will use the other $100 to cover the cost of improving his moto so that it is strong enough to pull the cart.  Currently, P. Mom makes about $2 a day as a moto taxi driver. He anticipates that with his new tuk tuk he will be able to make $10 gross income, and he will have about $4 in expenses, which means he should make about $6 a day. This will greatly increase his family’s standard of living.

 

P. Mom lives with his wife and one daughter. He has two grown children who are working in factories nearby, and one child who is studying in their original village. His wife currently sells food and fruits from their home.  P. Mom is hoping that he can increase their income enough that his wife’s business can expand into a grocery store. He would also like to make improvements on their home.

loans.use: Purchase of a motorbike cart for personnal transportation

loans.name: Sokrorn

texts.en:
K. Sokrorn is a mother of three in Phnom Penh, who is currently selling food in front of the local factories. She is making approximately $7.50 a day from selling food. After seeing her friend successfully open a store, K. Sokrorn decided that she would like to open a grocery store. Therefore, she is applying for her first loan from CREDIT MFI in order to acquire the inventory for her store. She is requesting $500 to purchase fruits, vegetables, and other products for the store.

 

K. Sokrorn and her husband, who is a moto taxi driver, are expecting this new grocery store to help them improve the lives of their children. They would like to use the additional income they will receive from the business to build a new home and purchase cows.

loans.use: Running Capital for a grocery shop

loans.name: Maari

texts.en:
Maari is married with 6 children. Maari has been greatly empowered through her active participation in various development activities. She is the coordinator of her village focal group. WEEC organized a training on Modern methods of livestock management, and she was among the participants.

In year 2004 Maari joined WEEC credit programme and was given a loan of USD 60. Her loan went to buy her first steer. To pay up her loan she started making bead ornaments for sale. This and the sale of milk enabled her to pay her loan promptly. After the fattening period, Maari sold the steers at the local market for USD 120.This enabled her to buy two Small steers. The steers are in the fattening period and will be sold in three months time.

loans.use: A loan of USD 450 Will help Maari to buy seven small steers. In three months, she will be able to get good profits and thus improve her standard of living.

loans.name: Seenoi

texts.en:
Seenoi is married with 4 children. She went through formal education and completed primary level. She is the chairlady of Retuno focal group a group that facilitates community development issues. Seenoi too attended the training on mordern methods of livestock management. She is actively involved in the trainings undertaken to enable her community see the need to change from their traditional methods of livestock rearing that leaves them counting heavy losses during the prolonged dry spells.

Seenoi steers project was started off with USD 120 that she received from the Group revolving fund. She raised her steers very well through the training she had received. She also wanted people to learn from her the need to encompass the positive changes. After the fattening period she sold the stork however she only bought two steers because of the dry spell. With the other proceeds she paid secondary school fee for her children.

loans.use: Seenoi wants to buy six medium sized steers. She will graze them 3-6 months thus they will be ready for sale in December.

loans.name: Setuka

texts.en:
Setuka is married with six children. She joined Umoja women group and became a very active member. Due to the growing market in Isinya town for steers, She took a loan of USD 120 and bought two steers. She paid her loan from the milk proceeds. With last years prolonged drought, her family lost some of their herds. Setuka`s family now sees the need to practice the modern methods of livestock management.

Setuka sells steers in cattle markets in Isinya and now she wants to buy 3 medium sized steers. She believes that with the support she receives from her family, the trainings she gets through her group, and the favorable market she will be able to excel in her steers project.

loans.use: Setuka wants to take advantage of the rainy season and buy   steers to be raised for about 3-6 months and then later be sold in Isinya market.

loans.name: Soyainoi

texts.en:
Soyanoi is married with four children. She joined Umoja women group and became a very active member. She actively advocates for the education of the girl – child because she did not get the opportunity to go to school. She is a committee member of Inkiito primary school.

Soyanoi started her small steers’ project with money she had saved for sometime from her bead work. This was after she attended a training organized by WEEC on “THE NEED TO SAVE”. She managed to buy two small steers. She later sold the steers at USD 125.She then took a loan of USD 130 from her group, added to her sales proceeds and purchased four steers. She is currently fattening them and intends to market them when the prices are most favorable.

loans.use: Soyainoi wants to buy three steers and will stand a chance of buying good young steers at a better price especially when she buys them at once.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is married and has seven children. Her four children are in Primary and another three in secondary school. She is a trustworthy, hard working woman and this is why the group members decided to elect her as their Treasurer.

Eunice started her small business in 2001 with the help of her husband who provided start up capital. The business has been growing and at least she is able to pay school fees for her children and provide for her family’s basic necessities. She no longer waits for her husband to buy some of the household items and food.

loans.use: She would like to add more stock into her shop such as sugar, maize flour, Wheat flour and rice. Maize being a staple food for the Kenyans once you stock maize flour and related products, you must make a sale every day. Therefore, she expects to increase her sales which will generate more income in

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is married with three children. Two of her children are in secondary school while the other one is in primary. She finished secondary school level but could not go further because her parents wanted her to get married. She looks forward to giving her children good education which she missed because her parents did not value it so much.

Mary runs a soft drinks outlet in Olturoto Trading centre and has been running it for five years. The business is doing so well to the extent of balancing a profit of USD 65 per week. She has been able to cement her house floor and plans to build a block house if the business continues with this trend for two years

loans.use: Mary sells sodas, bottled juices - passion fruit juice, mango and water at retail level. At times she sells to other retailers but on a small scale; however, she would be doing better if she had enough stock. Therefore, she will use this loan to buy more of the soft drinks for wholesale as well as t

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a very active member of Nyota Women Group which she joined in 2002. She is married with three children.

Alice started her small business in 2002 with assistance from her husband who gave her USD 150 to start. To date she can get USD 10 in a week which is on average good income in her standards. Her children have never missed school, they have enough food and get medical care when they are sick. She is happy to having joined her group because she has been borrowing small loans to push her in her business whenever there is a gap. The group loans she borrowed were paid back promptly because of being a hard worker and trustworthy.

loans.use: She plans to buy 3 bales of first class used clothes and new materials for making new clothes.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 46 years old, married with five children. She is very active in women affairs and the group decided to elect her to the post of chairlady. Nancy attended secondary education and this has helped her in directing other women.

Nancy started her business two years ago with USD 100 and it has been improving day-by- day. The business has grown to the tune of about USD 900 and continues to grow further. This business enables her to support the family in all household requirements and believes that she will be financially stable in two years to come.

loans.use: Nancy operates a retail shop that sells a number of household items. The population in Olturoto Trading centre has been growing as well as the demand of house hold items such as sugar, maize flour, rice, soap, salt and many more. Therefore, she wants to increase her stock of these items to match wit

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann is 38 years and married with 3 children. Her children are all of school going age and are attending local schools. Ann is quite active in her group and due to her leadership abilities she was elected the Vice Chairlady

Ann has accessed 4 loans from her group of USD 30, USD 60, USD 90 and USD 120. She has used these loans to expand her kiosk and also start the flower farming business. She successfully repaid these loans with the proceeds from her businesses. She makes a profit of USD 75 per month from her kiosk and USD 150 per month from flower sales as she has a ready market. She has been working very closely with her husband in managing the 2 businesses.

loans.use:
To meet the growing demand for goods from her kiosk, she intends to stock a variety of items so as to make her kiosk a one stop shop for her customers.
Loan usage Plan:  To expand her kiosk business by adding a variety of business stock

loans.name: Dorcus

texts.en:
Dorcus is married with 3 children and is 48years old. She is a nurse by profession and likes farming too. She is an open minded lady and this has enabled her to trying out other income generating activities to increase her income.

Dorcus has been a vegetable farmer for the last 5 years. She joined Revelations Women group in 2004 and started by saving USD 10 per month. In February 2005, she borrowed USD 300 and paid it. In November, she borrowed another loan of USD 300 she has repaid too. These loans helped her in educated her children and still struggling to see them through.

loans.use: Dorcus has been a farmer and a nurse for some time. She would like to start a beauty salon in Thika town to help her increase her income.

loans.name: Freshiah

texts.en:
Freshiah is 34 years, married with 2 children. One of her children goes to primary school. Her husband assists her on the farm which has ensured that they get regular income from their activities.

She keeps dairy cows and also rears sheep for sale. She started vegetable farming 2 years ago when she joined Githunguri Abigael Mothers group where she was able to access 3 loans of USD 45, USD 75, USD 120 which she successfully repaid back. Currently she is making a profit of USD 50 from sale of vegetables. With ready market for her vegetables, she intends to grow more since she has the land and intends to buy a water pump to irrigate her vegetable farm from a river that flows near her farm. This will ensure that she has vegetables all year round to meet her client’s orders.

loans.use: Freshiah wants to buy a small water pump.This will assist her in irrigating her vegetables as well as providing water for the cows.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
She is married with 5 children and is 50 years. 3 of her children have finished school while 2 are in secondary school. Her husband is a retired civil servant and currently assists her on the farm. She has been a group member for 5 years.

Grace has been a farmer all her life and therefore has experience in dairy and tea farming. A large acreage of her farm is under tea but has set aside an area where she grows fodder for her cows which are zero grazed. Grace bought her cows from tea proceeds as well as the loans she got from Our Lady of Unity women group. To date, she has successfully repaid 9 loans from her group. Her previous loan was of USD 500. She gets USD 30 per month from sale of milk and USD 220 from tea. With the loan applied for, she intends to buy a water pump so as to be able to get water from a nearby river for her cows. This has been a problem due to the steep terrain of her farm. This will enable her better manage dairy cows and get more milk for sale. She also intends to buy farm inputs-fertilizers and cattle feed.

loans.use: Grace wants to improve her farming by purchasing farming equipment-water pump and inputs-fertilizer and animal feeds

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is married with 3 children and is 43 years. Her husband is employed and is currently educating 2 children in University. Due to her strong community mobilization and leadership skills, she holds many leadership positions in church and in the community. She is currently the area zonal chair lady responsible for supervising 8 groups. She has been in her group for 6 years.

Grace has one dairy cow, 600 chicken (layers) and a quarter acre of land under horticulture and 2 acres under tea. She gets USD 120 from milk, USD 1000 from sale of eggs, USD 150 from tea and USD 120 from horticulture sales .She started chicken farming early last year from a loan of USD 750 she got from her group has been able to meet her client’s orders. With the loan applied for she intends to improve on the housing of the chicken to ensure that they are sheltered from bad weather conditions and also that there is more space for additional chicken in future. Part of the loan will also be used to buy chicken feed in bulk.

loans.use: Grace wants to improve her poultry farming that is Buying feeds and expanding the shed to get more space.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 36 years old and married with 3 children. 2 of her children are in primary school in a nearby private academy. She is also the group secretary.

Lucy started her business 3 years ago as a kiosk in Kabati town, which is quite vibrant due to being near a highway. This has however grown to the current general shop selling a variety of commodities. She was able to do this from the loans that she accessed from her group. She has received 4 loans from her group and successfully repaid them back. Her previous loan was of USD 120 was used to buy cereals for her shop to meet the huge demand that was there due to a prevailing drought in the country. She makes a profit of USD 75 per month and intends to add more stock in her business by buying a variety of goods in bulk from wholesalers so as to get a wider profit margin.

loans.use: Lucy deals stocksn a variety of household products. The loan will be used for buying more stock such as maize flour, beans, sugar, salt, soap,generally to increase her stock level.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married with 5 children and is 48years old. One of her children is waiting to join college and is currently assisting her at the farm together with her husband.

Margaret previously was used to subsistence farming-maize and beans. But she realized that this would not sustain her family and meet her family growing needs. That is when she rented a small farm and started growing French beans and cabbages. This has seen a huge transformation in her life as she is now able to make a monthly profit of USD 300 from her farming. This has enabled her send her children to school and live a decent life. The loan applied for, she intends to expand her farming by purchasing farm inputs-seeds and fertilizers so as to grow more of the cabbages and French beans. She gets orders from as far as Thika town and the buyers usually come to buy from her at the farm and therefore does not incur transport costs.

loans.use: Margaret is in the process of improving her farm and thus the loan will be used for buying improved seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is married and has 5 children. She is a high school teacher and an active member of the Anglican Church and an official of the church council. She is the treasurer of Plains view self help group. Her 5 children are all in school and her husband is employed.

To supplement her employment income, Pamela started poultry and dairy farming in her rural home in Gatundu. She has 350 chicken (layers) and 2 dairy cows. She has employed one person at the farm but always ensures she is there when she is free and over the weekends. She sells 11 crates of eggs per day at USD 25 and 25 litres of milk at USD 5 per day. Her total income from farming every month is USD 900. Gatundu is a fast growing area and Pamela would want to increase the number of her chicken to be able to serve this readily available market better. She already has orders that she is not able to meet.

loans.use:
Pamela wants to buy more chicken such that she 
increases the supply of eggs currently in short supply in Thika Town.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
She is 50 years old, married, has 5 children, 2 of whom have completed secondary school and 1 has completed college and is looking for employment.. She is also the group secretary.

Susan has a dairy cow; also she is a horticultural farmer, banana farmer and grows maize and beans. From her farming she is able to generate USD 150 per month and also feed her family. She bought her dairy cow from a loan of USD 120 she got from her group and income from her farming. She intends to start a small business in Githunguri shopping centre which is quite vibrant to supplement her income from farming. She will be assisted by her son who has received some formal business training but is currently unemployed. She previously had a shop in Muhutini but closed it due to insecurity. She thus has the necessary experience to manage the business.

loans.use: Susans success in farming has pushed her to starting a small retail business near her home. This will assist her in sselling her milk and farm output.

loans.name: Maria Martina

texts.en:
I have been working for three years selling dairy products such as small cheeses, butter, cheese, also corn, beans and firewood. In my community I am one of the only people who sell these products, which are basics for daily consumption. I hope I can increase my earnings and help my children in their education at the university level.

Loan Use: Buying butter, cheese, small hard cheeses, beans, corn and firewood.

Tengo tres años de dedicarme a la venta de lacteos como quesillo, mantequilla, queso, maiz, frijoles y leña. En mi comunidad soy una de las pocas personas que venden estos productos y que son basicos para el consumo diario. Espero poder incrementar mis ingresos y poder apoyar a mis hijos en sus estudios universitarios.

loans.use: Compra de Mantequilla, Queso, Quesillo, Frijoles, Maiz, y leña.

payments.comment: Por las personas que creen en los micronegocios, es que hemos podido hacer negocios en nuestro pais, agradezco su ayuda y ahora necesito renovar mi inventario para mejorar mis ventas de fin de año.

loans.name: Maria Socorro

texts.en:
My name is Maria Socorro and I sell corn, beans and firewood. I have been working for four years in this business, which I began with my own money. In the rainy season, people look for me so they can buy firewood, because in this area, we do not have electricity. I know that with the help (loan), I will be able to better my family’s earnings.

Loan Use: Buying beans, corn and firewood.

Mi nombre es Maria Socorro y me dedico ala venta de maiz, frijoles y leña. Tengo 4 años de dedicarme a esta actividad, la que inicie con mi propio capital de trabajo. En los meses de lluvia las personas me buscan para comprar leña, ya que esta zona no tenemos luz electrica. Se que con el apoyo que me brinden podre mejorar mi ingreso familiar.

loans.use: Compra de frijoles, maiz y Leña.

payments.comment: Mis ventas de granos basicos han mejorado mucho y en este momento necesito comprar maiz para los nacatamales de fin de año, gracias por su apoyo.

loans.name: Gloria Idalia

texts.en:
I have a small business, which is located in my house. I have been selling clothes, cosmetics, and shoes, for 15 years. My job is hard because I have to leave to go to offices to sell my products, but it is worth it, because my earnings enable me to help my children in their studies,which is especially important because one is already studying at the university.

Loan Use: Buying clothes for children and women, cosmetics, bedclothes(pajamas), curtains, sandals, and underwear.

Tengo un pequeño negocio ubicado en mi casa, vendo ropa, cosmeticos, y zapatos desde hace 15 años. El trabajo es duro porque tengo que salir a oficinas a vender mis productos, pero vale la pena ya que mis ingresos me dan la oportunidad de ayudar a mis hijos en sus estudios, logrando que 1 ya este en la universidad.

loans.use: Compra de Ropa para niño, dama, cosmeticos, ropa de cama, cortina, sandalias, ropa interior.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Jose Angel

texts.en:
I have had a small grocery store called Oneyda, in my home for three years, I attend to the store alongside my wife. Our clients are satisfied with the attention with which we help them, and also for our quality products at low prices. Our earnings help us to pay our familial and financial obligations.

Loan Use: Buying milk, bread, eggs, cornflour, sodas, coffee, sugar and other items

Tengo una pequeña pulperia llamada Oneyda en mi casa de habitacion desde hace tres años, esta la atiendo junto a mi esposa. Nuestra clientela se siente satisfecha por la atencion que les brindamos, ademas por los productos de calidad y bajos precios. Los ingresos que percibimos por las ventas nos ayudan a cubrir nuestros compromisos familiares y financieros.

loans.use: Compra de leche, pan, huevos, harina de maiz, refrescos, cafe, azucar y otros

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Bilma

texts.en:
I have been working for three years in my butcher shop, selling pork, beef and chicken. My shop is located in the transportation terminal of my town. My products are good and all the people that travel here from other towns buy my meat to take home with them. Now the demand is greater because our town is growing in size. Thanks to my earnings, I can help my family with the expenses of education and food.

Loan Use: Buying pork, beef and chicken meats.

Tengo 3 años de vender carne de cerdo, res y pollo en mi carniceria zelaya, esta ubicada en la terminal de transporte de esta ciudad. Mis ventas son buenas ya que todas las personas que viajan de otras ciudades compran carne para llevar a sus hogares. Ahora la demanda que tengo es mayor ya que nuestra ciudad ha crecido en poblacion. Gracias a los ingresos que obtengo ayudo a mi familia con los gastos de estudios y alimentacion.

loans.use: Compra de Carne de res, cerdo y pollo.

loans.name: Adelina

texts.en:
My name is Adelina and I have owned my shop for 5 years. It is located in one of the terminals in town, where I sell all types of ítems for basic daily consumption, along with my husband, we attend to our clients reliably and formally. Our earnings that we generate from our business help us with our familial and financial obligations.

Loan Use: Buying sugar, coffee, eggs, soap, sodas, bread and other items

Me llamo Adelina, tengo mi pulperia Kelin desde hace 5 años. Esta ubicada en una de las terminales de esta ciudad, aca vendo toda clase de producto de consumo basico familiar, junto a mi esposo atendemos a nuestra clientela que es bastante cumplidora y formal. Los ingresos que nos genera el negocio son para ayudarnos con nuestros gastos familiares y financieros.

loans.use: Compra de azucar, cafe, huevos, jabon, refrescos, pan y otros.

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
My name is Asunción and my business is called M.’ Grocery Store. It is located near to the school Jose Trinidad Reyes, which helps me sell my products. During the night I sell sweets because there is a lot of traffic in this area and the school has three daily segments of classes. My earnings help me care for my children in their studies and in my familial expenses.

Loan Use: Buying batteries, juices, milk, churros ( a type of sweet pastry), cookies, condiments, coffee and other items.

Me llamo Asuncion, y mi negocio lleva el nombre de Pulperia M.. Esta ubicada cerca de la escuela Jose Trinidad Reyes, lo que me ayuda a vender mis productos. Por las noches vendo golosinas ya que esta zona es bastante transitada y el colegio tiene tres jornadas diarias de clases. Los ingresos me ayudan atender a mis hijos en sus estudios y gastos de familia.

loans.use: Compra de baterias, jugos, leche, churros, galletas, condimentos, cafe y otros.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Manuel De Jesus

texts.en:
I work taking photos of events and of people, also for passports and kin. I have 5 years experience and in my community, I am contracted to cover events such as reunions, parties or press events. My business is family owned and operated, but I have two young assistants who help me take photos and develop them. I like to take photos and thanks to this job, I am able to work to support my family.

Loan Use: Buying rolls of film, cameras, photographic paper and other items.

Me dedico a tomar fotografias de eventos y personas, tambien para pasaportes y carne. Tengo mas de 5 años de experiencia y en mi comunidad me contratan para cubrir eventos en reuniones, fiestas o ruedas de prensa. Mi negocio es familiar pero tengo 2 jovenes que me ayudan a tomar fotografias y revelarlas. Me gusta tomar fotos y gracias a este trabajo he podido apoyar a mi familia.

loans.use: Compra de rollos fotograficos, camaras, papel para fotos y otros.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Sarin

texts.en:
T. Sarin came to CREDIT office with his wife to request a second loan, after successfully repaying the first. After investing his first $500 to have his house connected to the electricity network, he is now applying for a $1000 loan, whose main purpose is to improve their family house. As a self employed mason, Sarin has a great experience of construction. He will use $700 for buying the materials required and perform the works by himself.

The remaining $300 will be invested in the soy bean milk business Sahin’s wife is running on her side.

Every active member of the family will contribute to the repayment. Sarin usually earns around $7 a day, while his wife can make $2 profit out of $25 soy bean milk sales. Their eldest daughter is 26 and employed in a sewing factory and her $80 monthly salary might also help. Their two youngest sons are still going to school.

“Since we started borrowing from CREDIT, our standard of living improved”, they said. ‘We would like our children to study at the University, if possible abroad”, they added.

loans.use: purchase materials to improve his fanily's house

payments.comment: Thach Sarin was able to pay off his loan early. Thank you for partnering with CREDIT MFI to assist Thach Sarin!

loans.name: Navy

texts.en:
Kaeiv Navy is married and father of children. He is working at the National Assembly of Cambodia, as a support staff.

He applied for a $500 loan for his wife to open a grocery shop. She used to run a similar business but the family sold it a few years ago, when her eldest son got married. Navy’s wife will use the money as a running capital to purchase spices and other goods to be sold in the shop. They are expecting 10,000 Riel ($2.5) profit from the shop every day, which will cover daily expenses for food.

This is the first time Navy is borrowing money. “If we are successful, we will increase the size of the business step by step with our future loans”, he said.

loans.use: Running Capital for a grocery shop

loans.name: Saphean

texts.en:
S. Saphean is married and mother of three young children. In addition to her casual domestic tasks, she is alS. earning her living by selling vegetables in the market at night. Her husband is a cook and enrolls for frequent weddings ceremonies. He takes care of the children at night, when Saphean is out to the market.

With the $1100 loan she requested, Saphean is planning to expand her business with a bigger stand and more diversity in her products. She hopes to increase her income from the market and would alS. like to open a small shop in front of her house to sell cane juice during the day.

loans.use: Running capital for a vegetable shop

payments.comment:
Dear lenders, 

after their loan assessment, So Saphean and CREDIT  agreed on lowering the amount of this loan from $1,100 down to $700.
This amount fits with So Saphean financial needs and also with her repayment capacity.
That is why we are already posting this $400 repayment.
 
We wish So Saphean the best in her life and business, 

Thanks for your support, 
CREDIT MFI

We are pleased to report that So Saphean has been able to pay both November\'s and December\'s payments. Thank you for being patient in this situation.

CREDIT Staff

loans.name: Bam

texts.en:
M. Ban is married and father of 8 children. They are all living at the same place. His wife is growing rice in a field near their house for the family consumption, while their two eldest sons are employed in factories and their eldest daughter is waitress in a restaurant. 

M. Ban is selling watches and glasses on a mobile stand on different places such as markets and bus stations in and around Phnom Penh. For the moment, he is walking from one place to another or sometimes hiring a moto-taxi. He is selling his glasses for around 3000 Riel ($0.75) and his watches for 4000 Riel ($1). On sunny days he can sell for $20 and earn around $5 profit.

M. decided to borrow $500 from CREDIT. He will first purchase a cheap second-hand motorbike for $300, so that he could move to more places and increase its profit. M. wants to raise a pig the family house as well. It will cost $200 but they expect and exceptional income from the sale.

loans.use: purchasing a motorbike and a pig

payments.comment: October Payment. Thank you for your patience and understanding in Mav Ban\'s situation with his late repayments. We are very pleased he has been able to catch up on his payments.

loans.name: Dara

texts.en:
S. Dara has been self employed as a mason for more than five years now. He learnt this job from his father and took over the business when he retired. He lives with his wife, who is employed in a factory, and their four children.

For the first time, S. Dara is borrowing $700 from CREDIT because he wants to expand his activities and needs additional tools to perform the works required by a client. He will spend $500 in purchasing a motorbike, that will allow him to go further and faster and find more clients. He will also buy special scissors designed to cut steel for covering the roofs for $50 and another electric machine to cut floor tiles for $80.

His current client will pay him $600 for one and half month labor on building his house. “I am not worried about repaying this loan”, he said, “and if the business keeps going well, I would like to build a bigger house for my family!”

loans.use: Purchasing a motorbike and mason tools

payments.comment: September Payment. Thank you for your patience and understanding in Dara Sous\'s situation with his late repayments. We are pleased that he has been able to make his September payment, and we will keep you updated about his situation. Thank you.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married with one child. She went up to secondary school. She is the secretary of Umoja women group and actively participates in training members on group issues especially the running of the revolving fund.

Margaret started her steers business in 2004. She received a loan from the revolving fund that enabled her to buy two steers. She wants to increase the number to at least 15 steers such that she has a constant supply. She sells her steers in Isinya and Kiserian markets. Trainings in modern methods of livestock management have helped her in keeping good breeds avoiding inbreeding thus having quality steers all the time. This has increased demand for her steers, a major drive to keeping more.

loans.use: Margaret wants to increase the number of steers for her to supply more in the markets of Kiserian and Isinya.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
N. is 23 years old, married have no child but takes care of one girl of a relative and she is in primary school. 

N.`s main activity before joining Umoja women group was bead work and looking after her husband`s cows. When she joined Umoja women group, and was trained on modern livestock management, she decide to start a small steers’ project. She took a loan of USD 118 and bought 2 steers. After 4 months she sold them at Isinya market and got USD 225. This encouraged her and now aims at keeping 8 steers at a go and selling them as they mature to enable her generate income throughout the year. She intends to market at Isinya and Kitengela township. This will assist her take care of her dependant and also her children in future.

loans.use: Nashipae wants to buy two steers which will be fattened and sold in 4-6 month.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: W. is 52 years old a widow and has 6 children. She did her primary education and is the treasurer of Umoja women group. W. has struggled hard and has managed to educate 4 of her children, 2 up to college. She has been rearing the indigenous goats. When she joined Umoja women group she was trained on modern livestock management. Due to the vegetation devastation in Maasailand women received training and prepared them for a positive change. W. is happy that the new changes will enable her educate all her children since the steers will give her more income. From rearing of indigenous goats, W. has now bought 3 steers with a loan of USD 180 that she received from her group and paid it back. Her aim is to reduce the number of goats and engage in selling steers.

loans.use: This loan will be used to buy three steers to be grazed for 6 months and later be sold

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more timbers and carpentry tools.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase value to the milk.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand ox-plough spare parts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock more phones and accessories.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase the stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increase the stock of used clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase the stock of clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increase the stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying leather materials.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add more produce in the stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: TO increase the stock of wedding atire and decoration materials.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase the stock of produce

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
She is 54 years old, a widow with 5 children. Of five children, 3 are independent. One is in college still under her support and the other in secondary school. Both assist her in farming during their holidays.

Gladys has been in this business for 11 years. Also she carries out coffee farming and keeps livestock on a small scale. Her business has been performing very well over the years because of less competition within the area and she has regular customers.

loans.use: She won a tender to supply beef 140 kilograms per week to a neighboring secondary school. The loan will be used to buy more cows.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
She is 50 years old widow with 5 children, 2 are in a technical college and the other in High School.

Grace has been in farming for 26 years and this has been the source of income. She has been able to educate her children up to college level. She has 3 hectares of land with coffee trees and 3 Dairy cows which in aggregate brings a net income of USD180 per month. The milk market has improved and there are better terms of payment of dairy products offered by cooperative societies. She wants to replace in phases her dairy cows which on average produce 8 litres of milk per day with a better breed that can produce approximately 18 litres per day. Once this project is fully implemented she will increase her earnings more than double.

loans.use: She would like to buy an improved breed of dairy cow.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan is 56 years old married with 5 children, 2 are still depending on her even after finishing school due to unemployment. She has been in this business for 8 years and deals more with fast moving consumer goods e.g. rice, sugar, maize flour and cereals. Cereals have higher returns and their prices are not as volatile as the rest of the products.

loans.use: She would like to stock cereals because of having higher returns.

loans.name: Phyllis

texts.en: Phyllis is a young lady aged 23 years, single with no children.She has been in this business for four years and on average making a profit of about USD 75 per month. She washes them, irons such that they look flashier and modifies some to be fashionable. She wants to purchase a sowing machine to avoid expenses of going to the tailor.

loans.use: She wants to purchase a sowing machine to avoid expenses of going to the tailor.

loans.name: Winfred

texts.en: Winfred is 28 yrs old and single.This is the only business of its kind in Gaitheri trading centre and its services are in demand by the community. This clinic has been in operation for 5 years and members from the community have trust in her and really appreciate her services.

loans.use: She wants to stock the new malaria drug which is abit expensive but very effective.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is 36 years old, single with 4 children. Her children attend school, 1 in High School and 3 in primary school.Janet sells milk and she has been doing this business for last seven years. She also sells fodder, vegetables such as cabbages and kales to bring in extra income. The prevailing market conditions in terms of demand for milk, good prices has encouraged her to replace her cows by a better breed which will give her 18 litres per day instead of the previous 8 litres.

loans.use: Janet wants to buy a better breed dairy cow to increase milk supply.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 30 years old, married with 2 children both in primary school.Grace sells milk and calfs a business she has been doing for 5 years with returns of about USD 75 per month. She sells her milk in Kiambugi trading centre and to the neighbors. She is planning to get rid of the existing cows which are of low quality and replace them with high breed whose milk production is far much higher.

loans.use: She would like to improve on her premises to meet the required standard and buy a good quality dairy cow.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is 24 years old single with no children.She has been in this business for 3 years and employs 2 casual workers. She prepares chips and traditional foods such as Ugali, mixed vegetables-Sukuma week, and porridge. Chips move very fast and she experiences shortage during peak hours at lunch time. Currently the existing cooker can not allow her meet the demand during these hours.

loans.use: She needs money to purchase a higher capacity cooker that would be able to increase the output of chips two folds.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice is 35 yrs old married with 4 children, 2 are in primary school and 2 in boarding secondary school. She has more than 8 years experience in this business which has been generating an average monthly net profit of 100 USD. Her business has been sustainable due to minimum operational costs as she operates in an open air market. The fact that she moves in various markets, enable her to meet more customers.

loans.use: Muthoni wants to diversify her business and include ladies and children’s shoes.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 34 yrs old, married with 5 children. Her two children are in High School, 2 in primary school while the other is yet to join college. She has been doing this business for the last two years and has recorded tremendous achievement because she has been able to pay farmers on daily basis unlike cooperatives which pays on monthly basis. She has been using plastic Jericans but this has been stopped recently by the cooperatives that they are not hygienic. This has forced milk vendors to buy aluminium cans.

loans.use: She would like to purchase 12 aluminium cans and each cost USD 25.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline is 27 years old, married with one child. Her husband runs a small butchery in Rongai. She joined WEEC Credit program in 2003. She has attended various business courses organized by WEEC and this has helped her do her job and duties of group secretary. She started a small business of selling second hand blouses in Rongai in 2002. She was given a loan by her group of USD 225 and set up a small semi permanent beauty shop and clothes. The small business is doing well so far and has managed to pay her loan without any problem as well as living decently

loans.use: Caroline would like to stock new clothes to be and 1st class second hand clothes.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is married with one child. She was forced to drop out of school to take care of her youngest sister when her mother passed away. With her sister’s upbringing and education falling on her at such an early age, she sought for an income generating activity. She joined a women’s group and received basic business training courses that WEEC provided for its members.

 In year 2003 Esther received her first loan of USD 60 to start a small business. She started a fruits business. She put her stall near Hardy supermarket so as to target those who want to buy fresh fruit other of the supermarket. The fruit business is doing well and has enabled her to educate her sister up to secondary level. Esther believes that discipline and hard work is the core of any business success. To this, she is the discipline mistress in her group. Esther’s dream is to expand her business to include cereals. She has started a special project of keeping local chicken and they are in high demand compared to broilers. Each local chicken costs USD 4.

loans.use: Esther wants to stock cereals and buy more local chicken

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en:
P. Pheap came to CREDIT office in Phnom Penh because she just repaid her first loan and want to start a new cycle. This time, she is requesting $550 to invest in the business she is running with her husband.

P. Pheap and her husband have been selling foxes for food consumption on Psar Kandal, one of Phnom Penh biggest market for more than 4 years already. Fox meat dishes are highly appreciated in Khmer traditional cuisine and are prepared on special events and in a few restaurants. P. Pheap buys the animals from catchers from several provinces of Cambodia, such as Kompong Thom, Pursat and Kompong Chhnang, and sells them alive with a margin of about $1 per kilo.

This activity is not an easy one, but it has been covering the expenses of the family for a while now. P. Pheap is proud to say that 4 of her 5 children are going to school. The youngest is only 4 months old and her wish is to build a bigger house for her growing family.

loans.use: Running Capital

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Nan

texts.en:
S. Nan is harvesting water spinach on a small piece of land she rent near to her house, in the outskirts of Phnom Penh City. She lives alone with her grown daughter, who is 23 years old and already employed in a sewing factory. In the morning, she gets up at 5am to harvest the water spinaches. She takes a break between 11am and 2pm, when the sun is too hot and then goes back to the field until 5pm to sow new plants.  

S. Nan requested a $600 loan from CREDIT to pay the rent for the land and to purchase seeds for the next harvest. She also needs wooden sticks and string to delimit her field. This will cost her around $300.

With the remaining $300, S. Nan will have a bridge built between her house and the main path of the village. With the rainy season about to start, this improvement becomes critical for her. Last year, she had to use a boat to reach her house. She hopes the works can be completed before August.

The business is breeding around 30,000 Riels daily and with her daughter salary, S. Nan is really confident about repaying this loan. But she is dreaming about moving to another place because of the floods in the area.

loans.use: Buying seeds and renting land for the next crop. Building a bridge between her house and the village main path.

loans.name: Nen

texts.en:
P. Nen is married and lives with her husband and young baby in Phnom Penh suburbs, around 20 kilometers from the center of the city.

She decided to borrow $1,000 from CREDIT to help her husband in his business. He is running a small shop in the city and makes windows and doors out of materials such as steel, iron and glass. As he started only three years ago, his shop is still small but the business is profitable and he wants to expand. With $1000 he will purchase tools and raw materials to increase the quality and the volume of his production.

This business is already breeding $10 per day and P. Nen is also running her small business: she has got a sewing machine at home and makes clothes to be sold in Phnom Penh. She learnt these skills by helping her friends and now she can make around 50,000 Riel ($12.5) per week.

P. Nen wants to continue doing this activity, because she can look after her baby while her husband is busy outside.

loans.use: purchase tools and raw materials for her husband's business

loans.name: Siphan

texts.en:
K. Siphan is a grandmother living with her mother, and her Son’s family. They moved from Phnom Penh city to this newly populated area only one week ago but they already started building a proper house to shelter the seven of them from the heavy rains of the coming months.

K. Siphan requested $500 for her first loan with CREDIT because the family need fund to buy the material to complete the works, but also for investing in the small shop she is already operating on her new land.

K. Siphan's son is employed by the Cambodian Red Cross in a nearby Health Center Project and earns a regular salary of $135 per month.

K. Siphan is making around 10,000 Riel ($2.5) daily income from the shop but she expects more profit in the future, when she will expand her business with additional products.

loans.use: Building a new house

payments.comment: We are pleased to let you know that Keo Siphan was able to catch up on her payments for October, November, and December. The late payments were due to some confusion about how she was paying. She was trusting a neighbor to deliver her payments, and we had not received them. Thank you for your patience in this situation, and we will continue to keep you updated on Keo Siphan and her business.

loans.name: Chandara

texts.en:
K. Chandara is requesting a $500 loan because she recently moved from Phnom Penh City and would like to have a house built for her family. The works have already begun but she needs additional funds to purchase materials and hire 2 workers to help her husband. They will come from the countryside and will be paid 10,000 Riel ($2.5) a day, plus accommodation and meals.

K. Chandara also wants to invest some money in purchasing a cart for her husband’s tuk tuk (a personal transportation vehicle pulled by a motorbike). For the moment he is renting it for $60 per month which represents almost one third of the income generated by this activity.

When the house will be built, K. Chandar would like to start a business as well. She is thinking about selling porridge in her village in the morning.

loans.use: Building a new house

payments.comment: Keo Chandara was able to finish paying off her loan early. Thank you for partnering with CREDIT to help provide this loan to Keo Chandara and her family!

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Anita, a 32 year-old originally from Manabi, Ecuador, has three children, two of whom study at the colegio. Unfortunately, her third son who is 14 years of age does attend school because Anita and her husband cannot afford it. Sra. C.’s husband works as a cabinet maker and makes $120 every month. Anita has always had an entrepreneurial spirit, and once she married, she wanted to pursue her dream of opening a breakfast restaurant with her husband.  They began by running the small restaurant out of their home, but they realized 5 years ago that they would need a larger location to accommodate the growing number of customers that frequented their place. This husband-wife team has been able to improve their home which is in an area of Guayaquil called Isla Trinitaria. With the profits from business, Anita and her husband have been able to re-do the structure of their house to brick. She wants to borrow $585 so that she can put in new flooring in her house. The way things are right now, her family is very susceptible to flu and other throat sicknesses because the flooring is just dirt. Also, Anita would like to buy more utensils for her restaurant.

loans.use: Repair Floor, Buy Tools for cabinet-making

payments.comment: Pago total de la operacion de credito

loans.name: Edeisi

texts.en: Edeisi, who was born in Esmeralda, Ecuador, has lived in Guayaquil since she was very young. Now, this 42 year-old mother of two lives with her husband in a marginalized area of the city referred to as Isla Trinitaria. Edeisi and her partner had to wait 10 years to obtain the title to their house as well as many other hardships. They lack potable water which costs $1 per tank, hygienic services, and a mode of transportation. Now 7 years widowed, Edeisi is left with her two children who are almost independent and her husband’s cabinet making business. When he passed away, Sra. B. still had possession of all of the tools, but she took the initiative in finding a worker who could continue the business to continue bringing in money for the family. One of her sons markets the finished products in the local markets. Edeisi is asking for this $365 loan to buy more wood to continue making cabinets as well as a polisher.

loans.use: Buy wood for cabinet-making

payments.comment: Pago de mes de agosto primera quota 1/8

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy more inventory for Mini Market

loans.name: Luis

texts.en: Luis is a 40 year-old native of Guayaquil who has two children and a living wife. His wife is a mannequin maker, and “Lucho” used to work in a factory. Left without work, Luis had to learn how to sell fish to continue providing for his family. For 7 years Sr. A. has worked as a fish salesman in a local market. He arrives at 4:00 am every day to buy his fresh products in the grand market, and thanks to the help of his wife, they have been able to make improvements on their home from mud and raw materials to cement. Don Luis needs this loan to be able to buy a refrigerator to keep his fish fresh throughout the day.

loans.use: Buy refigerator to keep catch of the day fresh

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en: Pedro Quiñónez, originally from Columbia, has lived in Guayaquil, Ecuador for 10 years. He is a 56-year-old married man with 3 children. His business sells household provisions and treats. Pedro’s venture is run out of his home and he has been in this business for 5 years. Clients from the neighborhood can buy goods there from 9:00am until 11:00 pm. Sr. Quiñónez woul like to take out a $475 loan to buy more inventory and purchase special order items from his regulars. Don Pedro is a hard-working entrepreneur that wants to grow his small business and advance his family’s situation.

loans.use: Purchase more household items for mini market

payments.comment: Pago de la segunda quincena grupo solidario
Pago de las 2 Quincenas de el credito Grupal (trabajando venceremos)

loans.name: Yesenia

texts.en: Yesenia Guadamó, a 29 year-old single mother originally from Vinces, Ecuador, has lived in Guayaquil for 15 years. Since she and her husband split, she has been responsible for their two children ages 6 and 7. A good friend of Yesenia’s encouraged her to open a fish market, and so she started a small business a few years back. Sra. Guadamaó opens shop at 4:00 am and usually sells out by 1:00 pm. With her revenues from one day, Yesenia will buy fish for the next, but she would like to expand her offering by taking out a $365 loan. She wants to buy seafood like fish, shrimp, and shellfish like crab and scallops. This microloan will allow Yesenia to buy in cash, whereas now she currently purchases goods on credit for a one-day period and pays nearly double to settle the debt. She wants to strengthen her business and build a board with which she can display her fish. One of the side benefits of making more profit is that Yesenia can save enough money to fix the roof of her house and send her children to a better school.

loans.use: Purchase more diverse supply of fish; Market products better with display case

payments.comment: pago de la segunda quincena Grupo solidario
Pago de las 2 Quincenas del credito grupal(trabajando venceremos)

loans.name: Mercis

texts.en: Mercis R., who was born in Esmeralda, Ecuador has lived in Guayaquil for 10 years. She is a 42 year-old single mother with 4 children, one of whom (7 years old) still lived in the household. Sra. R. has a fish business which she learned about from her parents. This long-time fish saleswoman of 15 years has been searching for a way to make greater profits so that she can provide for her children. Her daily routine is fairly normal; she wakes up at 4:00 am to buy the catch for the day at which point she brings the fish to her market and sells it until around 1:00 pm. If she does not sell all of her fish at the market, she takes it home with her and finishes selling it there, she says. Mercis wants to take out a $475 loan to buy fish in cash and choose from the freshest fish around. Also, she wants to improve the presentation of her business to market the products better and bring in more clients. Mercis wants lenders to know that she is a very industrious woman who wants nothing more than to have her business succeed so that she can provide a better life for her children.

loans.use: Buy fish in cash at a discount; Market products better with display case

loans.name: Santina

texts.en:
A. Santina is an active member of Life in Africa. She currently works in the Invisible Children Bracelet project. Her salary combined with what her husband makes working in the stone quarry sustain their family.

Her family, like so many others, were forced to flee their home in Gulu in the North because of the war with the rebels. The headed to Kampala looking for a safe place to live and settled in the camp known as the Acholi Quarters. Their life was very hard at first but since joining LiA they have begun to hope and dream of a better life. They have begun to see possibilities instead of hopelessness.

Her husband knows the aggregate business very well since he works in it every day. There is much building going on in Kampala today so the demand for crushed stone is very high demand and very lucrative. The profit is almost double the costs of securing and crushing the stone. Their plan is to finance 12 trips to secure stone and waite for the customer within Kampala. There it will be crushed and sold netting them a tidy profit to continue on as well as adding to the family income.Santinas'aim is also to creat employment to the community arround Acholi quarters. To accomplish this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800.000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Therefore below is her break down:

Labor cost for making a trip full of aggregates is as stated below:

Stone extraction from the quarry 20,000/= x 12 = 240,000/=

Bringing out from the cave is 5000 x 12 = 60,000/=

Stone crashing by hand is 35,000/= x 12 =420,000/=

Loading cost 3000/= x 12 = 36,000/=

Others 44,000/=

Total = 800,000/=

WE Team to benefit: Talent discovery.

loans.use: Sone Quarry Investment

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!
Santina has been able to recover from earlier challenges that caused her to miss some payments, and was able to repay her loan in full by December.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
N. Irene is an active member of Life in Africa. She currently works in the Invisible Children Bracelet project making bracelets and also dyeing the materials they use. She is a young wife and as yet does not have children. However, she hopes to and she wants to work now to secure a solid source of income so that her children will not have to know poverty.

Her parents have given her a four room house but it is not finished. She plans to rent out the rooms which will be a secure source of income but she knows that she will be able to earn more and keep her tenants longer if the house is complete. This will also provide better housing for the families who rent from her.

To complete this house she is seeking a loan in the amount of 700,000. She will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Her loan description is as below:

1 trips of sand @ shs. 80,000...........80,000/= Bricks 2000 @ shs.65...................130,000/= Wooden doors 2 @ shs.30,000............100,000/= Wooden windows 4 @ shs.40,000..........160,000/= Cement 5 bags @ shs.18,000............. 90,000/= Labour.................................100,000/= Transport.............................. 40,000/=

Total..................................700,000/=

WE Team to benefit: Education

loans.use: Buying materials for finishing up building

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!
Irene has managed to make some payment on her loan and is hopeful that the remainder will be paid off within the next 2 months
When Irene was no longer able to finish up her loan, due to the problem highlighted here earlier on,  Life in Africa took up the responsibility to pay , and will settle it later from within.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
O. Christopher is an active member of Life in Africa. He joined almost 6 months ago because of his passion for crafts and this has earned him a good job as a bracelet maker for the Invisible Children Bracelet project. To suppliment what he earns he also works part time in the stone quarry.

He is 30 years old and was born in Northern Uganda. His childhood was stolen from him by the rebels when they attacked, brutally killing most of his relatives including his mother. He managed to survive but was forced to flee and he ended up in the displaced persons camp in Kampala known as the Acholi Quarters. Now he is married with four children of his own. They are all safe from rebel attacks but they still live in horrible conditions in the camp. His dream is to give his children what he has never had. A safe and permanent home where they can live in peace.

He has acquired a plot of land and he plans to build a home for his children. He has been saving and already has part of the money he will need. To add to his savings he is seeking a loan in the amount ot 800,000. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Cement 15 bags @ 18,000/=...... 270,000/= Transport â€“. ..................70,000/= Sand 2 trips................... 150,000/= Labour -....................... 150,000/= Bricks 3000 @ 65/=..............195,000/= Communication.................... 8,000/=

Total...........................843,000/=

O. has saved 100,000/= to help him complete this project. He promises , with utmost good faith to service this loan in a period of 12 months in sums of 80,000/= monthly.

WE Team to benefit: Talent Discovery

loans.use: Buying materials for building family House
