loans.name: Arnold

texts.en:
Arnold K. is a very active member of Life in Africa. He joined in June of 2004 and works hard as a foreman at the center as well as a team leader for the art gallery. He also does sanding for the Invisible Children Bracelet project.

To support his family he has also opened a video library business. He believes he can expand and improve his business by offering additional services. A pay phone would be one of these services that is much needed by his clients who cannot afford to have their own phone. In addition he plans to also sell airtime cards for his clients who have cell phones. This will be a convenience for them since they will not have to move to so many different places to have their needs met. The sister is willing to work in this project at 30,000/= which Arnold has accepted to pay.

To accomplish this he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Phonebooth - @400,000 - 400,000 Airtime cards - 6 packets - @ 50,000 -300,000 Rent - 5months - @20,000 - 100,000

WE Team to benefit: Gallery promotion services

loans.use: Installation and buying airtime

loans.name: Peace

texts.en:
Peace Komugisha is a mutoro by tribe aged 45 years. She is a mother of four children though she is now living a single life in Kampala. Her husband passed away and she has no plans yet of returning to the village as her job now is the only means of supporting herself and family. Peace komugisha’s way of life in Kampala here was basically on local brew. She could make local brew, which is bused so much by the people living in the slums of Kampala. Much as this local brews consumed these city dwellers, peace got fed up with this type of business as she find that dealing with drunkard persons is a very hard task.

She joined life in Africa four months ago after she had dropped the local brew business and now working for the invisible children bracelet project as a bracelet maker. By the time Komugisha dropped the business, she had saved 200,000/= that she wishes to use for the construction of a family house in her village Mbarara. With the current job she has at Life in Africa her saving is now 400,000/= She looks at this loan scheme as an opportunity for her to own her dream house. With this regards she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000/= that she is to repay in 12 months at a rate of 80000/= and below is her break down:

14 iron sheets of 32 gauge @ 10000 =. 140,000/=

3000bricks @ 50/= ……………………….150,000/=

15 bags of cement @ 18000……………….270,000/=

3 trips of sand @ 30000/=…………………90,000/=

Labor………………………………………..300,000/=

20 roofing timbers 4x3. @ 5000……………..100,000/=

One trip of aggregates ……………………….60,000/=

2 wooden doors @ 50000……………………100,000/=

2 wooden windows @ 15000…………………30,000/=

5kgs of nails @ 3000………………………….15,000/=

Total……………………………………………1,110,000/=

WE Team to benefit: Term: Talent discovery

loans.use: Building family house

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
O. Alfred is an active member of Life in Africa. He joined in September of 2005 and has worked very hard to provide for his family, which includes his wife and six children.

They were displaced by the war in Northern Uganda. He came from Gulu and has been completely separated from his other family members. He believes many of them are now dead and the others have not been able to be traced since the fled from the rebels. He and his family live in the camp known as the Acholi Quarters where they live in a small rented house.

He has acquired a plot of land from the King of Buganda who has mercy for these suffering people. He dreams of building a real home once again for his children and he has been working diligently towards that goal. He has managed to save 200,000 from his salary. Building this house will not only improve their living conditions and give them a permanant home, but it will free up the money they now have to pay for rent, which can be used to benefit the family. To complete this house he is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000/=. He will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

His budget is as below: Bricks 3000 @ 65/= 195,000/= Sand 2 trips @ 80,000/= 160,000/= Labor 150,000/= Iron 14 @10,000/= 140,000/= Transport 60,000/= Doors and windows 150,000/=

Total 855,000/=

WE Team to benefit:Talent discovery

loans.use: Buying building materials

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website, but the current state of the payment records is discouraging. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!

Alfred finished his loan, two months ago and with the arrangement of auto payments that we have with kiva, we had thought that this would be automatically posted and yet the earlier loans of 2006 were not under this arrangement, and we really regret any inconvinience caused by not updating this payment.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith T. is young woman from Kabale in Southwestern Uganga. She is a single mother of one child and is the sole support for herself and the child. She was never able to be educated in her village and she longed for a better life. So she left the village and moved to Kampala hoping to get an education and a good job.

Then her younger sister had to come and live with her and she had to give up on her own education. Instead, she has put all her efforts into keeping her sister and her child in school. This was very difficult since she had no steady income. Then she found Life in Africa where she now works in the Invisible Children bracelet project. The life has much improved but she knows she must do more to achieve all her goals.

Her plan is to open a business dealing with millet which is in high demand since it is a nutritious food source and is one of the staples of the Ugandan diet. She has already found a building to rent. She will employ one person to work the shop while she continues with her work at Life in Africa. She believes that the added income will make life much easier and will insure that her sister and child are able to finish school. For this project she is seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000/= and she will be able to repay this loan in 12 months.

Below is her Budget:

Millet grain 20 bags @30,000/= 600,000/= Saucepans 2 units @10,000/= 20,000/= Transport 36,000/= Rent 70,000/=(5 months advance) Containers 2 units @30,000/= 60,000/= Cups 12 units @1,200/= 14,400/=

Total 800,400/= Judith will pay the loan back in 12 months at the rate of 80,000/= per months WE Team to benefit: Education

 WE Team to benefit: Adult Education

loans.use: Start up a millet store

Judith was able to recover from some financial challenges, and repaid her loan in December 2008.

loans.name: Steven

texts.en:
S. Steven is an active and hard working member of Life in Africa. He is the proud father of one child and he is employed in the Invisible Children bracelet project as a sander.

Before coming to Life in Africa, he was a hawker. He walked miles each day selling small personal items like hair pins, soap, perfume, sunglasses and other items. The income he earned was what sustained his family but it was unreliable and on some days he earned nothing. This made life difficult. Now, his income is consistent and their lives have improved greatly.

Their biggest expense is the rent they pay for their small home. However, he does own a home that is not finished since it still lacks a roof. He has been saving to complete it. Once it is roofed, his family will be able to have a better life with the money they will be saving on rent and they will also have the pride of owning their own home. To complete this project he is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000/= and he will be able to repay this loan in 10 months.

Below is his budget:

Iron sheets 30 units: 1 unit=11,000 330,000/= Labour 200,000/=

Total 530,000/= At present he has saved 30,000/= to help with the same. Steven will pay back this loan in full in 10 months.

WE Team to benefit: Craft Production

loans.use: Buying materials for roofing

A journal update about this particular borrower's performance is next on our Kiva reporting agenda - thanks for your patience!

loans.name: Sopheng

texts.en:
C. Sopheng moved from Phnom Penh City to this newly populated area only one week ago. He is living with his wife and one grandson in a little shelter built quickly. He is requesting $300 to turn it into a proper house. He will but the materials and rent tools to perform the works with the help of a few relatives. He estimates they need only 2 days of hard labor to complete the task.

C. Sopheng is self employed as a moto-taxi and can make around $3 profit per day. His wife used to have a small laundry service business in Phnom Penh but now she doesn’t know what she can do.

C. Sopheng has a plan for the future. When this new village will be connected to basic facilities such as water and electricity, he will launch a business of producing and selling ice cream. “I don’t know exactly how to produce it, but I can learn from friends”, he said.

loans.use: Building a new house

loans.name: Sokrorn

texts.en:
H. Sokhorn is requesting a $500 loan to build a proper house in the plot she was recently allocated by the government in Phnom Penh far suburbs. H. Sokhorn is not employed; she stays at home and takes care of her children, while her husband is self-employed as a mason. He learnt his skill when employed by a Chinese company, which ceased its activities 4 years ago. He sustains his family with around $5 daily but his income is not steady. He has to propose competitive bids to be in charge of the works, but as he is a gifted worker, he is not worrying about unemployment.

With the $500, H. Sokrom will purchase materials and her husband will built the house in addition to his casual workload.

Hom Sokhorn would like to start a business of catering for the neighborhood, if the village becomes more populated.

loans.use: Building a new house

loans.name: Siengdy

texts.en:
Seng Siengdy is a single mother living with her six children, two of them already grown and employed in sewing and cement factories and three others going to school.

Seng Siengdy was granted a small plot of land after being displaced from Phnom Penh to this new village. As her neighbors, Seng Siengdy would like to build a house very soon and she requested $500 to have the works performed. If everything goes smoothly, she expects her house to be built in 1 week only, considering she will hire 3 workers full-time.

Seng Siengdy used to have a small business in town. She was selling ice for the small restaurant on the streets. She would like to start again but the village is not yet connected to the power grid and the demand for ice is very low, as there is not yet a restaurant. The family is confident about repaying the loans on the children’s salaries, which is $220 cumulated per month. “This won’t be easy, but the house is worth it”, she said.

loans.use: Building a new house

loans.name: Dara

texts.en:
S. Dara is married and father of three children, all of them are go to school in Phnom Penh city. He is self-employed as a moto-taxi driver and makes around 15,000 Riel every day. His wife is running a very special business, as she sells Ants’ Eggs to a few traditional restaurants of the City. Ants’ Eggs are very scarce in Phnom Penh but S. Dara’s wife has good connections with collectors from the provinces and she can sell for 150,000 Riel ($37.5) daily with a margin of around 40%.

S. Dara already spent $900 of his personal savings on the roof and the walls of his new house but he needs an additional $500 to finish it. He will perform most of the building operations by himself and hopes to finish it very soon.

After building the house, S. Dara is considering resuming his career as a government officer he interrupted 7 years ago for familial obligations.

loans.use: Building a new house

payments.comment:
Siek Dara and his family were able to repay their loan quicker than they had initially anticipated. They are very thankful for the loan, and happy about having a new home for their family. Thank you for lending to Siek Dara, and helping his family have a better start to their life in their new community. 

Thank you for partnering with us, from CREDIT Staff.

loans.name: Som At

texts.en:
S. Som At is married and mother of 6 children, who are between 30 and 12 years old. She is not employed but still very busy with taking care of her children and grandchildren. Her husband is a moto-taxi, and brings two of their children to school in the city every morning.

S. Som At moved to this new place with her family only 12 days ago. All of them are still camping until their new house is built. That is why S. Som At contacted CREDIT. She needs a $500 loan to rent the skilled labor force ($250 for 1 week) and purchase the materials (another $250). S. Som At is saving money on the materials because she moved with the remains of her previous house. She already has wood and zinc for the roof.

When the house is finished, S. Som At is planning to start a business in the community. “With my next loan”, she said.

loans.use: Building a new house

loans.name: Dorah

texts.en:
Dora M. is 60 years old, married with 10 children. Out of the ten children 8 are independent while 2 still go to school.

Dorah is a farmer, grows and sells maize, Potatoes, Beans, coffee, and sells milk too.

She started this business 20 years ago and it has assisted her to educate all her children.

Her business makes at least USD 125 per month and this assists her to pay school fees for her 2 children and general household requirements. The poor storage facility forces her to sell at cheap prices whereas if she had improved facility, she would be storing her produce until the prices are relatively high.

loans.use: Dorah would like to renovate her granary which allows rodents and leaking thus destroying her farm produce.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is 56 years old, married with 1 child.  She has been a member of Kabuta Ladies in Action since 2001. The group runs a group revolving fund where she received a loan of USD100 in 2003 fortunately paid in time. Her first loan helped her to buy pesticides for her coffee which at the end of the season she sold and made a profit of USD200. She grows and sells tea leaves, cabbages, and potatoes. In addition to vegetables, Jane also sells milk in Gakira which gives her USD 30 as profit in a month.

loans.use: Jane wants to improve her farming by buying fodder for her dairy cow, buy fertilizer and agro chemicals for her cabbages to keep high quality vegetables.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a widow aged 50 years with 6 children. Single handedly, she has been able to educate her children where one is in secondary school while three are in college and two have finished college but not yet employed.

She is an active member of Anglican Church of Kenya where she is a choir member. Also she is a member of Kabuta Ladies in Action a community based organization whose activities aim at uplifting and promoting income generating activities at house hold level.

Joyce is a farmer and grows maize, beans, coffee, Potatoes and Vegetables both for sale and home consumption. More so, she sells milk which gives her about USD 10 per month.

loans.use: Joyce wants to pay school fees for her children because her business’s cash flow is low but can raise the money in three months.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Lois would like to improve her embroidery work by buying maasai materials.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 56 years old, married and all her children are independent. Unfortunately, one of her daughters passed away and left three children. Margaret takes care of the three children. Two are in primary school while the oldest one assists her to run the business. She is working hard to educate them up to at least college level. She set her business near the busiest bus stage of Rongai. Her business is located near the bus stop and therefore makes a lot of sales in the evening when the residents going back home from work. However, in the morning she supplies to those who roast\boil maize along the roadside. She buys fresh maize from various markets; Wakulima, Kiserian and Kadisi.

loans.use: Margaret wants to start selling other food stuffs such as yellow bananas, mangoes, green pepper, and onions.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is married with 2 children. She is trained as a hair dresser and has located her business in a very busy area of Rongai centre. Monica joined WEEC program in 2003 and has received training on Group leadership, Basic business skills, and Customer care.

 Monica wants to make optimum use of her room. She therefore wants to add cosmetics, and also buy stock of the current attires that are fashionable for the youth. When she has many customers, Monica hires trained hairdressers and pays them on commission basis. She is also preparing to start training those who want to become hairdressers but can’t afford to pay for fulltime hairdressing course.

loans.use: Monica wants to buy Cosmetics, Fashionable clothes and some plastic seats for her trainees to use.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a single mother and 50 years old. Her husband married another wife when Ruth failed to get many children. In 2003 she started a small business of selling green maize. She moved from house to house especially in parklands area selling. This work was very tedious and she decided to get a permanent stall in Rongai. From her proceeds she managed to buy a small plot where she settled with her son.

Ruth has set her business at the busy Tuesso stage Ongata Rongai. Her main customers are the casual workers who work in stone quarries at Rimpa, Gataka and those that live in Kware slum area. They pay her on a weekly basis as they get their wages. She intends to stock more items to cater for their demand. She also supplies the people who roast maize on the roadsides. Ruth`s average sales is USD 7 per day.

loans.use: Ruth wants to include other foodstuffs such as cassava, arrow roots, yams and Irish potatoes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Rose would like to purchase a variety of fruits to increase her customer base.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en: Amina is married with three children.She lives in the outskirts of Dar es Salaam where there is no public water service system.Residents depends on shallow wells which are not covered as the main source of water for domestic use. Outbreak of waterborne deseases like diarrhoea and cholera is common.Amina through her savings managed to drill a shallow well and covered it with a slab made of cement.Her business is not yet operational because she is short of funds of buying reservior tank and an electrical pump.She needs an additional capital of USD 750 so as to buy an Electrical pump and a Tank to effectivelly run her business.The tank will be used as a distribution and a water treatment point.The business would make her improve her livelihood but more important provide a valuable water service to the community.

loans.use: Purchase of an Electrical Pump and a Reservior Tank

loans.name: Leonard

texts.en: Leonard is married with three children. He lives in Kiwalani area in Dar es Salaam. He sells vegetables and fruits near his residence. He buys fresh produce of fruits and vegetables from nearby villages for resale at a small profit. The business has been his main source of livelihood for the past ten years. The business has not grown because he has to make a balance between business and family needs. The proposed loan will assist Leonard to expand his business by adding new products. The amount needed to expand his business is US$ 950. If his business is expanded, he will be able to meet the challenge of paying school fees for his child who is expected to start secondary education. The business provides a source of employment for his wife too.

loans.use: WORKING CAPITAL

loans.name: Felichesm

texts.en: M. lives in Vituka area in Dar es Salaam. He owns a shop selling different consumable items. He aims at increasing the stock of soft drinks.  Soft drinks have high turnover in his shop. The demand of soft drinks in Dar es Salaam is high because of the weather, it is hot through out the year. The profit margin of soft drinks, mainly Pepsi cola are high if one a retailer buys more than 50 crates at a time. The loan requested will enable M. to meet the needs of a profitable level of purchase of stocks. He is asking for a loan of US$ 950.

loans.use: Working  Capital

loans.name: Wangaeli

texts.en: S. is married with four children. He lives in Kiwalani area in Dar es Salaam. He owns a shop near his residence. He sells different items in his shop. He recently realized high demand for sewing and tailoring supplies. With his savings he managed to stock few of these sewing materials. He cannot meet the demand for these items due to insufficient working capital. He is in need of additional capital of USD 950 to run this new line of business effectively.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Eorn

texts.en:
T. Eorn and his family used to live in Phnom Penh city, near to a pagoda. They moved 12 days ago because the Cambodian government granted them a piece of land in this new village, around 25 kilometers away from the center of the city.

T. Eorn is married and lives with his wife and 5 children. His two eldest daughters are already working in a factory, making $45 per month, while two of his children are still going to school and two stay with her wife at home. He is employed by the government and earns $120 monthly.

T. Earn requested $500 to build a house for his family to live properly. He stressed their need to have toilets installed in her house. The village is not yet connected to the power and the water grids but she expect this to be done soon. When her loan will be disbursed, T. Eorn will purchase raw materials and hire two people for three weeks, until the works are completed.

“This new house is a real chance for the 7 of us”, she said, “because living outside the city is good for our health and safer for our children”.

loans.use: Building a new house for his family

loans.name: Sokni

texts.en:
M. Sokni is a moto-taxi in Phnom Penh. He moved in this new village from downtown a couple of weeks ago and is now riding the 25 kilometers back and forth everyday for a net profit of 10,000 Riel ($2.5).

His wife is employed in a sewing factory in Phnom Penh and M. also transports her to her workplace and back home at night. Her salary is about $70 per month.

With the $500 he requested, Sokni would like to upgrade the house he built in a hurry when the couple was granted this piece of land. He is to buy materials and tools but also filling land to elevate the ground floor of the house. This improvement is critical as the rainy months already started.  

Sokni expects to be able to perform these improvements by himself in two weeks time. If there is still a little money left at the end, he would like to open a shop in front of his house and sell grocery and coffee to the people of the community.

loans.use: Housing improvement

loans.name: Somoul

texts.en:
I. Somoul is living with her grown son in a quickly built and precarious shelter in a new village around 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They moved in two weeks ago and have felt a critical need for housing improvement since their arrival. I. Somoul herself requested a $300 loan but she trusts her son to manage everything related to the works. He explained us he is going to buy for $250 of materials such as sand, cement, wood and zinc and hire two people from the community for 100,000 Riel ($25) for 1 week. He truly believes the works can be completed one single week after receiving the money from CREDIT.

I. Somoul is concerned about repaying her loan. She is self-employed and sells fruits and vegetable in a Market in Phnom Penh. She gets up early morning with her son and together they go to buy their fruits and vegetables at 4 am. She usually finishes at 5pm. She can make 20,000 Riel ($5) profit every day, while her son is making 10,000 Riel from taxi fares.

loans.use: Improving the house

loans.name: Kaemorak

texts.en:
W. Kaemorak is married and lives with his wife and three children in the house they built quickly after moving into their new village. He started the works two weeks ago but needs additional funds to complete the improvement he planed. He is doing everything alone, “by my own” he said in English.

W. Kaemorak speaks a little English. He learnt when driving foreigners on his moto-taxi. He would like to learn more but his wife say he is too old now. “English is for fresh brains”, she said. Their two youngest children, 14 and 5 years old, are going to school six days a week.

As for the family resources, the moto taxi breeds around 12,000 Riel ($3) per day. Kaemorak’s wife can make around 10,000 Riel ($2.5) in sewing trousers and repairing clothes on her machine at home. The family eldest son is employed as a security guard in a night club in Phnom Penh. He makes $80 per month and works at night.

loans.use: Finish to build his house

loans.name: Sa Hel

texts.en:
P. Sa Hel and his brother are building a brand new house in a new village from scratch. This will take a full month and cost around $1,000, but P. Sa Hel and his wife have savings and are only requesting a $500 loan. This is a price worth paying for this couple to have their own house.

P. Sa Hel is a moto-taxi and makes around 12,000 Riel ($3) a day. His wife is employed in a shop in Phnom Penh. She sells mobile phones and earns around 60,000 Riel per day ($15). They are very confident in repaying this loan on time.

P. Sa Hel is very happy with the situation. “I like this new place”, he said, “because there is fresh air”. “The place is not for sale”, he added, “we will raise our family here!”

loans.use: Building a brand new house

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is married with four children. She lives in Kijichi area in Dar es Salaam. The area has no reliable water supply. By the help of her husband and her own savings she managed to buy a water tank and an electric pump. The current size of the tank is not sufficient to meet demand of water from residents.  No public water system exist in the area. Erratic power supply which is experienced by all residents in Dar es Salaam also justifies the need for an additional storage tank and its accessories.  The additional tank will also provide an additional facility for treatment of water ready for domestic use. The project has a great value to the community as it provides a valuable resource need by each households and reduces incidences of water borne diseases.

loans.use: Purchase of Water Tank

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase stock of used clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase the stock of firewood for the business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more fabrics.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy and sell more poultry.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase the stock the stock of produce.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase the stock of pharmacy

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase stock of poultry breed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add more stock in the secretarial bereau.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add more stock in secretarial work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase on stock of Timber.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add more stock in the business of clothes and shoes.

loans.name: Sunanda

texts.en:
Ms.Sunanada K. - age 18 - is a spinster .She stays with her family of 5. She is educated up to 7th class is living in her small village called Sanganatti in Mudhol taluka of Bagalkot district in Karnataka, India. Now she is engaged in tailoring with a single sewing machine. She earns  Rs.30/- per day. She wants to purchase a improved sewing machine with which she will be able to stitch more cloths to increase her daily income to Rs.50/- to Rs.60/- per day.  To purchase this sewing machine she requires a loan amount of Rs.3000/-. Loan repayment will be completed in 1 years and installment will paid once in every 6 month. 

*July 2006 exchange rate is 46 rupees to the US  dollar

loans.use: Sunanda will purchase an improved sewing machine to stitch more clothes

loans.name: Siddaling

texts.en:
Mr.Siddaling P. – handicapped - aged 19 years is bachelor staying with his 5 family members. He was illliterate but is now able to read and write with the help of night school. He lives in a small village called Marapur in Mudhol taluka of Bagalkot district in Karnataka, India. He now does tailoring work in the village for Rs.50/- day. He would like to shift to dairy business by purchase one she buffalo. By rearing this buffalo he will be able to get about 12-15 liters milk per day and by which he will be able to earn an amount of Rs.125/- to Rs.150/- per day with a net profit of Rs.75/- to Rs.100/- per day. To purchase buffalo he requires a loan amount of Rs.15000/-. Loan repayment will be completed in 2 years and installment will paid every month.

*July 2006 exchange rate is 46 rupees to the US
dollar

loans.use: Purchasing a buffalo

loans.name: Renukavva

texts.en:
Ms.Renukavva Y.M. - aged 30 years, has two daughters. She was ill literate and now able to read and write by attending night school in her small village called Madabhavi in Mudhol taluka of Bagalkot district in Karnataka, India.  Now she is working as a farm labor for Rs.40/- day. She would like to purchase one she buffalo. By rearing this buffalo she will be able to get about 12-15 liters milk per day and by which she will be able to earn an amount of Rs.125/- to Rs.150/- per day with a net profit of Rs.75/- to Rs.100/- per day. To by this she bufellow she requires a loan amount of Rs.15000/-. Loan repayment will be completed in 2 years and installment will paid every month.

*July 2006 exchange rate is 46 rupees to the US
dollar

loans.use: Purchasing a she-buffalo

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
Ms. Sunita S.P. - aged 28  is  married and has 4 children. She was educated up to 7th class. She is living in her village called Saidapur in Mudhol taluka of Bagalkot district in Karnataka, India. Now she is engaged in small-scale leather business by which she is earning an amount of Rs.35/- per day. She purchases raw leather and after fine finish she supplies the same to foot wears makers. Now she would like to expand her business by employing one or two woman labourers. To expand her business she requires a loan amount of Rs.10000/-. Loan repayment will be completed in 1 year and installment will paid every month.

*July 2006 exchange rate is 46 rupees to the US
dollar

loans.use: To hire 2 additional labourers

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary Warua is 62 years old, married with 6 children, 2 of them still live with her and provides every thing.

Mary has been selling used clothes for the last seven years. The business has been performing very well because these items are not only cheap but also affordable by many people. This gives her a high profit margin and keeps her pushing forward. She also grows coffee on a small scale and keeps a dairy cow. There is improvement in milk prices and this is encouraging her to buy another cow, which can give about 20 litres per day.

loans.use: She would like to buy a dairy cow that can give her 20 litres per day.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 48 yrs old a widow and has 5 children. Of these children, two are in secondary school; two in primary school while the other is working.

Lucy has been carrying out farming activities for 22 years, and this provides for her household necessities. Her coffee plantation is about three hectares and has another hectare where she grows fodder and seasonal crops. Due to low prices of coffee in the whole country, she has been concentrating on dairy farming. At least she earns about USD 70 per month.

loans.use: Lucy wants to buy a diary cow to supplement her income.

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en:
Sylvia is 50 years old married with 4 children, two of them are independent and two still in college and secondary school.

She has been running a small shop for the last 8 years, realizing a net income of approximately USD 100 per month. She has also a small coffee farm, which brings in some income seasonally.However, this is not enough to sustain her family requirements thus, need for extra source of income.

loans.use: She intends to buy a high breed dairy cow that will produce aleast 18 litters of milk per day.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 53 years old a widow with 5 children. Two are in a local technical college and one in High School.

Jane has been in farming for 28 years and it’s from farming that she has been able to educate her children. She has 400 trees of coffee on a three-hectare piece of land and 2 Dairy cows, which in aggregate brings a net income of USD100 per month.

loans.use: She wants to replace in phases her current dairy cows which on average produce 8 litters of milk per day with hybrid cows that can give 15 litres per day.

loans.name: Adonijo

texts.en:
Adonijo is 49 years old married with 5 children; two are in a technical college while the other one is in High School.

She has been in horticulture farming for more than 20 years and has a good customer base of institutions such as schools and local hotels.

The loan applied for of $600 is intended to diversify her area of farming to include dairy farming. Her objective is to take advantage of this group of dairy farmers she joined recently because they will be buying animal feeds and drugs as a group which is cheaper than when you are alone.

loans.use: Adonijo wants to buy a dairy cow so as to improve her daily income from the sell of milk.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary W. is 53 years old widow with 6 children, one in college, two in High school and others in primary school.

She grows vegetables on a 2-hectare piece of land. She has been selling vegetables for more than 5 years. Demand for her vegetables grows day by day because the society is now aware of the values in vegetables due to home development seminars chairperson of her group and the campaign by the government about health living.

loans.use: Income from vegetables is not enough and thus she wants also to start selling milk, which is easy to market and does not take a lot of time.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane M. is 56 years old, married with 5 children. Three of her children are independent while the others are in a technical college.

Jane has been running her shop for more than 18 years, realizing a net income of approximately $180 per month. She also has a small farm from which she gets additional income and food for her family.

As a member of a dairy farming group, she will greatly increase her income given that she has all other necessary resources.

loans.use: She intends to purchase a hybrid dairy cow, which can produce a lot of milk.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane K. is 49 years old married with 5 children, 3 in college and 2 in High school.

For approximately 18 years, Jane has been keeping poultry and it has been her sole source of income. She always keeps 600 broilers every crop and she constantly supplies to her customers in Kangema Town. She also has two dairy cows each producing roughly 10 litters of milk. Annually she realizes a gross income that ranges between $ 400 and $ 500 per month.

loans.use: She would like to buy a dairy cow, which would be producing approximately 20 litters of milk per day.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
My first loan I invested in only clothing. It was for L500.00. The second loan I used for plastics and I earned a profit. With the third loan I was awarded L700.00 and I bought my refigerator and I began to sell what I am selling at present.

With my individual credit, I am able to sell more because I have invested in my business and with the earnings I have recieved, I can better my home. Thank you to the Adelante Foundation.

Loan Use: Sodas, ice, food storage/display to sell in shop

Original Description in Spanish: Mi primer prestamo lo inverti en ropa solo fueron L500.00 pero algo es algo. El segundo en plastico y fui obteniendo ganancia. Me prestara L700.00 con el tercer prestamo y compre mi refrigeradora y empese a vender lo que vendo ahora. 

Con mi credito individual, vendo mas porque lo he invertido en mi negocio y con las ganacias he podido hacerle mejora ma mi casa. Gracias a Fundacion Adelante.

loans.use: Refrescos, hielo, venta de comida

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
With my first loan of L500.00, I bought eggs, one pig, sodas and with the earnings I have invested in the betterment of my home. My home used to be old and dilapitated.

With my individual loan I have bought more pigs, sodas and foods. With my earnings that I have made divisions (for rooms) that are made of cement. Also, I am the educator of my assembly.

Loan use: Caring for the pigs, butchering of the pigs, food storage display to sell in shop, sodas.

Original Description in Spanish: Con mi primer prestamo de L500.00 compro huevos, un cerdo, y refrescos y las ganacias los invertio mejorar la casa, mi cas era manaca y cana brava.

Con mi prestamo individual he comprado mas cerdos, refrescos y comidas. Con las ganacias he hecho los divisiones de mi casa que ahora es de cemento. Tambien, soy la educadora de mi asemblea.

loans.use: Cria de cerdo, destoso de cerdo, venta de comidas, refrescos

loans.name: Maria Concepcion

texts.en: My name is Maria Concepcion A. M., but they call me Concha.  I am 30 Years old and I have 1 daughter who is 14.  I have been with Adelante for 1 ½ years and am on my third loan.   I had a small business before, but it was very small and didn’t make much money.  Now I have bought a microwave, some furniture and a lot of other things for my house with the earnings from my business.  I have also been able to buy things for my daughter that I couldn’t before like new clothes, shoes, and now I am able to send her to highschool.  I wouldn’t be where I am today without the loans and education from Adelante.  For example we recently had a business planning lecture that talked about planning enough time for family and business and for me that was very useful.  I have also learned a lot about how to keep a record of my business – to record sales and inventory so that I can grow my business. In the next year or two I would like to be able to buy my own house, continue to grow my business and continue to learn.I had very little when I started but I had a small business – it wasn’t until my first loan with Adelante that I have been able to really make a business.With the education lessons I know how to grow inventory I even bought a freezer to increase the products to sell and I will increase my sales by notating what sells.  I have recommended several women to Adelante and tell them that they will be given money and knowledge to start their own business.  But I also tell them that they need to be ready to work and if they are then they can have a business like just like mine.

loans.use: Assorted items - general retail

loans.name: Keefa

texts.en:
My name is P. Keefa and a married man with four children. I joined life in Africa in january and also work with the Invisible children's bracelet project as a sander. From the wages makes, he supports and maintain them all. I also live in rented house and the money he payS for rent is really my biggest expense and makes life very difficult. I would really dream of having a house of my own. I already have a good sized piece of land on which to build my own house. This house means total security to my children and wife ven when am gone from this world. This is why am seeking a loan in the amount of 800,000/= to help me achieve this dream. He is ready to pay this loan within 10 months. Loan use: Build family house

Loan term: 10 months

Loan payment; 80,000/=

Below is his budget:

Labour 100,000/= Cement 9 bags @ 17,000 153,000/= Nails 20,000/= Bricks 5,000 @45/= 225,000/= Timbers 12 @ 500/= 6,000/= iron sheets 18pcs @11,000 198,000/= Sand 3 trips 30,000/= Transport 3 trips 30,000/= Water 30,000/= Communication 8,000/=

Total 800,000/=

WE Team to benefit: Education

loans.use: Building a family house

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website, but the current state of the payment records is discouraging. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose M. is a very wonderful lady who joined Life in Africa early this year. She is a widow with 8 children. Her husband died from a motor accident in 2001. She is very skilled in handcrafts and makes such beautiful crafts like ladies bags, scarves, mats, baskets, beads, etc. She is currently renting a house in Nsambya, a suburb of Kampala. She earns her living and supports her family through earnings from the bracelet project at LiA and wholesale store near her place of residence that deals with foodstuffs like beans, cowpeas, maize and soyabeans. She needs to expand this business so as to be able to maintain her children in school, pay the house rent, feeding and clothing plus medicare. She is now seeking aloan in the amount of 800,000/= to expand this business and get more profits and increase her savings so that infuture, she can begin to build her own house so as to get rid of this rent business because, rent actually uses much more money that anything else in her life. These savings also would help with the ever increasing school fees for the children. Rose will be able to pay back this loan in 10 months. Below is her budget:

Beans 12 bags 60,000 - 720,000 Transport 84,000

Total 804,000

Loan use: e Expand Wholesale Food Store

Loan term: 10 months

Loan repayment: 80,000/= per month

WE Team to benefit: Education

loans.use: Expanding food store

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!

The total amount LiA has repaid to Kiva for this loan is now equivalent to payments received by LiA from the borrower. Visit LifeInAfrica.com/kiva/2006loans.htm to view the current repayment status of all Kiva loans disbursed at Life in Africa in 2006. A journal update about this particular borrower's performance is next on our Kiva reporting agenda - thanks for your patience!

loans.name: Faustino

texts.en:
Faustino O. is a member of Life in Africa and a family man too. He has lived through thick and thin to support his family. He left the stone Quarrying business to his wife and started working with the invisible bracelet project as a bracelet producer and because of his articulate and concise approach to issues, Faustino was entrusted with quality control in the invisible children Bracelet campaign that is in partnership with Life in Africa. With his visionary acumen, he seeks to expand his house by constructing two more rooms for rent, which will help him to save more money to square his family bills.

Faustino has already saved 250,000 and to to meet his expectations of expansion he needs a loan of 800,000 UGX and he comfortably believes he will service the loan over a period of 10 months in premium sums of 80,000 from his monthly IC salary and the stone business itself.

His budget is as follows:

Bricks 4000 @ Ushs.60 = 240,000 Iron Sheets 24pcs @Ushs. 11,000 = 264,000 Bags of Cement 10Pkts @Ushs.18500 = 185,000 Timber @Ushs. 60,000 Transport @Ushs. 40,000 Water @ Ushs.11, 000 Labour 250,000 Total Ushs. 1,050,000

WE Team to benefit:Member Services

loans.use: Expanding Family House

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther T. is a mother of three, Esther lives with her husband who is a businessman. She joined Life in Africa in October 2004. She is a very talented designer especially gifted with tie and dye and, also makes awesome crafts. Her tie and dye fabrics are much sought after especillay by African women. Esther also works at Life in Africa with the invisible children bracelet project as a bracelet producer. she does earn an income that can help with the house expenses. Esther's challenge is that after making her tie and dye products, she needs to ask some one with a sewing machine to help her sew her beautiful into garments so she can put them up for sale. She then has to pay for this service by the sewing machine owner. If only she had her own machine, she would be producing lots good quality garments. This is the reason why she now seeks a loan in the amount of 800,000/= so she can have her own machine and buy materials to do this work without her having to pay for the service. This will also enable her to do her work much faster and more attention will be paid to it. Esther will be able to pay back this money in 12 months. Below is her budget:

Sewing machine 400,000/= Material cloth 200,000/= Rent 150,000/= Contingencies 50,000/= Total 800,000/=

WE Team to benefit: Education

loans.use: Purchasing a sewing machine and Tie & Dye Fabrics.
